analysis: Interesting pick from the Kings. They drafted a shooter in Ben McLemore last year, but Stauskas might be a better version of McLemore. He's more cocky, which means he's less shy about letting it fly. But I don't see how McLemore and Stauskas can play together, and for a defensively challenged team, Stauskas shouldn't be your guy. Meanwhile, the Kings still need another point guard.

strengths: Ideal PF size with long arms • Great rebounder, aggressive on both ends • Good mobility and coordination for size
weaknesses: Needs improved low post footwork • Struggles with on-court awareness • Confidence and experience issues
awards: Third-team All- Big Ten ( 2014 ), Big Ten Freshman of the Year (2014), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
analysis: Vonleh's slide has more to do with teams' concerns about how raw he is. He's got enormous potential, and he can play both inside and on the perimeter. He can rebound and run the floor. No doubt he's an upside pick, but I'm not sure how he fits with Cody Zeller. I think the Hornets took the best talent available.

strengths: Ideal size and quickness for a point guard • Strong defensive instincts and skills • Effective in transition and finishing at rim
weaknesses: Needs to improve shooting range and consistency • Struggles with left-hand finishes • High turnover rate, plays out-of-control at times
awards: Lefty Driesell Award (2014), Sun Belt Defensive Player of the Year (2014), 2× First-team All-Sun Belt (2013, 2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2015 ), All–NBA G League Third Team ( 2024 ), NBA G League Assists Leader (2024)
analysis: Update: The Sixers will trade this pick to the Magic for the rights to Dario Saric and swap a future first-round pick. I love Elfrid Payton. He was my sleeper in the draft.

strengths: Unbelievable scoring skills • Excellent shooter with deep range • High basketball IQ and good decision-making
weaknesses: Struggles defensively against NBA athleticism • Limited physical and athletic ability • Not effective creating own perimeter shot
awards: National college player of the year ( 2014 ), 3× Consensus first-team All-American ( 2012 – 2014 ), 2× Lute Olson Award (2012, 2014), NCAA scoring champion (2014), 2× MVC Player of the Year (2012, 2013), Big East Player of the Year (2014), 3× First-team All- MVC (2011–2013), First-team All-Big East (2014), 2× MVC tournament MVP ( 2012 , 2013 ), No. 3 retired by Creighton Bluejays
analysis: The Nuggets will send McDermott to the Bulls for the No. 16 and No. 19 picks. The Bulls have really wanted a shooter and someone who can play for them right now. McDermott checks both boxes. It's a great pick for the Bulls.

strengths: Versatile point‑forward vision • Competitive rebounder • Crafty scorer inside and out
weaknesses: Average NBA burst • Needs quicker lateral defense • Streaky three‑pointer
awards: Adriatic League MVP ( 2014 ), Adriatic League Final Four MVP ( 2014 ), Adriatic League Top Scorer ( 2014 ), Adriatic League Top Prospect ( 2014 ), Adriatic League Ideal Five (2014), 2× FIBA European Young Player of the Year (2013, 2014), Croatian League champion (2013), Croatian League Finals MVP ( 2013 ), 2× Croatian Cup champion (2010, 2013), 2× All-Croatian League First Team (2013, 2014), All-Croatian League Second Team (2011), 2× All-Croatian League Forward of the Year (2013, 2014), FIBA Europe Under-18 Championship MVP ( 2012 ), FIBA Europe Under-16 Championship MVP ( 2010 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2017 ), EuroLeague 50–40–90 club ( 2016 ), EuroLeague Free Throw Percentage leader (2016), Turkish Cup champion (2015), Turkish Presidential Cup champion (2015)
analysis: The Magic will send Saric to the Sixers for Elfrid Payton. Saric is a great value here at No. 12. He's one of the most skilled players in the draft. He has an unbelievable feel for the game. Unfortunately, he just signed a three-year deal in Turkey and can't come to the NBA for two years. That means the Sixers won't have Embiid or Saric next season. Looks like it will be tank city in Philly again next season.

strengths: High level explosiveness and athleticism • Excellent shooting skills with NBA range • Strong transition player and dunker
weaknesses: Needs to improve basketball IQ • Inconsistent and struggles with contact • Underwhelming defensive player
awards: Pac-12 All-Freshman Team ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2013), AP Washington Player of the Year (2013), Washington Mr. Basketball (2013)
post draft awards: 2× NBA All-Star ( 2021, 2022 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2015 ), 2× NBA Slam Dunk Contest champion ( 2015, 2016 )
analysis: LaVine is a swing for the fences. He's one of the best athletes in the draft, he shoots the ball from deep and he has great size for his position. However, he's skinny, his shot selection is poor and he's just not quite ready. If he develops, he could be one of the five best players in the draft. Given where Minnesota is heading, this was an interesting pick.

strengths: Big time scorer with fantastic instincts • Excellent in transition and versatile shooter • Strong defensive effort and rebounding
weaknesses: Undefined position and lacks ideal size • Struggled with three-point shooting this season • Poor lateral quickness and overall athleticism
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2014 ), ACC Player of the Year (2014), First-team All-ACC (2014), ACC All-Freshmen Team (2013), No. 24 jersey honored by NC State Wolfpack, McDonald's All-American ( 2012 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2025 ), NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 )
analysis: The Suns needed help on the wing, and they got the second- or third-best wing scorer in the draft in Warren. Warren is not a great shooter, but he is a scoring machine. He just has a nose for the bucket. He was dominating players in workouts. We will see if his lack of a jumper and elite athleticism will hinder his career.

strengths: Explosive big with 3-point range • Strong leader and hard worker • Good free throw shooter
weaknesses: Poor shot blocking timing • Struggles creating for others • Reduced lung capacity concerns
awards: 2× Second-team All- Big Ten (2013, 2014), Fourth-team Parade All-American (2010)
post draft awards: Pro A champion ( 2019 ), French Cup winner (2019), Greek League champion ( 2018 ), Greek Basketball Cup winner (2019)
analysis: The Hawks love shooters, and Payne is the best shooting big man in the draft. He can really stretch the floor. He also has good athleticism, great strength and can play with his back to the basket. He's the sort of player who will play both the 4 and the 5 in the NBA. I like this pick.

strengths: Excellent balance and mobility for size • Effective in pick and roll situations • Solid free throw shooter
weaknesses: Foul prone with discipline issues • Struggles against bigger opponents • Maturity and behavior concerns
awards: Croatian League champion ( 2014 ), Croatian League Finals MVP (2014), All-Croatian League Second Team (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2015 )
analysis: Nurkic is huge. He carves out a lot of space in the paint. He has soft hands and great feet around the basket. In short, he's an old-school center. His lack of athleticism and some off-the-court issues created some interesting debates in draft war rooms. It will be interesting to see if he comes to the NBA right away.

strengths: Versatile and talented scorer • Excellent size and wingspan • Good rebounder and passer
weaknesses: Streaky jumper, takes bad shots • Needs to improve ball handling • Lacks quickness and driving ability
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2014), SEC All-Freshman Team (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 ), First-team Parade All-American (2013)
post draft awards: Israeli Basketball Premier League Top Scorer (2020)
analysis: The Celtics took one of the youngest players in the draft. Young is about upside. He has the potential to be an elite shooter and has great size for his position. He can play both the 2 and 3. There are concerns about whether he'll ever live up to the potential, but he's a good value pick here.

strengths: Extremely cerebral and unselfish • Excellent decision-maker and mature • Strong outside shooter at 43%
weaknesses: Lacks elite athleticism • Needs to improve one-on-one defense • Thin frame could be a disadvantage
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2014), ACC All-Freshmen team (2014), ACC All-Defensive team (2014), First-team Parade All-American (2013)
post draft awards: Turkish Cup winner (2019), Italian Cup winner ( 2024 ), LBA assists leader ( 2024 )
analysis: The Suns have been searching for a point guard. Ennis is a true point guard who sees the floor well and rarely makes mistakes. He also can shoot it a little and plays solid defense. He's not a great athlete and doesn't have much flash, but he's steady -- high praise for a freshman. I wonder what this means for Eric Bledsoe, who is a restricted free agent this summer.

strengths: Well-rounded, fundamentally sound player • Strong shooter from deep • Versatile defender across guard positions
weaknesses: Struggles with physical limitations • Inconsistent at breaking down defenses • Needs to improve shot selection
awards: First-team All- Big Ten (2014), Second-team All-Big Ten (2013), Big Ten All-Defensive Team (2014), Big Ten Freshman of the Year (2013), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2013), McDonald's All-American ( 2012 ), First-team Parade All-American (2012), Indiana Mr. Basketball (2012)
analysis: This is a great get for the Nuggets. I had Harris ranked as the 10th-best prospect in the draft. His lack of size scared away a lot of teams, but he's one of the only true two-way players in the draft. The Nuggets just got Arron Afflalo, so Harris might not get a ton of playing time this season, but with Afflalo likely to opt out of his deal next summer, Harris could be a long-term play for the Nuggets.

strengths: Exceptional physical attributes • Solid shooting form • Good defensive potential
weaknesses: Lacks experience and polish • Limited ball-handling skills • Needs to adapt to NBA competition
post draft awards: EuroCup champion ( 2025 ), All-EuroCup Second Team ( 2023 ), Bundesliga champion ( 2023 ), All-Bundesliga First Team ( 2023 ), BCL Americas champion ( 2022 ), BCL Americas MVP (2022), NBB MVP ( 2022 ), All-NBB First Team (2022), NBA G League champion ( 2017 )
analysis: This is Raptors general manager Masai Ujiri doing what he does. He's a gambler and not afraid to take huge risks. Caboclo has a 7-foot-7 wingspan, can shoot it and reminds some scouts of Giannis Antetokounmpo. He's far away from being able to play in the NBA, but credit Ujiri for swinging for the fences.

strengths: Quick and intelligent bigman • Strong finisher and passer • Good size and physicality
weaknesses: Limited high-level experience • Questionable work ethic and conditioning • Foul prone and emotionally inconsistent
awards: First-team Parade All-American (2012)
analysis: McGary might have gotten overrated after his magical run in the 2013 NCAA tournament as a freshman. Then a back injury tanked his sophomore season. This is a good spot for him as far as draft placement. However, the Thunder also took a center last year with Steven Adams.

strengths: Excellent scoring and competitiveness • Strong anticipation on defense • Effective mid-range shooter
weaknesses: Limited athletic ability • Poor lateral and foot speed • Inconsistent three-point shooter
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2014 )
post draft awards: All-IBL Indonesia First Team ( 2024 ), IBL All-Star ( 2024 ), IBL Three-Point Contest champion ( 2024 ), SPB champion (2022)
analysis: Adams is one of the best scorers in the draft, and, according to Kevin Pelton's projected WARP, he was one of the best players in the draft. John Hollinger, who helped pioneer those stats, still is in the Grizzlies' front office. He can score -- really score. But he's one of the most unathletic 2-guards ever.

strengths: Versatile scorer from all levels • Strong shooter with NBA range • Good size and playmaking ability
weaknesses: Needs to add upper body strength • Not assertive enough offensively • Inconsistent defensive effort
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2014), SEC All-Freshman Team (2012), Mississippi Mr. Basketball (2011)
analysis: This is turning into a great night for the Jazz. They were praying Exum would fall to them, then hoped Hood would drop to them at No. 23. They wanted a big shooter who could play two positions, and that's what they got in Hood. The Jazz were devastated when they fell out of the top three on lottery night. But this draft should make Jazz fans feel really good.

strengths: Excels in clutch situations • Improved playmaking and efficiency • Strong defender and rebounder
weaknesses: Limited athleticism and size • Tendency to over-dribble • Questionable shot selection
awards: 2× NCAA champion ( 2011, 2014 ), NCAA Final Four Most Outstanding Player (2014), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2014 ), Bob Cousy Award (2014), AAC Player of the Year ( 2014 ), First-team All- AAC (2014), First-team All-Big East (2013)
post draft awards: 2× LBA champion ( 2023, 2024 )
analysis: The Hornets will send this pick to the Heat for the No. 26 and No. 55 picks. We reported on Wednesday that the Heat were making an all-out effort to draft Napier but lacked the resources to get up too high in the draft. When Napier fell to No. 24, they were able to move up two spots, give up a second-rounder and get the guy LeBron James wanted them to get. Not sure what this means for Mario Chalmers or whether a rookie point guard is ready to run the Heat, but he has as much moxie as any guard in the draft.

strengths: Explosive rim‑runner • 7'4 wingspan shot‑blocker • Elite lob finisher
weaknesses: Raw offensive touch • Foul‑prone • Needs added strength
awards: Pro A Best Young Player ( 2014 ), Pro A Most Improved Player ( 2014 )
post draft awards: NBA rebounding leader ( 2021 ), NBA D-League All-Defensive First Team ( 2015 )
analysis: Capela is long and athletic. He bears a passing resemblance to a young Serge Ibaka. However, he is very raw. Incredibly raw. And the Rockets, who are trying to clear cap space, will keep him overseas for at least a season.

strengths: Effective scorer inside and out • Excellent free-throw shooter • Strong finisher in transition
weaknesses: Poor defensive awareness and effort • Struggles against quicker players • Low assist rate, offensive black hole
awards: NBA D-League All-Rookie Second Team (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2011 ), Third-team Parade All-American (2011)
analysis: Miami traded this pick to Charlotte. The Hornets were strongly considering Hairston for months. They really wanted a shooter who can stretch the floor and play right now. Had Hairston not gotten into trouble off the court, he would've been a lottery pick. If he can clean up his act, he has a chance to be a steal here. The Hornets got a lot of talent already with Vonleh and Hairston.

strengths: Knock‑down catch‑and‑shoot • Savvy pick‑and‑roll creator • Clutch shot‑maker
weaknesses: Limited first‑step burst • Average lateral quickness • Relies on step‑backs
awards: 2× EuroLeague Rising Star ( 2014, 2× ABA League champion ( 2011, 2013 ), All-ABA League Team ( 2014 ), 4× Serbian League champion ( 2011 – 2014 ), 2× Serbian Cup winner (2011, 2012 ), Serbian League Playoffs MVP (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2018 ), EuroLeague 2010–2020 All-Decade Team (2020), EuroLeague champion ( 2017 ), All-EuroLeague First Team (2017), 2015 ), 2× Turkish League champion ( 2016, 2017 ), Turkish League Finals MVP (2017), Turkish Cup winner ( 2016 ), Turkish Cup Final MVP (2016), Turkish Super Cup winner ( 2016 ), 3× Serbian Player of the Year (2017, 2019, 2023)
analysis: This is a draft-and-stash guy for the Suns. Bogdanovic is one of the best young scorers in Europe. He's probably ready to play in the NBA right now, but I doubt the Suns bring over three rookies in one season.

strengths: Deadly long-range shooter • High free throw percentage • Good playmaking improvement
weaknesses: Struggles creating offense • Limited defensive awareness • Physicality issues due to slight build
awards: 2× Second-team All-Pac-12 (2013, 2014), Pac-10 All-Freshman Team (2011)
analysis: Wilcox is a bit of a surprise. The Clippers selected Reggie Bullock, a similar player, last year in the draft. Clearly they need more shooters. Wilcox has deep range, and he's a good shooter. If he were younger (he's already 23 years old), he would've gone much higher in the draft.

strengths: Versatile defender, strong rebounder • Hard worker, improved over college • Efficient cutter, good shot blocker
weaknesses: Limited shooter and ball handler • Poor free throw shooter • Lacks offensive playmaking skills
awards: 2× Pac-12 All-Defensive Team ( 2013 , 2014 )
analysis: Huestis was a surprise here. We had him projected as a late-second-round pick. But I don't think he's a bad pick. He's a good athlete and a terrific defender, and he plays unselfishly. He was the guy who helped shut down Andrew Wiggins in the NCAA tournament.

strengths: Exceptional floor vision and height advantage • Versatile in multiple positions • Strong rebounder and defender with long arms
weaknesses: Lacks elite-level athleticism • Struggles to finish through contact • Inconsistent jump shot
place of birth: New York City , New York, U.S.
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, SN ( 2014 ), First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2014 ), Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2013 ), Pac-12 tournament MOP ( 2014 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2012 ), First-team Parade All-American (2012)
analysis: This was karma. The first Boris Diaw clone to come along -- since Diaw -- goes to the Spurs. Coach Gregg Popovich knows exactly how to play him. When Anderson has the ball in his hands, he can be special. Diaw is a free agent, so he might not be around to mentor Anderson. But I've got to believe the Spurs give him his best chance to succeed.

strengths: Combines size, speed, and strength effectively • Excellent passer and ball handler • Effective rebounder and intense player
weaknesses: Inconsistent shooting mechanics • Prone to turnovers under pressure • Lacks defensive fundamentals and focus
post draft awards: EuroCup champion ( 2021, 2023 ), French Cup winner ( 2018 )
analysis: The Bucks are going long on Inglis. He's got a huge wingspan, an NBA body and is a very good athlete. His body and athleticism are ahead of his skill set, but he's got a ton of promise. He reminds the Bucks of a poor man's Kawhi Leonard. He'll come over and play right away for Milwaukee.

strengths: Exceptional athletic ability and rebounding • Effective in transition and defensive versatility • Respectable three-point shooting with set feet
weaknesses: Struggles with pull-up shooting and decision-making • Needs to improve ball handling and finishing skills • Must get stronger to defend bigger players
awards: ACC Defensive Player of the Year (2014), First-team All-ACC (2014)
post draft awards: IBL champion ( 2024 ), All-IBL Indonesia Second Team ( 2024 ), IBL All-Star ( 2024 )
analysis: McDaniels is a terrific athlete. Guess what the Sixers like? Great athletes. He can block shots and defend; he just can't shoot.

strengths: Elite three-point shooter • Effective without the ball • Solid passer and defender
weaknesses: Struggles against fast opponents • Can be neutralized by good defense • Poor at free throws and finishing
awards: First-team All-ACC (2013), Second-team All-ACC – Coaches (2014), Third-team All-ACC – Media (2014), ACC tournament MVP ( 2014 ), Washington Mr. Basketball (2010)
post draft awards: NBA Three-Point Contest champion ( 2019 )
analysis: Harris is a terrific shooter and is super tough, but he's a bit of a liability on the defensive end. He can play right now, however.

strengths: Versatile scorer and athletic forward • Effective off catch and shoot • Solid perimeter defender potential
weaknesses: Needs improved ball handling • Limited post defense against bigger players • Prone to lapses in defensive focus
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2014 ), 2× First-team All- MVC (2013, 2014), MVC Newcomer of the Year (2013), 2× NJCAA Division III Player of the Year (2011, 2012), 2× NJCAA All-American (2011, 2012)
analysis: Early slid because teams were concerned about his ability to play the 3. He struggled with his ballhandling in drills, but he can shoot and is a good athlete. This is good value for the Knicks here.

strengths: Powerful post scorer • Tenacious rebounder • High basketball IQ
weaknesses: Below-average lateral quickness • Limited offensive game • Struggles against taller players
awards: First-team All- SEC (2014), Second-team All-SEC (2013), SEC All-Freshman team (2012)
post draft awards: NBA D-League champion (2016), NBA D-League Finals MVP (2016), NBA D-League MVP (2016), All-NBA D-League First Team (2016), NBA D-League All-Star (2016)
analysis: The Jazz will send Stokes to the Grizzlies for a 2016 first-round pick. Stokes was another guy who ranked very high in analytics models. Clearly, the Grizzlies are still watching the numbers. He can really rebound, and his numbers were almost identical to Julius Randle's last season.

strengths: Strong NBA frame • Reliable mid‑range jumper • Physical offensive rebounder
weaknesses: Below‑rim finisher • Defensive awareness lapses • Conditioning questions
awards: 2× First-team All- SEC (2013, 2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2011 ), Fourth-team Parade All-American (2011)
post draft awards: Israeli League champion ( 2019 ), Serbian Cup winner ( 2021 ), NBA D-League All-Star (2017)
analysis: O'Bryant is a crafty scorer in the low post. He isn't a great athlete and might not be a great fit in Milwaukee because they plan on playing Jabari Parker at the 4. But he was getting a lot of looks late in the first round.

strengths: Long, fast, and versatile small forward • Excellent three-point shooter at 42% • Strong defender with 7' wingspan
weaknesses: Struggles with defensive technique • Inconsistent offensive performance • Limited playmaking ability, low assists
awards: NCAA champion ( 2014 )
post draft awards: NZNBL blocks leader ( 2021 )
analysis: Daniels really helped his stock in the tournament. He has great size and can shoot it, but he's not a great athlete. He was very inconsistent at UConn.

strengths: Dual offensive threat with strong scoring • Excellent free-throw and three-point shooter • Fast and effective in transition
weaknesses: Lacks assertiveness and consistency • Still recovering from a torn ACL • Struggles against physical strength and screens
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2013 )
analysis: This is a great pick for the Pistons. Dinwiddie would've been a first-round pick if he hadn't blown out his ACL. He's a big guard who can play both the 1 and the 2. He's not a great athlete, but he's very crafty and has a high basketball IQ. The Pistons could use a player like this in their backcourt. He's the anti-Brandon Jennings.

strengths: Exceptional size and athleticism • Versatile defensive potential • Effective without ball focus
weaknesses: Needs to develop perimeter skills • Struggles with positional identity • Ineffective as a shooter
analysis: Like we mentioned earlier, the Sixers love athletes, and here's another. Grant isn't much of an offensive player, but he's crazy long, defends multiple positions and finishes above the rim. The Sixers are just loading up on athletes.

strengths: Tremendously athletic with solid frame • Strong finisher at the basket • Solid midrange shooter
weaknesses: Inconsistent three-point shooter • Can be too passive offensively • Needs to improve defensive rebounding
awards: NBA champion ( 2005 ), 2× NBA All-Star ( 2000, 2001 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 1995 ), National college player of the year ( 1994 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 1994 ), Consensus second-team All-American ( 1993 ), NCAA scoring champion (1994), Big Ten Player of the Year (1994), 2× First-team All- Big Ten (1993, 1994), Big Ten Athlete of the Year (1994), First-team Parade All-American (1991), McDonald's All-American ( 1991 ), Indiana Mr. Basketball (1991)
analysis: This will feel like a tough fall for Robinson III. Teams were looking at him in the late teens and 20s. He has the requisite athleticism, but teams worry about his transition to the 3 and his tendency to cruise and float -- even in workouts. He's a good kid, and if he gets it together, this is a nice pick for Minnesota.

strengths: High basketball IQ • Strong work ethic • Excellent shooting ability
weaknesses: Lacks speed and leaping ability • Struggles with post play • Defensive weaknesses due to slow foot speed
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2023 ), NBA Finals MVP ( 2023 ), 3× NBA Most Valuable Player ( 2021, 2022, 2024 ), 7× NBA All-Star ( 2019 – 2025 ), 4× All-NBA First Team ( 2019, 2021, 2022, 2024 ), 2× All-NBA Second Team ( 2020, 2023 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2016 ), Hickok Belt (2023), 4× Serbian Player of the Year (2018, 2021, 2022, 2024), ABA League MVP ( 2015 ), ABA League Top Prospect ( 2015 )
analysis: Jokic impressed teams at the Nike Hoop Summit. He's not a great athlete, but he's very skilled and can score in a variety of ways. Some think he could be a Nikola Vucevic type in the NBA. It's a nice stash pick for the Nuggets.

strengths: Strong fundamentals and smart player • Powerful leaper and finishes well • Good on-ball defender with active hands
weaknesses: Short for a shooting guard • Lacks standout offensive skill • Struggles with creative ball-handling
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2014 ), Pac-12 Player of the Year ( 2014 ), First-team All-Pac-12 (2014), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2014), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2012)
post draft awards: NBA G League champion (2018), NBA G League Finals MVP (2018)
analysis: Johnson is one of the best athletes in the draft. He's just undersized for his position. But he plays hard, gets after it defensively and is a solid pick for the Rockets here.

strengths: Tremendous size and mobility • Effective in pick and roll situations • Solid free throw shooter
weaknesses: Lacks explosiveness and elite athleticism • Limited offensive post moves • Prone to committing unnecessary fouls
awards: All-Liga ACB Young Players Team ( 2014 )
post draft awards: 2× EuroLeague champion ( 2018, 2023 ), EuroLeague Final Four MVP ( 2023 ), 3× All-EuroLeague First Team ( 2021 – 2023 ), 3× All-EuroLeague Second Team ( 2019, 2024, 2025 ), 3× EuroLeague Best Defender ( 2019, 2021, 2023 ), 6× EuroLeague blocks leader (2019–2024), EuroLeague rebounding leader ( 2021 ), All-EuroCup First Team ( 2015 ), 4× Liga ACB champion ( 2018, 2019, 2022, 2024 ), 6× Spanish Supercup winner (2018–2023), Liga ACB Finals MVP ( 2022 ), 3× All-Liga ACB  First Team ( 2019, 2021, 2023 ), 2× All-Liga ACB Second Team  ( 2020, 2022 ), 7× Liga ACB Defensive Player of the Year ( 2018 – 2024 ), 7× Liga ACB blocks leader (2015, 2018, 2019, 2021–2024), Liga ACB rebounding leader (2024), Spanish Supercup MVP (2022), NBA D-League Defensive Player of the Year ( 2017 ), All-NBA D-League First Team ( 2017 ), NBA D-League All-Defensive Team ( 2017 ), NBA D-League All-Star (2017)
analysis: The Hawks drafted a monster. Did you see this guy's hands? The Hawks love guys like this. He's not some stiff. He's made an impact in Spain. He'll stay overseas and continue to develop and could actually make it to the NBA someday.

strengths: Incredible leaping ability and athleticism • Strong improvement in shooting • Versatile defensive capabilities
weaknesses: Limited ball-handling skills • Inconsistent jump shooting • Struggles against physical guards
awards: 2× Second-team All- Big 12 (2013, 2014), Louisiana Mr. Basketball (2010)
post draft awards: Italian Cup winner ( 2024 )
analysis: Brown is an amazing athlete and can really defend, but he's a bit of a tweener, which is why he slid. The Nets wanted a four-year senior who can defend. Some teams thought he might be able to play some point.

strengths: Highly mobile and coordinated big man • Reliable playmaker and excellent distributor • Versatile defender with lateral agility
weaknesses: Inconsistent progress and performance • Predictable post moves • Decline in shooting and rebounding stats
awards: 2× First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2013, 2014 ), Pac-12 Most Improved Player (2013), NIT champion ( 2012 ), Pac-10 All-Freshman team (2011)
analysis: Powell was once touted as a potential lottery pick. He reminds me a bit of someone like Josh McRoberts. He's versatile and skilled but lacks toughness. I feel like the Hornets have a lot of guys like him at this position.

strengths: Quick guard with strong handle and vision • Can score from all three levels • Good lateral quickness and defensive potential
weaknesses: Struggled with outside shooting • High turnover rate, poor assist-to-turnover ratio • Needs to improve off-hand and finishing ability
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2014), First-team All- C-USA (2012), C-USA All-Freshman Team (2011)
post draft awards: NBA Sixth Man of the Year ( 2021 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2015 )
analysis: The Wizards traded this pick to the Lakers. Clarkson was doing really well in workouts, and I'm surprised he fell this far. He's athletic, can play some point and his shooting touch looked much better in workouts. This is a nice pick for the Lakers, who were looking for a young point guard and got a steal this late in the draft.

strengths: Elite speed and agility • Strong finisher despite size • High free throw percentage
weaknesses: Limited shooting ability • Questionable playmaking skills • Defensive liability due to size
place of birth: New York City, New York , U.S.
awards: NCAA champion ( 2013 )*, Consensus First-team All-American ( 2014 ), Third-team All-American - SN, NABC ( 2013 ), First-team All- AAC (2014), First-team All-Big East (2013), Frances Pomeroy Naismith Award (2014), AAC tournament MVP ( 2014 ), No. 2 retired by Louisville Cardinals
post draft awards: NBL (China) Player of the Year (2017), NBL (China) Guard of the Year (2017), NBL (China) Import of the Year (2017), 2× NBL (China) scoring champion (2017, 2019)
analysis: The Sixers traded this pick to the Pelicans for the rights to Pierre Jackson. This is interesting. Jackson was the Russ Smith of last year's draft: tiny, super quick, athletic and more of a scoring guard than a true point. Jackson was very good in the D-League, so this might be a good deal for the Sixers. As for Smith, if he can learn to play under control and play some point, he could be valuable for the Pelicans someday.

strengths: High basketball IQ and decision-making • Strong, versatile defensive skills • Effective passer with good court vision
weaknesses: Limited athleticism and quickness • Struggles to create own shot • Inconsistent three-point shooting
awards: AP honorable mention All-American ( 2014 ), Second-team All-ACC (2014), CBI MVP ( 2012 )
post draft awards: NBL1 North champion ( 2022 ), NBL1 National Finals All-Star Five ( 2022 ), 2× All-NBL First Team ( 2019, 2020 ), NBL (China) scoring champion (2018), Italian Cup champion (2018)
analysis: The Bucks will send this pick to the Hawks for a future second-round pick. Patterson is a blue-collar forward who doesn't do any one thing great but does everything well.

strengths: Strong mid-range shooting and physical play • High motor and excellent rebounder • Effective in the post and improved shot blocker
weaknesses: Older age limits potential • Struggles with athleticism and fast breaks • Limited experience and court awareness
awards: First-team All- Mountain West (2014), Mountain West tournament MVP ( 2014 )
analysis: Bairstow is a tough, old-school power forward who does most of his damage in the paint. He isn't a great athlete, but he knows how to play. I expect the Bulls will stash him overseas -- maybe back to Australia.

strengths: Excels as a stretch 4 or 5 • Averages over 3 blocks per game • Impressive at Adidas Nations
weaknesses: Struggles with physical strength • Poor rebounding for his height • Inconsistent against top competition
awards: 2× First-team All- Horizon League (2012, 2014), Horizon League Defensive Player of the Year (2014)

analysis: The Knicks worked out Antetokounmpo before the draft and fell in love. He's a very good athlete and scrappy. However, don't mistake him for his brother Giannis. He isn't nearly as skilled or as big, but he was good enough in the D-League to warrant this selection. Not sure if the Knicks will just send him back to the D-League, however.

analysis: Towns is the best and most complete player in the draft. He has great size. He is a good athlete. He is very skilled offensively. He can score inside and outside. He's an excellent defender and rim protector. And he's a great kid. He and Andrew Wiggins will be an awesome combo. Awesome enough to win titles someday if they stay together.

weaknesses: Below average run/jump athlete • Inconsistent intensity on defense • Needs to improve finishing in transition

analysis: Among players eligible for the NBA draft, D’Angelo Russell sat atop Kevin Pelton’s WARP projections, had the highest offensive rating of any freshman last season, and was the top projected guard in ESPN’s Statistical Plus/Minus projections. Although SPM saw him as a high-risk, high-reward prospect, it projected he had the best chance of any player in the 2015 draft class to develop into a superstar.

strengths: Elite low-post scoring ability • Exceptional size and wingspan • High field goal percentage
weaknesses: Struggles with free throw shooting • Limited defensive mobility • High turnover rate
awards: NCAA champion ( 2015 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2015 ), USBWA National Freshman of the Year (2015), Pete Newell Big Man Award (2015), ACC Player of the Year (2015), First-team All-ACC (2015), ACC Rookie of the Year (2015), Morgan Wootten National Player of the Year (2014), USA Today High School Player of the Year (2014), McDonald's All-American Game co-MVP ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014), Illinois Mr. Basketball (2014), FIBA Under-17 World Cup MVP (2012)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2016 ), NBA G League Up Next Game ( 2025 ), BSN All-Star (2024)
analysis: Okafor doesn't fit. That's clear. But it doesn't mean it's a bad choice, especially with Joel Embiid ailing and the Sixers still not totally sold on Nerlens Noel. I think Kristaps Porzingis and Emmanuel Mudiay were better picks and better fits in Philadelphia. Sam Hinkie thinks the draft is about assets, and I think he felt he grabbed the best asset left on the board. Hinkie will figure out how to untangle the triple towers of Embiid, Noel and Okafor later. My guess is he'll keep Okafor and figure out what to do with the other guys.

strengths: Perfect height with excellent coordination • Solid shooter with diverse scoring ability • Effective weak side and P&R defender
weaknesses: Needs to bulk up significantly • Lacks an effective inside game • Struggles against traditional centers
awards: EuroCup Rising Star ( 2015 ), 2× ACB All-Young Players Team ( 2014, 2015 )
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2024 ), NBA All-Star ( 2018 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2016 ), EuroBasket blocks leader ( 2017 )
analysis: I'm a huge (no surprise) Porzingis fan. The question, and it's a big one, is whether the Knicks actually keep him or whether they send him on to another team. He's a great fit in the triangle offense and being patient with him will be worth it. Porzingis has the most star potential of anyone in the draft. But I don't think the Knicks have patience. It will be interesting to see how this plays out. For his development, Porzingis' camp was hoping he'd go to Orlando.

strengths: Excellent athleticism and scoring ability • Versatile player with good size and vision • Strong rebounder and defensive anticipation
weaknesses: Can be overly critical of teammates • Needs to gain muscle and maturity • Inconsistent intensity in one-on-one defense
awards: 2× Liga ACB champion ( 2012, 2014 ), 2x Spanish Cup winner (2013, 3× Spanish Supercup winner ( 2015, 4× Catalan League champion (2012-2015), LEB Oro Rising Star ( 2013 ), FIBA Europe Under-16 Championship MVP ( 2011 )

analysis: The Magic were hoping Porzingis would fall to them at No. 5. But they also were very high on Hezonja and are happy with this selection. They desperately need shooting and they need offense and Hezonja immediately becomes the best scorer on the team (especially if Tobias Harris leaves). Hezonja can be wild and unpredictable, but I think he'll be great in Orlando.

strengths: Elite defensive abilities and rim protection • Strong finisher around the rim • High potential to guard NBA wings
weaknesses: Limited offensive game • Inconsistent focus and intensity • Underdeveloped basketball instincts

analysis: Cauley-Stein is a boom or bust prospect. He could be not only the best defender in the draft, but also the best defender in the NBA. He's the most athletic 7-footer I've ever scouted and has elite defensive instincts. The problem lies on the other end. His offensive skills are rudimentary. You're playing four-on-five on offense and six-on-five on defense with him. He fits great next to DeMarcus Cousins — if Cousins stays in Sacramento. The Kings desperately need a rim protector. They also added another mercurial personality to the mix. Very interesting.

strengths: Rare combination of size and skills • Natural leader with killer instinct • Strong finisher and creative passer
weaknesses: Inconsistent shooter with poor percentages • Prone to turnovers and bad shots • Defensive lapses and off-ball issues
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2016 ), BSN scoring champion (2024)
analysis: This is a home run for the Nuggets. They were searching for a second pick in the first round to grab a point guard and Mudiay falls into their lap at No. 7. To get Mudiay at this point is a steal. Mudiay has as much upside as any player in the draft. The team is trying to move point guard Ty Lawson and will continue to work on that over the summer. Mudiay is the future and immediately has the most talent of anyone on the team.

strengths: Versatile two-way wing with upside • Strong physical attributes and athleticism • Effective scorer and rebounder
weaknesses: Inconsistent finishing against length • Struggles with decision-making in transition • Needs more consistent defensive effort
awards: Julius Erving Award (2015), Third-team All-American – NABC ( 2015 ), First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2015 ), Pac-12 Freshman of the Year (2015), Pac-12 All-Freshman team (2015), First team Parade All-American (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), California Mr. Basketball (2014), FIBA Americas U18 Championship MVP ( 2014 )
post draft awards: Turkish Super Cup winner ( 2024 )
analysis: The Pistons needed a wing. They just grabbed the wrong one. Yes, Stanley Johnson is a solid choice here: He's big, physical and he can score. But with Justise Winslow on the board? I think that's a big mistake. I see Winslow as the better prospect on both ends of the floor and in the locker room. The Pistons aren't going to like my draft grades.

strengths: Versatile offensive skills at 7 feet • High basketball IQ and court vision • Effective shooter with consistent range
weaknesses: Struggles with athleticism and quickness • Limited effectiveness in various offensive systems • Slow release and needs strength for NBA physicality
awards: National college player of the year ( 2015 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2015 ), Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Award (2015), Big Ten Player of the Year (2015), 2× First-team All- Big Ten ( 2014, 2015 ), Big Ten tournament MOP ( 2015 ), No. 44 jersey retired by Wisconsin Badgers
analysis: Michael Jordan fell in love with Kaminsky. (He does that. See: Kwame Brown, Adam Morrison, D.J. Augustin, Cody Zeller, Noah Vonleh … you get the picture.) It doesn't mean he's a bad pick. Kaminsky does fit in a certain way for the Hornets. They had a lot of success with Josh McRoberts and desperately needed shooting. Kaminsky can fill that role and really help with the shooting woes.

strengths: Elite speed and athleticism • Versatile scoring ability • Strong on-ball defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent performance history • Loses focus during games • Needs to improve free throw shooting
awards: NCAA champion ( 2015 ), ACC All-Freshman team (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014), Texas Mr. Basketball (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2016 )
analysis: Winslow and the Heat are a perfect fit. Pat Riley loves strong, athletic players who get it done on both ends. Winslow is a gritty driver and a great defender. As he continues to improve his shot and offensive game, he has star potential. Sometimes it pays to slip a bit in the draft. Miami is the perfect situation for Winslow.

strengths: Elite size and shooting ability • Excellent shot-blocking instincts • High basketball IQ and adaptability
weaknesses: Lacks athletic fluidity • Struggles against physical NCAA players • Inconsistent performance in major games
awards: Third-team All- Big 12 ( 2015 ), Big 12 Freshman of the Year (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2016 ), 2× NBA blocks leader ( 2019, 2021 )
analysis: With David West opting out and Roy Hibbert being shopped, the Pacers needed a big. I'm surprised they passed on Murray State's Cameron Payne, but I can't fault them for taking Turner. While he's not NBA ready, he has elite size, is a solid athlete, protects the rim and he can stretch the floor. He's a great modern NBA big. Fans will just have to be patient.

strengths: Excellent size and offensive versatility • High basketball IQ and court awareness • Effective rebounder and screen setter
weaknesses: Lacks elite athleticism and explosiveness • Inconsistent three-point shooting • Struggles with on-ball and perimeter defense
awards: SEC All-Freshman Team (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014), Indiana Mr. Basketball (2014)
analysis: Lyles is such a Jazz pick. Solid, not sexy. He's very skilled, has a high basketball IQ and should be an excellent backup for Derrick Favors. I don't think he showed everything he could do in Kentucky. There's upside there. I just don't think he's a star. He's more like a young Carlos Boozer.

strengths: High basketball IQ and sharpshooting ability • Excellent in catch-and-shoot situations • Strong playmaking and unselfishness
weaknesses: Struggles against physical defense • Needs to improve defensive quickness • Inconsistent at driving and finishing
awards: LNB Pro B Finals MVP ( 2014 ), Third-team All-ACC (2013)
post draft awards: 3x BBL champion ( 2018, 2019, 2024 ), 2x German Cup winner (2018, 2024 ), Turkish Super League champion ( 2022 ), All-EuroCup First Team ( 2018 ), German All-Star ( 2018 ), All-German Bundesliga Second Team ( 2018 ), LNB Pro A MVP ( 2016 )
analysis: The Suns needed shooting and they ended up getting possibly the best shooter in the draft. He has deep range and a pure stroke. The question is whether he can do anything else. I'm not sure he'll be an elite defender, playmaker or penetrator. Given the Suns' current guards, having him serve as a sniper from 3 might be enough.

strengths: High basketball IQ and playmaking ability • Good height and shooting versatility • Quick and effective in transition
weaknesses: Needs to improve physical strength • Prone to turnovers and rushed decisions • Struggles with finishing through contact
awards: OVC Player of the Year (2015), Lute Olson Award (2015), 2× First-team All- OVC (2014, 2015), OVC Freshman of the Year (2014), No. 1 retired by Murray State Racers
analysis: Payne is a super-talented point guard who played a bit under the radar at Murray State. The Thunder needed a backup for Russell Westbrook. Not only will Payne be able to handle that duty, but he is also great insurance in case Westbrook eventually bolts. Great value at No. 14.

strengths: Prototypical size and athleticism • Two-way potential • Positive response to coaching
weaknesses: Streaky outside shot • Raw offensive skillset • Needs added strength
awards: Big 12 All-Newcomer Team (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014)
analysis: The Hawks will trade Oubre's rights to the Wizards for the 19th pick and some second-round picks. I'm a big Oubre fan. He's got elite size for his position. He has the potential to be a terrific 3-and-D player in the league. But he's very young and his basketball IQ is low. If he puts in the work — a big if — he could be one of the best 8-9 players in this draft.

strengths: High volume scorer with good handle • Excellent three-point shooter • Strong assist to turnover ratio
weaknesses: Needs to improve shot selection • Struggles against taller defenders • Underperformed in NCAA tournament
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2015), AAC All-Rookie Team (2014)
analysis: Rozier's best comp might be a young Marcus Smart. He's built like a tank, is super tough, is a tenacious defender and is very quick. However, his jump shot needs work and he's not a pure point guard. The Celtics needed depth here, but did they simply get a smaller version of what they already have?

strengths: Young with strong body and good size • High scoring potential and floor spacing • Improving shooter with solid pick-and-roll use
weaknesses: Inconsistent shot selection and finishing • Needs improvement in on-ball defense • Struggles against tough competition and injuries
awards: MWC Freshman of the Year (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 )
post draft awards: Ukrainian League champion (2021), Ukrainian Basketball SuperLeague Finals MVP (2021)
analysis: Vaughn's stock rose after terrific workouts in Santa Barbara and again in Milwaukee on Monday. He's one of the best scorers in the draft. He can shoot and get to the basket. The Bucks needed a shooter who could create his own offense. He's young and he's not ready, but the Bucks can wait. If he develops—this pick is a steal.

strengths: NBA-ready body with versatile skills • Effective scorer inside and outside • Strong rebounder and defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent jump shooter • Struggles with creating off the dribble • Lacks elite athleticism and length
awards: 2× Second-team All- Big Ten ( 2014, 2015 ), Big Ten All-Freshman team ( 2013 ), First-team Parade All-American (2012), Wisconsin Mr. Basketball (2012)
post draft awards: BBL Champion ( 2024 ), BBL Final MVP ( 2024 ), BBL Champion ( 2023 ), BBL MVP ( 2023 ), BBL Team of the Year ( 2023 ), BBL Cup winner (2023), BBL Cup Final MVP (2023), All-EuroCup Second Team ( 2023 ), FIBA Europe Cup Champion ( 2022 )
analysis: I'm a big Dekker fan. He's got great size for his position. He's a very good athlete. He's tough, but he's a streaky shooter. However, in the right offense, Dekker will thrive. If the Rockets hold on to him, I think this is a nice fit for them.

strengths: Explosive athleticism and size • Elite finishing ability at the rim • Strong ball handling and passing skills
weaknesses: Questionable long-range shooting consistency • Limited improvement potential due to age • Unclear positional fit as combo guard
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2015 ), First-team All-ACC (2015), Second-team All-Big East (2013), ACC tournament MVP ( 2015 )
post draft awards: EuroLeague champion ( 2024 ), EuroCup MVP ( 2023 ), All-EuroCup First Team ( 2023 ), Greek League champion ( 2024 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2025 ), Lega Serie A champion ( 2022 ), Italian Cup winner (2022), All-Turkish Super League First Team (2023), Greek League Best Defender (2024)
analysis: This gets complicated. The Hawks traded for this pick and then traded it to the Knicks for Tim Hardaway Jr. This is a really nice pickup for the Knicks. Grant is a good athlete, can defend multiple positions, and can play the 1 and 2. He is NBA-ready and super competitive. I love the Knicks' draft.

strengths: Utilizes size advantage effectively • Strong finisher at the rim • Excellent game tempo control
weaknesses: Needs to improve body strength • Streaky outside shooter • Requires better on-ball defense
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2015 ), Bob Cousy Award (2015), 2× First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2014, 2015 ), 2× Pac-12 All-Defensive team (2014, 2015)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2024 )
analysis: With Greivis Vasquez heading to Milwaukee, the Raptors really needed a backup point guard, and I think Wright is a good choice. He's not sexy—he's not a great athlete—but he's got great size for his position, sees the floor well, and has a great feel for the game.

strengths: High basketball IQ and versatility • Elite athleticism and strong physical build • Improved three-point shooting ability
weaknesses: Needs to develop ball-handling skills • Inconsistent shooting and finishing • Lacks advanced offensive moves
awards: Third-team All-American – NABC ( 2015 ), Second-team All-ACC (2015), ACC Sixth Man of the Year (2014)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League First Team ( 2022 ), 2× All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2020, 2023 )
analysis: If Anderson shoots anywhere near the 45% he hit from 3 during his junior season at Virginia, he's a steal at No. 21. The Mavs drafted him hoping he'd shoot the lights out. He's a power wing and a good defender. Time will tell who he becomes.

strengths: Great size and versatile defender • Effective mid-range and expanding range • Strong finisher and active rebounder
weaknesses: Lacks post moves and footwork • Not a great post defender • Ceiling limited by athleticism
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2015 ), SEC Player of the Year (2015), First-team All- SEC (2015), Second-team All-SEC (2014), SEC All-Freshman team (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 ), First-team Parade All-American (2013), Arkansas Mr. Basketball (2013)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2021 ), NBA Cup champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Portis is one of the safest picks in the draft. He does just about everything well—shooting, posting up, rebounding and shot-blocking. He plays with one of the best motors in the draft. He won't be a star, but he'll be super productive. Love this pick for the Bulls.

strengths: NBA-ready body with strong athleticism • Elite defender across multiple positions • Effective in transition and as a playmaker
weaknesses: Inconsistent and limited offensive game • Poor outside and free-throw shooting • Needs to improve ball handling and control
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2015 ), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2015), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2014), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
post draft awards: 3× PBA champion ( 2023 Governors', 2024 Governors', 2024–25 Commissioner's ), 3× PBA Best Import of the Conference ( 2023 Governors', 2024 Governors', 2024–25 Commissioner's )
analysis: Hollis-Jefferson is my sleeper. An elite wing defender who can guard up to four positions, has a terrific motor and playmaking ability. He can't shoot—that's an issue—but he does everything else at a high level. He’s got a little Andre Iguodala in him. Great fit for the Blazers.

strengths: Excellent court sense and leadership • Adaptable and plays under control • Thrives in pick-and-roll situations
weaknesses: Lacks quickness and athleticism • Struggles with perimeter defense • Needs to improve shooting efficiency
awards: NCAA champion ( 2015 ), NCAA Final Four Most Outstanding Player ( 2015 ), AP honorable mention All-American ( 2015 ), Third-team All-ACC (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), Minnesota Mr. Basketball (2014)
analysis: The Cavs flipped this pick to Minnesota for Nos. 31 and 36. Jones is the best pure point guard in the draft, a winner who sees the floor as well as anyone in the class. He lacks size and athleticism, but backing up Ricky Rubio? That's perfect.

strengths: Ideal height and strong frame for NBA • Improved statistically each college season • Effective rebounder and good ball handler
weaknesses: Inconsistent shooter, struggles from distance • Prone to foul trouble, limits minutes • Defensive intensity and focus lacking
awards: First-team All- SEC (2015), SEC All-Freshman team (2014), McDonald's All-American (2013), First-team Parade All-American (2013), Louisiana Mr. Basketball (2013)
post draft awards: Israeli League champion ( 2023 ), Israeli League Cup winner ( 2022 ), NBL champion ( 2022 )
analysis: Martin was a top-10 high-school prospect who might still turn into a stud. Great athlete with an NBA body, he rebounds and runs the floor, but he's a tweener. He needs to develop a go-to offensive game—if his jumper comes along, the Grizzlies will be pleased.

strengths: Elite rebounder and rim protector • Strong post presence • Soft hands finishing
weaknesses: Lacks offensive polish • Limited shooting range • Needs mobility improvement
awards: ABA League champion ( 2013 ), 2× Serbian League champion ( 2013, 2014 ), All-Serbian League Second Team ( 2015 )
post draft awards: 2× EuroLeague rebounding leader ( 2020, 2021 ), VTB United League champion ( 2021 ), VTB United League Supercup winner (2021), VTB United League MVP ( 2023 ), 2× All-VTB United League First Team ( 2022, 2023 ), 2× VTB United League rebounding leader ( 2022, 2023 ), Greek League champion ( 2016 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2024 ), 2× Greek Super Cup winner ( 2023, 2024), 2× All-Greek League First Team ( 2018, 2019 ), 2× All-Greek League Second Team ( 2017, 2024), Greek League Most Improved Player ( 2017 )
analysis: A classic Spurs draft-and-stash. They're freeing up cap space, so Milutinov’s pick hold needed to go. He's solid, big, moves well, has soft touch. With development overseas, he could make the league in a few years.

strengths: Excellent length and athleticism • Strong defensive presence • High character and toughness
weaknesses: Limited offensive post skills • Inconsistent shooting mechanics • Struggles against athletic defenders
awards: 2× First-team All- MWC (2014, 2015), MWC Defensive Player of the Year (2015), 2× MWC All-Defensive Team (2014, 2015)
analysis: Nance is a versatile forward—good athlete, high basketball IQ, can face the basket or play in the post. What you see now is what you're going to get, so a lights-out shooter like R.J. Hunter might have been higher upside here.

strengths: Sharp catch-and-shoot shooter • Deep three-point range • Quick off-ball mover
weaknesses: Limited athleticism • Questionable defense • Needs off-the-dribble creation
awards: 2× Sun Belt Male Athlete of the Year (2014, 2015), 2× Sun Belt Player of the Year (2014, 2015), 2× First-team All-Sun Belt (2014, 2015), CAA Rookie of the Year (2013), First-team All-CAA (2013)
analysis: Danny Ainge loves shooters—and Hunter is one of the best. He needs touch-ups as a playmaker, but Brad Stevens is the perfect coach to get the best from him. I love this pick for the Celtics.

strengths: Great size and athleticism • Effective in transition and rebounding • Developing outside shooting threat
weaknesses: Needs to improve post play • Fundamentals as a rebounder lacking • Inconsistent awareness and focus
post draft awards: PBA champion ( 2019 Commissioner's ), NBA D-League All-Star (2017), P. League+ Comeback Player of the Year ( 2024 )
analysis: McCullough had a promise from the Nets months ago—he’d be 10–15 spots higher without that torn ACL. He probably sits this season, but he has a huge wingspan, good athleticism and can stretch the floor. Nets are swinging for upside.

strengths: Great rebounding instincts and aggressiveness • High shooting release with range potential • Unselfish with good vision
weaknesses: Needs to add upper body strength • Slow, methodical shooting release • Struggles guarding quick perimeter players
awards: Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2015 ), Pac-12 All-Freshman team (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014), Wisconsin Mr. Basketball (2014)
analysis: I love this pick. Looney was a top-5 prospect once—an unfortunate hip injury and position questions hurt his stock. There's serious talent here: great rebounder, skilled passer. If he gets healthy, the Warriors landed a steal at No. 30.

strengths: Versatile with solid size and athleticism • Excellent spot up shooter and rebounder • High basketball IQ and court vision
weaknesses: Struggles in ISO and with physical contact • Needs quicker, more fluid shooting mechanics • Limited by ankle injury and defensive quickness
awards: Turkish Cup winner ( 2015 ), Turkish Supercup winner (2015), FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship MVP ( 2014 ), Albert Schweitzer Tournament Most Talented Player (2012)
post draft awards: Greek Cup winner ( 2025 ), 3× BSL All-Star (2015–2017)
analysis: The Cavs acquired this pick in the Tyus Jones trade. Osman was the best international prospect after Porzingis and Hezonja. He’s a big play-maker at point forward—great feel and motor, even if his athleticism and shooting are work in progress.

strengths: Dominant rebounder and rim presence • Quick leaper with potential to add muscle • Improved mid-range shooting and basketball IQ
weaknesses: Below ideal height for NBA power forward • Limited offensive game at NBA level • Poor free throw shooter
awards: NCAA champion ( 2013 )*, Karl Malone Award (2015), First-team All- AAC (2014), Second-team All-ACC (2015), AAC Most Improved Player (2014)
post draft awards: NBA Sixth Man of the Year ( 2020 ), All-NBL Second Team ( 2025 )
analysis: Harrell was the highest-ranked Top-100 player to slip to Round 2. A beast of an athlete with great energy and toughness—just lacks height and a consistent motor. At this point, he can carve out a rotation role for the Rockets.

strengths: Elite shot blocker with great timing • Improved offensive skills and rebounding • High basketball IQ and motor
weaknesses: Lacks ideal height and strength for PF • Struggles with post defense and turnovers • Inconsistent jump shot mechanics
awards: NCAA blocks leader (2015), First-team All- SEC (2015), Second-team All SEC (2014), 2× SEC All-Defensive Team (2014, 2015), SEC All-Freshman Team (2014)
post draft awards: 2x Italian Supercup winner ( 2022, 2023 ), VTB United League champion (2022), VTB United League Supercup winner (2022), VTB United League Playoffs MVP (2022), VTB United League Defensive Player of the Year (2022), 3× VTB United League All-Star (2019, 2021, 2022), 3× All-VTB United League First Team ( 2019, 2021, 2022), VTB United League Hall of Fame (2023), Spanish Super Cup champion (2019), Spanish Cup champion (2020), NBA D-League All-Star (2016)
analysis: Mickey is an excellent shot-blocker but undersized. I never understood why he wasn't ranked higher—his rim protection alone should earn him minutes in the NBA.

strengths: Excellent perimeter shooter • Effective in transition play • Strong defensive rebounder
weaknesses: Struggles with finishing over length • Inconsistent off-the-dribble shooting • Defensive focus wanes over time
post draft awards: 2× All-EuroCup Second Team ( 2021, 2025 ), NBA D-League All-Star (2017)
analysis: Brown has great size for a wing and shot 44–45% from three at Stanford. The Lakers drastically improved their shooting in this draft by landing him in Round 2.

strengths: Fundamental big with face-up touch • High-post passer • Solid free-throw shooter
weaknesses: Below-average lateral mobility • Limited shot range • Struggles vs physical bigs
awards: 2× Liga ACB champion (2013, 2× ACB All-Young Players Team ( 2015
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2017 ), FIBA EuroBasket MVP ( 2022 ), 2016), 2× Catalan League champion (2023, 2024), 2016 ), Catalan League MVP (2024)
analysis: Traded from Philly to New York, Hernangomez teams up with Porzingis—another skilled, below-the-rim big who reminds me of Zaza Pachulia. Solid depth piece.

strengths: Exceptional wingspan and athletic ability • Dominant defender and rebounder • Effective in pick-and-roll situations
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA center position • Inconsistent offensive game • Needs improvement in outside shooting
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, SN ( 2015 ), First-team All-ACC (2015), ACC All-Defensive Team (2015), ACC Most Improved Player (2015), McDonald's All-American ( 2011 )
post draft awards: NBA D-League All-Star ( 2016 )
analysis: This pick goes to Cleveland. Christmas is a long backup big—rebounder and shot-blocker—who improved every year at Syracuse. Should contribute right away.

strengths: Strong athletic big man with prototype size • Premier NCAA shot blocker with great timing • Improved jump shot and free throw accuracy
weaknesses: Inconsistent jump shot, face-up game developing • Struggles with lateral quickness and quick players • Dominant with strong hand, weak with right hand
awards: First-team All- MAC (2015), Third-team All-MAC (2014), MAC Defensive Player of the Year (2015)
analysis: A classic Sixers pick: great shot-blocker, tons of effort, undersized but high upside as a rim protector.

strengths: Elite off-ball cutter • Knockdown three-point stroke • Competitive perimeter defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent shot creation • Below-average size for role • Limited ball-handling
awards: Second-team All-American – SN ( 2015 ), First-team All-Big East (2015), Big East Co-Most Improved Player (2014), Robert V. Geasey Trophy (2015)
post draft awards: Israeli League champion ( 2023 ), Israeli League Cup winner ( 2022 ), NBA G League champion (2018), VTB United League champion (2021), Gomelsky Cup champion (2020)
analysis: First player drafted outside the Top 50 of my board. A crafty shooter and scorer, but not an elite athlete and a bit undersized.

strengths: Athletic wing with scoring instincts • Solid defensive potential • Good versatility at 6'6"
weaknesses: Raw shooting mechanics • Needs strength for NBA • Inconsistent decision-making
analysis: An athletic slasher from Argentina—very quick but can’t really shoot. Many expected him to land in San Antonio.

strengths: Great size and athleticism • Improved ball handling and shooting • Effective in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Struggles with physical strength • Inconsistent finishing at the rim • High turnover rate
awards: First-team All- SEC (2015), 2× SEC All-Defensive Team (2014, 2015)
analysis: A versatile, athletic guard who can play 1 and 2. Not a great finisher, but a reliable spot-up shooter with good size.

strengths: Elite athleticism and combine performance • Sharpshooting with high three-point percentage • High basketball IQ and versatile role player
weaknesses: Lacks lateral quickness on defense • Limited iso scoring and ballhandling • Potential distraction from baseball career
awards: Third-team All-ACC ( 2015 )
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2021 ), NBA Cup champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Very good shooter with great athleticism and toughness—he could have been a two-sport pro (baseball) if not basketball.

strengths: Versatile scorer and passer • Effective in pick-and-roll situations • High three-point shooting percentage
weaknesses: Poor defensive fundamentals • Low assist-to-turnover ratio • Needs to improve physical strength
awards: AP honorable mention All-American ( 2015 ), First-team All-ACC (2015), Third-team All-ACC (2014), ACC Rookie of the Year (2013)
post draft awards: FIBA Europe Cup assists leader ( 2024 ), LKL champion ( 2016 ), NBA G League champion (2018), Greek League All Star (2020)
analysis: A big guard who can handle 1 and 2; perfect backup for Exum in Utah. Solid shooter with a good feel.

strengths: Elite scoring off the dribble • Quick first step • Deep three-point range
weaknesses: Average size for NBA guard • Below-average defense • Turnover prone
awards: Third-team All-American – SN ( 2015 ), Pac-12 Player of the Year ( 2015 ), First-team All-Pac-12 (2015), Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2014 ), Third-team All- Conference USA (2013), Conference USA All-Freshman (2012), Third-team Parade All-American (2010), Texas Mr. Basketball (2010)
post draft awards: CBA Foreign MVP (2020), CBA scoring champion ( 2020 ), CBA All-Star (2019), CBA All-Star Game MVP (2019)
analysis: One of the best pure scorers in the draft—an off-the-bench Lou Williams type. Only guy in my Top 30 still on the board in Round 2.

strengths: Great size and vision as a combo guard • Effective in pick-and-roll situations • Improved jump shooter and decision maker
weaknesses: Struggles with shot selection and finishing • Lacks NBA level speed and quickness • Needs to improve off-ball play and attitude
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
analysis: Big guard who can get to the rim; attitude and body language hurt his stock, but he can carve out a role if he embraces it.

strengths: Dangerous scoring threat with shooting touch • Quick release and uses screens effectively • Good rebounder for a guard
weaknesses: Undersized for shooting guard position • Struggles to create separation off dribble • Defensive liability due to size
awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2010 ), SEC Player of the Year (2009), First-team All- SEC (2009)
analysis: Quick, explosive combo guard with scoring chops—but a lack of size makes him a tough fit in the NBA.

strengths: High level athleticism and explosiveness • Strong finishing ability and body control • Excellent perimeter defender with quick hands
weaknesses: Inconsistent perimeter shooting • Limited court vision and passing • Struggles against tough defense and screens
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2015 )
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2019 )
analysis: A plus athlete and defender; offense is a work in progress, but he’s the type of tough wing Masai Ujiri covets.

strengths: Wide shoulders and sturdy frame • High field goal efficiency • Strong offensive rebounder
weaknesses: Limited playmaking ability • Average defensive rebounder • Not a great rim protector
awards: 2× LKL champion ( 2014, 2015 ), LKF Cup winner ( 2015 )
post draft awards: LBA champion ( 2018 ), 2× Italian Supercup winner ( 2017, 2018 ), All-LKL Team ( 2017 ), King Mindaugas Cup champion ( 2016 )
analysis: A Euroleague veteran with shot-blocking and rebounding skills. The Sixers will stash him overseas; he’s a project.

strengths: Dominant rebounder with strong physical presence • High motor and effective role player • Solid shot-blocker with good instincts
weaknesses: Limited offensive skill set • Struggles defensively on quick plays • Poor free-throw shooter and foul-prone
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
post draft awards: 2x NBL champion (2019, 2023), NBL Finals MVP (2019), CBA All Import Player First Team (2021), CBA All-Star (2019), All-NBA D-League First Team (2017), NBA D-League All-Star (2017), NBA D-League All-Rookie Team (2016)
analysis: A true backup center—rebounder, rim-protector, space-eater. Perfect 10–15 minutes per night in the NBA.

strengths: Consistent impact player with NBA range • Improved shooting percentages each season • Above average rebounder with 6'11.5" wingspan
weaknesses: Not a great defender, may never be • Frail build, lacks physical strength • Falls asleep defensively, out of position
awards: First-team All- Big Ten ( 2015 ), Third-team All-Big Ten – Media ( 2013 ), Big Ten All-Freshman team (2012)
post draft awards: FIBA Intercontinental Cup champion ( 2020 ), ABA League champion ( 2022 ), Serbian League champion ( 2022 ), Serbian Cup winner ( 2022 ), Lithuanian King Mindaugas Cup winner ( 2018 ), 2× Lithuanian LKL champion ( 2018, 2019 ), Greek League champion ( 2021 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2021 )
analysis: A hustler who rebounds and runs the floor. The Wizards needed PF depth, though he profiles more as a 10th–12th man.

strengths: Dead-eye three-point shooter • High shooting mechanics • Floor-spacing asset
weaknesses: Limited defensive tools • Below-average athleticism • Not strong finisher inside
awards: Spanish Supercup winner ( 2015 ), All-Liga ACB Young Players Team ( 2014 )
post draft awards: 3× Bundesliga champion ( 2020 – 2022 ), 2× German Cup winner ( 2020, 2022 ), All-Bundesliga First Team ( 2020 ), Liga ACB All-Star Game 3 Point Shootout champion (2017)
analysis: A sharpshooter from Sweden coming off an ACL—definite draft-and-stash pick with a pure stroke.

strengths: Led NCAA in scoring as a sophomore • Excellent three-point and free-throw shooter • Strong ball handler and playmaker
weaknesses: Lacks ideal size and athleticism • Struggles against tight, physical defense • Defensive focus and accuracy issues
awards: Honorable mention All-American – AP ( 2015 ), NCAA scoring champion (2015), 2× First-team All- Big Sky (2014, 2015), First-team Academic All-American ( 2015 )
post draft awards: NBL champion ( 2025 ), 2× All-NBL First Team ( 2021, 2025 )
analysis: One of the draft’s elite shooters—instant bench offense for the Magic behind Payton and Oladipo.

strengths: Draft's first Indian prospect • Massive 7'2" frame • Natural rim protector
weaknesses: Raw offensive skillset • Limited mobility • Needs weight and strength
analysis: He’s huge—insane length—but very raw. I’d be stunned if he ever logs NBA minutes.

strengths: Strong defensive instincts • High motor and energy • Versatile forward with length
weaknesses: Limited shooting range • Needs offensive polish • Inconsistent jump shot
awards: Haggerty Award (2015), Second-team All-Big East (2015), Big East Co-Defensive Player of the Year (2015), Big East Most Improved Player (2015)
post draft awards: WASL champion ( 2023 ), 2× Bahraini League champion (2023, 2024), Bahraini Cup winner (2023), NBA G League All-Defensive Team ( 2020 )
analysis: Showed marked improvement as a senior—strong rebounder and shot-blocker, but the lack of a jumper and shot creation scares teams.

strengths: Good wing scoring touch • Solid rebounding for size • High basketball IQ
weaknesses: Below-average athleticism • Limited isolation game • Struggles creating own shot
awards: Spanish Cup winner ( 2012 ), Spanish Supercup ( 2013 ), ACB Best Young Player Award ( 2015 )
post draft awards: EuroCup champion ( 2017 ), FIBA Intercontinental Cup champion ( 2020 )
analysis: A gritty shooter with good toughness, but athletic limitations and foreign contract make him a draft-and-stash candidate.

strengths: Elite rebounder • 7'3" wingspan rim protector • Efficient pick-and-pop shooter
weaknesses: Limited ball skills • Low free-throw percentage • Lacks strength inside
awards: Third-team All- Atlantic 10 (2015)
post draft awards: Arab Clubs Championship winner ( 2022 ), KBL Best 5 (2021), BSN champion ( 2016 ), NBA D-League All-Star (2016)
analysis: Elite shot-blocker with length and athleticism—he’ll disrupt on defense and carve out a role as a backup big.

strengths: Excellent rebounder and finisher • Versatile and smart defender • Strong physical presence with leadership
weaknesses: Inconsistent intensity and motor • Limited offensive range and quickness • Poor free throw shooter and slow agility
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten (2015), Big Ten All-Defensive Team (2015), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2012), Big Ten tournament MOP ( 2014 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2011 ), Third-team Parade All-American (2011)
post draft awards: T1 League All-Star ( 2023 ), Dominican LNB Best Defender (2019)
analysis: A defensive stalwart with strong NBA body. Offense and motor didn’t always show up at MSU, but he has the tools.

strengths: Good quickness and vision • Efficient pick-and-roll operator • Solid outside shooter
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA PG • Needs to improve defense • Average burst

analysis: Simmons was the No. 1 player on our Big Board all year and was the clear choice at No. 1. He has superstar potential as the biggest point guard to play the game. Yes, the Sixers think he's a point guard. To help him reach his upside, they'll need to play him that way.

weaknesses: Needs to improve physical strength • Defensive skills and footwork lacking • Can appear passive or disengaged in play

analysis: Ingram was the consensus No. 2 pick in the draft and the second player with clear All-Star upside. He has elite length, is a very good shooter and can defend multiple positions. The Lakers need all of that. He needs to get stronger, but he has a chance to be a star.

strengths: Explosive athlete with a 7-foot wingspan • Strong finisher, good in transition • Potential as a combo forward
weaknesses: Inconsistent long-range shooter • Prone to turnovers and fouls • Needs to improve shot selection
analysis: The Celtics had been signaling for a week that they really liked Brown. He had two terrific workouts for them and shot the lights out — something he didn't do at Cal as a freshman. He's an elite athlete, and he has a great NBA body. If he can really hit jumpers in the NBA, he has star potential. But that's a big if after a rocky freshman season at Cal.

analysis: I love this pick for the Suns. They have a huge need at the 4, and Bender is the prototypical new stretch 4 in the NBA. He is a very good shooter, and he protects the rim, rebounds and can guard multiple positions. I think Marquese Chriss has more upside and could make the Suns regret this pick, but Bender is a safer pick.

strengths: Excellent size and athleticism for a PG • Strong defensive instincts and versatility • Improved outside shooting and playmaking skills
weaknesses: Prone to turnovers and control issues • Inconsistent jump shooting ability • Concerns over injury history and age

post draft awards: NBA G League All-Defensive Team ( 2023 )
analysis: Tom Thibodeau loves Kris Dunn. He loves tough defenders who can guard multiple positions. But I'm a little surprised if he turned down a Jimmy Butler for No. 5 and Zach LaVine trade. I think that was the one deal that really would've made both teams better in the long run. I can't fault them for loving Dunn, but that trade could be a missed opportunity.

strengths: Improved 3-point shooting to 52.3% • Enhanced ball handling and playmaking • Elite conditioning and work ethic
weaknesses: Height disadvantage for NBA guard • Prone to turnovers under pressure • Not an elite NBA defender
awards: Naismith College Player of the Year (2016), John R. Wooden Award (2016), Oscar Robertson Trophy (2016), Sporting News College Player of the Year (2016), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All-American – AP, NABC ( 2015 ), Jerry West Award (2016), 2× Big 12 Player of the Year (2015, 2016), 2× First-team All- Big 12 (2015, 2016), Second-team All-Big 12 (2014)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2017 ), NBA Three-Point Contest champion ( 2020 )
analysis: Buddy Hield is a great fit in New Orleans. Eric Gordon is a free agent, and the Pelicans desperately need shooting and scoring. I think Hield will give them instant offense. He'll love playing with Anthony Davis and competing for coach Alvin Gentry. Hield is an obvious fit for New Orleans, though I might add that I had Jamal Murray ranked higher on my board and, long term, he might have been the better pick.

strengths: Polished, clutch performer with size • Comfortable finishing, creative in paint • Strong three-point shooter, moves well off-ball
weaknesses: Limited experience as primary playmaker • Prone to defensive lapses, gambles • High turnover rate, dependent on jump shot
awards: Third-team All-American – AP ( 2016 ), First-team All- SEC ( 2016 ), SEC All-Freshman Team ( 2016 ), BioSteel All-Canadian MVP (2015)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2023 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2017 )
analysis: Murray is a great fit for the Nuggets. He's the perfect backcourt mate for Emmanuel Mudiay, whose game is all about power, athleticism and passing. Murray's play is all about shooting and finesse. Each of them can play both the 1 and the 2. In a league of positionless players, they should work together perfectly. This was a steal for the Nuggets. Murray was at No. 4 on my Big Board.

strengths: Explosive frontcourt athlete with solid shooting • Quick first step and good at creating separation • Potential as a defender with good length and quickness
weaknesses: Low rebounding output for his physical gifts • Lacks fundamental defensive skills and discipline • High foul rate and plays out of control
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2017 )
analysis: I'm a big Marquese Chriss fan and a little surprised he slid to No. 8. I'm even more surprised the Kings would reportedly trade him for No. 13, No. 28, Bogdan Bogdanovic and a 2020 second-rounder. None of those players will have Chriss' upside. For the Suns? Great move. They were debating Chriss versus Bender up until right before the draft. Now they get both. Chriss' athletic ability should allow him to play the 3, at times, next to Bender. I think the Suns got significantly better tonight.

strengths: Excellent mobility for a 7-footer • Strong finisher around the rim • Good defensive footwork
weaknesses: Limited offensive post moves • Poor free throw shooting • Underdeveloped rim protection skills
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2016 ), Pete Newell Big Man Award (2016), Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Award (2016), Pac-12 Player of the Year (2016), First-team All-Pac-12 (2016), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team ( 2015 )
analysis: Poeltl is one of the safest picks in the draft. He's going to be in the NBA a long time. He has soft hands, and he rebounds, blocks shots and excels in the pick-and-roll. He needs to get stronger and develop a better jumper, but he is super skilled. Still, I'm a little surprised that the Raptors didn't swing for an upside pick like Skal Labissiere or Thon Maker. I can't fault the selection, but it's not a characteristic swing for the fences from Masai Ujiri.

strengths: Legit 7-footer with ball skills • Good rebounder and shot blocker • Strong free-throw shooter
weaknesses: Struggles with physical contact • Lacks defensive awareness • Needs to improve post play
analysis: You've got to hand it to Bucks general manager John Hammond: He's not afraid to go for it. He did it several years ago with Giannis Antetokounmpo. And he did it again with Thon Maker, who has the ability to be a star in the NBA, if the Bucks are patient. Maker is athletic. He can do a lot of things on offense. And he has one of the best motors in the draft. There's obviously major risk here for the Bucks. But I'd rather see a team like Milwaukee be aggressive than play it safe.

strengths: High energy, relentless rebounder • Strong core, excellent footwork • Great vision, effective passer
weaknesses: Average athlete, limited wingspan • Struggles against athletic defenders • Inconsistent shooting mechanics
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), Second-team Academic All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All- WCC (2016), Second-team All-WCC (2015), WCC All-Freshman Team (2015), No. 11 retired by Gonzaga Bulldogs
post draft awards: 3× NBA All-Star ( 2020, 2021, 2023 ), 2× All-NBA Third Team ( 2023, 2024 ), 3× NBA rebounding leader ( 2023 – 2025 )
analysis: The Magic are sending Victor Oladipo, Ersan Ilyasova and the draft rights to the No. 11 pick — Sabonis — to the Thunder for Serge Ibaka. I love the trade for the Thunder: An Oladipo-Westbrook backcourt will be very dynamic; and Sabonis has the sort of skill level and strength to play right now. The Magic? I love Ibaka. He fits a need as a stretch 4 who can protect the rim. But the Magic gave up a lot to get him.
