analysis: Prince wasn't ranked in my top 30, but that's not quite as bad as it sounds. There is a lot of parity from Nos. 10 to 35, and Prince is in that tier. He has potential as a 3-and-D guy for the Hawks. With Kent Bazemore hitting free agency, Prince fits a need. I think he has DeMarre Carroll-like upside, but in four years at Baylor, Prince was still more about potential than actual production.

strengths: Great size and length for position • High basketball I.Q. and solid midrange game • Good in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Struggles defending quick guards • Needs to improve shot mechanics • Must bulk up and enhance stamina

analysis: Papagiannis was a late riser on draft boards over the past couple of weeks. But No. 13? I think that's far too high. He is 7-foot-2, he's skilled and, at 18, he has a ton of upside. But trading Marquese Chriss for him? I don't see it. I think he could be a solid backup center in the NBA. He's a project, though, and I'm not sure, given the modern NBA, there is still a place for the lumbering-center type.

strengths: Exceptional leader with high basketball IQ • Elite passer with great court vision • Developed into a great perimeter shooter
weaknesses: Slow and lacks athleticism • Struggles without the ball • Uncertain defensive role at next level
awards: AP Player of the Year (2016), NABC Player of the Year (2016), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2016 ), Senior CLASS Award (2016), Julius Erving Award (2016), Lute Olson Award (2016), Big Ten Male Athlete of the Year (2016), Big Ten Player of the Year (2016), First-team All- Big Ten (2016), Third-team All-Big Ten (2015), Big Ten tournament MOP ( 2016 )
analysis: The Bulls traded their former franchise point guard, Derrick Rose, to the Knicks on Wednesday. Did they draft another one at No. 14? On the surface, Valentine doesn't seem to be a point guard. He played the wing at Michigan State. But he's one of the best passers in the draft, and in the new, positionless NBA, he'll see time at point guard, at least on the offensive end. There have been concerns about his knees and what position he will defend, but overall, this is a really good pick if he can stay healthy. He fits perfectly.

strengths: Versatile forward with stretch shooting range • Agile roller in pick-and-pop • High motor and stamina
weaknesses: Raw post footwork • Inconsistent defensive focus • Needs strength for physical play

analysis: Our own Kevin Pelton had Hernangomez ranked No. 8 on this draft board. I wouldn't go that far, but I do love this pick for the Nuggets at No. 15. He played well in Spain this year. He can shoot the 3 and is very skilled. I'm not sure if this is a draft-and-stash type of pick, but with Hernangomez and fellow draftee Jamal Murray, I think the Nuggets got a lot more skilled.

strengths: Tremendous wingspan and mobility • Great in transition and slashing • Improving perimeter shooter
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA power forward • Raw, untested against elite competition • Lateral quickness and post defense need work
post draft awards: EuroLeague champion ( 2023 ), 2× Liga ACB champion ( 2022, 2024 ), Spanish Cup winner ( 2024 ), LNB Pro A champion (2021), French Cup winner (2021), 3× Spanish Supercup winner (2021–2023), CBA All-Star ( 2017 )
analysis: I actually really like this pick for the Celtics. Fran Fraschilla called Yabusele the 'French Larry Johnson,' and I think that about sums it up. He is a beast in the paint but still pretty bouncy. He can even shoot the rock from 3. And he plays really hard. This will be a draft-and-stash pick for the Celtics. But in the long run? I think he'll be in the NBA for quite a few years.

strengths: Explosive first step and quickness • Strong pick-and-roll play • Tough on-ball defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent outside shooting • Below-average size for PG • Prone to turnovers
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2016)

analysis: I wonder if the Baldwin pick signals uncertainty about whether the team will be able to re-sign Mike Conley this summer? Baldwin is a physical specimen. He is huge, a very good athlete and a proven shooter. Is he a point guard? His decision-making was questionable at Vanderbilt. So was his leadership. But with the way the league is going, he should be able to find a spot in the NBA.

strengths: Versatile with smooth offensive skills • Good feel and understanding of the game • Productive and solid rebounder
weaknesses: Below average athleticism and speed • Struggles with explosiveness and physicality • Limited defensive capabilities

analysis: The Pistons got one of the steals of the draft in Ellenson. For much of the year, he was ranked in the top 10 on my Big Board. He slid late, based on concerns about his lack of athleticism, but he's one of the most skilled big men in the draft. He can shoot 3s, has an advanced midrange game and is big enough to play center and rebound. His versatility should allow him to thrive, and I actually really like him long term, as paired with Andre Drummond.

strengths: Explosive athlete with strong transition play • Excellent shooter with good mechanics • Effective off-ball movement and finishing
weaknesses: Needs improvement in playmaking • Ball handling and turnovers are issues • Defensive fundamentals and discipline lacking
awards: ACC All-Freshman team (2016)
analysis: Beasley is one of the best shooters in the draft. He suffered a stress fracture in his right leg that limited his workouts and caused him to slide a little. Before the injury, I thought he might go in the lottery. He's a great athlete, and he plays really hard. My only question is, with Gary Harris and Murray on the roster, are the Nuggets really keeping Beasley? You can never have enough shooters, but he's a bit redundant.

strengths: Excellent size and shooting ability • Strong court vision and passing • Effective in transition
weaknesses: Injury-prone with foot issues • Needs to gain strength • Inconsistent half-court playmaker
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten ( 2014 )
analysis: The Nets got this pick from the Pacers as part of the Thaddeus Young trade. This is an upside selection for Brooklyn, despite the fact that it is a taking a college senior. Had he not been injured during his junior and senior seasons, he would likely have been a late lottery pick. He is athletic, can defend three positions, shoots the 3 and is an excellent ball handler and passer. If he overcomes the medical concerns, the Nets will have a really good player who will help them get better.

strengths: Explosive athlete with big wingspan • Excellent in transition and open floor • Strong finisher and passer
weaknesses: Low shooting efficiency • Defensive intensity and technique lacking • Needs to improve physical strength
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), Atlantic 10 Player of the Year (2016), Robert V. Geasey Trophy winner (2016), 2× First-team All- Atlantic 10 (2015, 2016), Atlantic 10 All-Defensive Team (2016)
analysis: I really like Bembry. He has an old-school game but in the body of an elite athlete. Next to Ben Simmons, he is the best passer in the draft. His shooting percentage from 3 dropped the past three seasons and that's a concern, but I love this pick for Atlanta.

strengths: Prototypical size and athleticism • Versatile and effective scorer • Strong perimeter defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent offensive production • Needs improved ball-handling • Unreliable shooting form and decision-making
awards: ACC All-Freshman team (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2015 ), First-team Parade All-American (2015)
analysis: The Kings got this one right, I think. They needed help at the 2-guard position, and Richardson brings a lot to the table. He has a huge wingspan, and he can score off the bounce. He is a streaky shooter, but when he gets it going, he's one of the best scorers in the draft.

strengths: Exceptional rebounding ability • Strong finisher at the rim • Effective in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Needs to improve footwork • Limited offensive versatility • Struggles against quicker guards
awards: FIBA Europe Cup Starting Five ( 2016 ), ABA League Top Prospect ( 2016 )
post draft awards: Turkish League champion ( 2023 ), Israeli League winner 2021, Israeli Cup winner ( 2021 ), Israeli League Cup winner ( 2021 ), Turkish Super Cup winner ( 2022 ), Turkish Super Cup MVP ( 2022 )
analysis: Žižić is another draft-and-stash option for the Celtics. He's one of the best rebounders in the draft. He is strong and has a great motor. But he's really raw offensively. Overall, it's a nice pick for the Celtics; Žižić will be in the NBA someday.

strengths: Lengthy two-way wing • Strong defensive versatility • Smooth catch-and-shoot stroke
weaknesses: Inconsistent shot creation • Needs strength for rebounds • Raw finishing at rim
awards: Serbian Cup winner ( 2016 ), All-Adriatic League Team ( 2016 ), French Second League champion (2013), LNB Pro B Leaders Cup champion (2015)
post draft awards: Italian League champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Both Kevin Pelton and I are on record as Luwawu-Cabarrot skeptics. He's projected as a 3-and-D type in the NBA, though he is a streaky shooter. And while he was a good defender in Europe, I don't think he would be ranked this high if he had played college ball. With Dejounte Murray on the board, I think the Sixers missed an opportunity here.

strengths: High efficiency and shot selection • Excellent athleticism and mobility • Strong finisher and rebounder
weaknesses: Needs to improve outside shooting • Struggles with physicality and strength • Defensive consistency and intensity lacking
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All-ACC (2016), Third-team All-ACC (2015), ACC All-Defensive Team (2016), No. 11 honored by North Carolina Tar Heels, First-team Parade All-American (2012), South Carolina Mr. Basketball (2012)
analysis: Johnson was one of the best rebounders in college basketball as a senior. He's a very good athlete, and he has a really nice midrange game. But he looks like a tweener in the NBA: He lacks strength and doesn't stretch the floor. I think there were better prospects on the board.

strengths: Natural born scorer with high shooting percentage • Excels in creating scoring opportunities • Strong athleticism and agility
weaknesses: Needs to improve defensive strength • Inconsistent performance in games • Requires more muscle mass for NBA level
awards: 2× Turkish Cup winner ( 2015, Turkish Supercup winner (2015), Turkish BSL Slam Dunk Contest winner (2016)
post draft awards: NBA G League champion (2023), 2017 ), FIBA Champions League Best Young Player ( 2017 ), 3× Turkish BSL All-Star (2015–2017)
analysis: I totally endorse the Korkmaz pick. He was ranked No. 13 on my final Big Board. He is a prototypical NBA wing who can shoot and handle the ball. He's a very good athlete. The main issue is that he needs to get a lot stronger. But I think the Sixers essentially got a lottery pick at No. 26. That's a home run.

strengths: High energy with great length and quickness • Effective defender on perimeter and post • Strong rebounder and solid shooter
weaknesses: Questionable competition level at mid-major • Offensive skills somewhat unorthodox • Needs to improve upper body strength
awards: AP Honorable mention All-American ( 2016 ), WAC Player of the Year (2016), WAC Freshman of the Year (2015)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2019 ), 3× NBA All-Star ( 2020, 2023, 2025 ), All-NBA Second Team ( 2020 ), All-NBA Third Team ( 2022 ), NBA Most Improved Player (2019), NBA D-League champion ( 2017 ), NBA D-League Finals MVP (2017)
analysis: Siakam is a Masai Ujiri player all the way: tough; plays with a great motor; good rebounder and shot-blocker; and willing to do all the dirty work. He's not the most sophisticated offensive player, but he plays his heart out. I think Cheick Diallo might have been a better option for the same type of player, but Siakam is ready to play right now.

strengths: Prototypical height and length • Excellent shooting and range • High defensive potential
weaknesses: Inconsistent intensity and energy • Lacks physical toughness • Underdeveloped basketball fundamentals
awards: First-team Parade All-American (2015)
post draft awards: NBA G League champion ( 2025 ), NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2024, 2025 )
analysis: Labissiere was a major risk as a potential lottery pick. But late in the first round? There's no risk. He is a terrific pick here. He's an elite shooter and can be a very good shot-blocker. If he ever figures out how to assert himself, he could be a Channing Frye-type player.

strengths: Tremendous handles and versatility • Explosive athlete with great length • Excellent rebounder and defender
weaknesses: Needs to gain strength • Inconsistent shooting and performance • Must improve decision making and turnovers
awards: Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2016 ), Fourth-team Parade All-American (2015), Washington Mr. Basketball (2015)
post draft awards: NBA All-Star ( 2022 ), NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2018 ), NBA steals leader ( 2022 )
analysis: The Spurs got the steal of the draft. Murray was ranked No. 9 on my final Big Board. He is a superquick, 6-foot-5 point guard with a 6-foot-11 wingspan. He's one of the best shot creators off the bounce in the draft. He plays really hard and is an elite rebounder. He isn't a great shooter, and he needs to get stronger. But he has All-Star upside, and the Spurs are the perfect team to get it out of him. Remember, Tony Parker went late in the first round too.

strengths: Ideal size and athleticism for NBA center • Efficient shooter, nearly 60% from the floor • High-character, hardworking individual
weaknesses: Inconsistent intensity and focus • Poor rebounding for his size • Needs improvement in post skills and toughness
awards: 2× First-team All- SEC (2015, 2016)
post draft awards: 2× NBA champion ( 2017, 2018 )
analysis: Jones is an elite athlete reminiscent of DeAndre Jordan. He can jump out of the gym and should enjoy receiving lobs from the Splash Brothers for years. He doesn't always show up, which is why he's not a lottery pick. But at No. 30, he's really good value for the Warriors.

strengths: NBA length with 7'2" wingspan • Advanced rim protector and defender • Effective scorer around the rim
weaknesses: Lapses in defensive awareness • Struggles offensively beyond the rim • Foul prone and bites on fakes
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2015 ), First-team Parade All-American (2015), Mr. Basketball of Michigan (2015)
post draft awards: 2× T1 League All-Defensive First Team ( 2022, 2023 ), 2× T1 League blocks leader ( 2022, 2023 )
analysis: This was a stunning fall for Davis on draft night. He's an elite athlete with an NBA body. But he struggled in workouts, and teams worried if he would be able to make the transition to the league. He is a great pick for the Grizzlies in the second round.

strengths: Great size and finishing ability • Effective in pick and roll situations • Potential as a mid-range shooter
weaknesses: Prone to injuries • Struggles with defensive footwork • Limited offensive range beyond 5-7 feet
analysis: Some teams were Zubac fans, while others preferred Ante Žižić, who went No. 23. Zubac might ultimately have more upside if he's given time to develop, particularly on the offensive end.

strengths: Excellent end-to-end speed • Strong shot blocking ability • Effective rebounder
weaknesses: Poor offensive decision making • Needs to improve physical strength • Inconsistent shot mechanics
awards: First-team Parade All-American (2015), McDonald's All-American Game MVP ( 2015 )
analysis: He's raw. But had Diallo stayed in school another season, he probably would have been a lottery pick next year. He is tough and athletic, and he might have the best motor in the draft.

strengths: True floor general with high basketball IQ • Quick with the ball, pushes tempo effectively • Competent perimeter shooter with quick release
weaknesses: Limited by lack of height and strength • Streaky shooter with inconsistent field percentage • Struggles to finish at the rim against size
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2016 ), Bob Cousy Award (2016), SEC Player of the Year ( 2016 ), SEC Defensive Player of the Year (2016), First-team All-SEC (2016), SEC All-Freshman Team ( 2015 ), SEC tournament MVP ( 2016 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 )
analysis: If Ulis were three inches taller and 30 pounds heavier, he would've been a lottery pick, but his size hurt his draft stock. Still, Ulis has an elite feel for the game.

strengths: Tremendous size and wingspan for wing position • Effective post-up and spot shooting abilities • Solid rebounder and versatile scorer
weaknesses: Lacks elite explosiveness and leaping abilities • Inconsistent shooter, struggles in ISO • Limited lateral speed defensively
awards: 3× Serbian Cup winner ( 2016
post draft awards: 2019, 2020 ), ABA League Supercup winner ( 2019 )
analysis: Zagorac is a skilled wing player who has great size and length for his position. However, his lack of a consistent jumper and elite athleticism limit his upside.

strengths: Strong body frame and good size • High basketball IQ and leadership • Effective off-ball and perimeter scorer
weaknesses: Needs improved ball-handling • Limited athletic and explosive ability • Shooting mechanics and range concerns
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2016 ), Consensus second-team All-American ( 2015 ), NABC Defensive Player of the Year (2016), ACC Player of the Year (2016), 3× First-team All-ACC (2014–2016), 2× ACC Defensive Player of the Year (2015, 2016), No. 15 retired by Virginia Cavaliers
post draft awards: NBA Sixth Man of the Year ( 2023 ), NBA Rookie of the Year ( 2017 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2017 ), 50–40–90 club ( 2019 )
analysis: Brogdon slipped a bit because of concerns about his foot, but he's a really versatile player who can swing between the 1, 2 and 3. His lack of athleticism is the main thing holding him back.

strengths: Strong defensive presence and rim protector • Impressive physical measurements and strength • Effective in pick-and-roll situations
weaknesses: Limited offensive skill set • Prone to fouling and turnovers • Poor free throw shooting and conditioning issues
post draft awards: Israeli Basketball Premier League MVP ( 2022 ), All-Israeli League First Team ( 2022 ), Israeli Basketball State Cup winner ( 2022 ), Israeli Basketball State Cup MVP (2022), Croatian League champion ( 2021 ), All-Croatian League First Team (2021), All-Croatian League All-Defensive Team (2021), Croatian Cup winner (2021), Croatian Cup MVP (2021), All-Korean League First Team (2020), Korean League All-Imports Team (2020)
analysis: Onuaku is a beast in the paint. He has an NBA body. He can really rebound and block shots. And he's just 19 years old. It's his lack of an offensive game that holds him back.

strengths: Excellent size and wingspan for guard position • Strong defensive skills and versatility • Effective in transition and clutch situations
weaknesses: Needs to increase strength and muscle • Lacks a natural position, affecting consistency • Can be careless and undisciplined with the ball
awards: Second-team All- MWC (2016), MWC All-Defensive Team (2016)
post draft awards: 3× NBA champion ( 2017 – 2019 ), NBA G League champion ( 2023 )
analysis: He's not only a good athlete who can defend multiple positions, but he's also a terrific passer and an emerging shooter. McCaw could easily have been a first-round pick.

strengths: Good size and athleticism for position • Effective in transition and half-court • Improving shot mechanics and range
weaknesses: Needs to add strength • Lacks elite court vision • High turnover rate
analysis: Michineau is a 6-foot-4 point guard from France. He's quick, and he has the size and athleticism to defend. But he's not a good shooter, and his game is a work in progress. He wasn't ranked in our top 100.

strengths: Excellent size and strength • Good interior scoring ability • Effective post defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent motor • Poor practice habits • Struggles against strong defenders
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2015 ), First-team Parade All-American (2015), Wisconsin Mr. Basketball (2015)
post draft awards: Balkan League champion ( 2024 ), T1 League points leader ( 2022 ), NBA G League champion (2019)
analysis: Stone is super talented. He has a great low-post game and can even shoot the 3. His lack of elite athleticism is what's holding him back.

strengths: High basketball IQ and solid skill set • Versatile big man with mobility • Strong passer and decision-maker
weaknesses: Needs to improve post play • Lacks physical strength and toughness • Inconsistent intensity and focus
awards: McDonald's All-American (2015)
analysis: Zimmerman was once considered a potential first-round prospect. He is the type of big man who can stretch the floor and still protect the rim. But he has to get stronger and tougher, and some minor injury concerns have held him back.

strengths: NBA-ready body frame and size • Versatile and strong playmaking skills • Effective in transition and finishing
weaknesses: Inconsistent shooting mechanics • Questionable decision-making • Struggles with defensive fundamentals
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All-Big East (2016), Big East All-Rookie team (2015), Big East tournament MOP ( 2016 ), Haggerty Award (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014), Mr. New York Basketball (2014)
post draft awards: Kazakhstan League champion (2019)
analysis: Whitehead is one of the best scorers in the draft, and he's also a terrific ball handler who can make plays for others. He's just not an elite athlete, and there have been concerns about his commitment to playing with teammates.

strengths: Elite rim protector with mobility • Effective mid-range shooter • High basketball IQ and feel
weaknesses: Lacks overall strength and weight • Struggles with defensive rebounding • Not a vocal leader or mentally tough
awards: 3× CBA Best Defender (2016, 2× CBA blocks leader ( 2015, 2016 ), FIBA Asia Champions Cup champion ( 2016 ), CBA Rookie of the Year Award ( 2015 ), 2015 FIBA Asia Championship All-Star Team
post draft awards: CBA champion ( 2017 ), 2017, 2020), 4× CBA All-Star ( 2015 – 2017, 2020, 2021 ), All-CBA Second Team ( 2020 ), All-CBA First Team ( 2021 ), 2022 FIBA Asia Cup All-star Five, 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup qualification (Asia) 4th window MVP
analysis: Zhou is loaded with talent. He is huge and very skilled on the perimeter, and he can be an excellent shot-blocker. He's just very skinny, and there are questions from teams about his true age.

strengths: Excellent athleticism and quickness • Effective in transition and off-ball plays • Improving three-point shooter
weaknesses: Needs to build physical strength • Inconsistent defensive effort • Shot mechanics and selection need work
awards: French Second League Most Improved Player (2016), French Second League champion (2013)
post draft awards: EuroCup champion ( 2022 ), All-EuroCup First Team ( 2021 ), 2× Italian Supercup winner ( 2022, 2023 )
analysis: Cordinier isn't ready, but he can really play. He is a good shooter and quick with the ball, and he can even play a little point. But he needs a lot more experience and to get stronger.

strengths: Explosive scorer and playmaker • Strong finisher, seeks contact • Good on-ball defender
weaknesses: Smaller stature for NBA • Needs improved point guard skills • Streaky shooting, dropped percentages
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
analysis: Jackson has the tools to be really effective on both ends of the floor. He's an elite athlete, he defends, he sees the floor well and he can even shoot it a bit. Teams just worry that his lack of elite size and missing aggression on offense make him more of a backup point guard.

strengths: Rim protection specialist • Excellent timing and wingspan • Effective pick-and-roll roller
weaknesses: Limited offensive moves • Poor free throw shooting • Lacks mobility on switches
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All- Big Ten (2016), Second-team All-Big Ten (2015), Big Ten Defensive Player of the Year (2016), 3× Big Ten All-Defensive Team (2014–2016), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2013)
analysis: Hammons has the skill set, athleticism and body of an NBA lottery pick. But his lack of production at Purdue during his first three years, combined with conditioning and potential attitude issues, dropped him to the second round. If he gets all of that worked out, he'll be the steal of the draft.

strengths: Versatile forward with good perimeter shooting • Athletic with strong finishing ability • Adaptable role player and efficient scorer
weaknesses: Limited ballhandling and shot creation • Struggles with rebounding for his size • Likely reached developmental ceiling
awards: Third-team All- Big Ten – Media (2015)
analysis: Layman is a terrific athlete who can play the 3 and the 4. He's a good shooter, but he lacked assertiveness in his four years at Maryland.

strengths: NBA-ready body with versatile play • Effective without needing ball control • Strong defender across multiple positions
weaknesses: Slow shot release and adjustment issues • Struggles in ISO and pick-and-roll • Inconsistent shooter with high dribble
awards: German BBL champion ( 2014 ), BBL All-Star (2016), BBL Best German Young Player ( 2016 )
post draft awards: 2× German Cup winner (2021, 2023)
analysis: Zipser played well at the Adidas Eurocamp and helped himself become a potential late first-round selection. He is very long, a strong defender and a good shooter. He could eventually be a 3-and-D player in the NBA.

strengths: Versatile with good size and athleticism • Effective shooter with solid IQ • Experienced in multiple positions
weaknesses: Lacks exceptional standout skill • Needs improvement in free-throw shooting • Prone to turnovers and defensive lapses
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2016)
analysis: Gbinije is another point forward who would've gone in the first round if he were three years younger. I think he can help a team right away.

strengths: High basketball IQ and scoring efficiency • Versatile scorer with strong post moves • Excellent passer and leader
weaknesses: Lacks quickness and explosiveness • Subpar physical measurements for NBA • Limited defensive capabilities
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2016 ), Third-team All-American – AP, NABC ( 2015 ), Karl Malone Award (2016), 2× First-team All- Big 12 (2015, 2016), Third-team All-Big 12 (2014), Big 12 tournament MVP ( 2015 ), Big 12 All-Rookie team (2013)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League First Team ( 2018 )
analysis: Scouts will tell you that his lack of athletic ability and size for his position are concerning. But with playmaking 4s all the rage in the NBA, is Niang the guy who fell into the second round that should've been in the top 10?

strengths: Aggressive scorer with strong interior play • High free throw percentage and shooting range • Effective in transition and finishing at rim
weaknesses: Lacks height and athleticism for position • Inefficient scorer with poor shot selection • Limited defensive presence and rebounding skills
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All-Big East (2016), Big East Most Improved Player (2016)
post draft awards: 2× Greek League champion ( 2020, 2021 ), Greek League rebounding leader (2019), LBA champion ( 2022 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2021 ), Italian Cup winner (2022), Serbian League champion ( 2023 ), Serbian Cup winner ( 2023 )
analysis: Bentil is a scoring machine who can hit shots from anywhere on the floor. If he were a couple of inches taller, he would have gone much higher.

strengths: Excellent rebounder and leaper • Strong shooter with three-point range • Consistent improvement in scoring
weaknesses: Limited offensive variety • Plays upright, lacks defensive agility • Not a strong shot blocker or rim protector
awards: Big Sky Player of the Year (2016), First-team All- Big Sky (2016), AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), 2× Big Sky Defensive Player of the Year (2014, 2016)
post draft awards: EuroLeague champion ( 2019 ), 2× VTB United League champion ( 2019, 2021 ), ABA League champion ( 2024 ), Serbian League champion (2024), Greek League champion ( 2023 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2023 ), 2× Serbian Cup winner (2024, 2025), Greek Super Cup winner (2022)
analysis: I'm a big Bolomboy fan. He's a great athlete and elite rebounder who plays particularly hard. His offensive game is coming along, as well. He's underrated.

strengths: Great size and mobility • Explosive with good defensive skills • Impressive shooting range
weaknesses: Needs to improve fundamental skills • Struggles with physicality in the paint • Inconsistent free throw shooting
awards: French Cup winner ( 2016 ), French Leaders Cup winner (2014), LNB Pro A Best Young Player ( 2015 )
post draft awards: EuroLeague champion ( 2023 ), Spanish Supercup winner ( 2022 ), NBA G League rebounding leader ( 2022 ), LNB Pro A champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Cornelie is a classic stretch big man. He's a fluid athlete, as well. He just needs to get stronger. He's a very good draft-and-stash candidate.

strengths: Lightning-quick first step • Excellent ballhandler and passer • Strong scoring instinct
weaknesses: Undersized frame • Below-average jumper • Defensive mismatch against taller guards
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, NABC, SN ( 2016 ), NCAA assists leader (2016), Horizon League Player of the Year (2016), 2× First-team All- Horizon League (2015, 2016), Horizon League Freshman of the Year (2014)
post draft awards: CBA International MVP ( 2022 )
analysis: Felder is vying to be the next Isaiah Thomas. He's a gifted athlete, terrific scorer and fine playmaker. He is just three to four inches short of being a lottery pick.

strengths: Elite shooter with strong shot selection • Excellent ball handler and passer • Strong defensive awareness and positioning
weaknesses: Struggles with physicality and strength • Inconsistent finishing against bigger defenders • Prone to forcing passes and rushed shots
awards: Second-team All-American – SN ( 2014 ), 2× Second-team Academic All-American (2014, 2015), First-team All-ACC (2014), Third-team All-ACC (2015), First-team Academic All-American (2016), ACC Most Improved Player (2014), ACC All-Freshman team (2013), No. 5 honored by North Carolina Tar Heels, McDonald's All-American ( 2012 ), First-team Parade All-American (2012), Iowa Mr. Basketball (2012)
post draft awards: 2× Serbian Cup winner ( 2019, 2020 ), ABA League Supercup winner ( 2019 )
analysis: Paige is a talented guard who never really progressed the way teams wanted to see. But he can shoot and play the point, and he is a solid selection here.

strengths: Versatile wing with good size and vision • Tenacious rebounder and willing passer • Strong finisher and transition player
weaknesses: Inefficient offensive player with poor FG% • Lacks speed and defensive quickness • Struggles to create own shot, underweight
awards: Second-team All- AAC (2016), AAC Rookie of the Year ( 2015 ), AAC tournament MVP ( 2016 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014)
analysis: For two straight seasons, Hamilton has shot worse than 40 percent from the field, and his 3-point shooting dipped to just 33 percent last season. He's a terrific rebounder and proven playmaker, which is appealing to NBA teams, but he really needs to add strength and a jump shot.

strengths: Dominates with maturity and confidence • Excellent rebounder and post scorer • Strong, effective in high-post plays
weaknesses: Struggles with athleticism and speed • Defensive liabilities in pick and roll • Inconsistent shooting, poor free-throw accuracy
awards: 7× CBA All-Star ( 2013 – 2015, CBA Rookie of the Year ( 2013 )
analysis: Zhelin burst onto the scene at the Nike Hoop Summit years ago and made a name for himself in China. His lack of athleticism hurts his stock a bit, but he's big, skilled and worth watching over the next few years.

strengths: High basketball IQ • Solid mid-range shooting • Strong perimeter defense
weaknesses: Inconsistent three-point accuracy • Lacks explosive athleticism • Needs playmaking polish
awards: MAC All-Freshman Team (2012)
post draft awards: NBA D-League Rookie of the Year (2017), All-NBA D-League Second Team (2017), NBA D-League All-Rookie Team (2017), NBA D-League All-Star (2017)
analysis: Nader is a wing who averaged 13 points per game and shot 37 percent from the 3-line last season. He's the second player to be drafted outside our top 100.

strengths: Versatile with good assist-to-turnover ratio • Effective in high tempo offense • Strong perimeter shooter
weaknesses: Struggles with shot selection • Below average field goal percentage • Needs to improve strength for NBA defense
awards: Third-team All- Big 12 (2016), First-team Parade All-American (2012)
post draft awards: ENBL MVP ( 2025 ), Israeli League Cup winner ( 2019 )
analysis: Cousins was off the radar for much of last season, thanks to the Buddy Hield show, but he has a lot going for him. He is big and very athletic, and he shoots the ball well and plays terrific defense.

strengths: Versatile guard with strong rebounding • Improved playmaking and ball handling • Solid defender with good anticipation
weaknesses: Needs to improve shooting mechanics • Inconsistent from three-point range • Free throw shooting below average
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2015 )
analysis: Wallace began the season red-hot, before cooling in Pac-12 play. For a while, he was considered a potential late-first-round pick; but as the season progressed, he looked more like a second-round selection.

strengths: Explosive slasher in transition • High motor and energy • Instinctive rebounder
weaknesses: Limited outside shot • Below-average size • Consistency concerns
awards: Second-team All- MVC (2016), MVC Newcomer of the Year (2015), MVC All-Newcomer Team (2015)
post draft awards: VTB United League All-Star Game MVP (2024), All-Champions League Second Team ( 2022 ), 2× Basketligaen champion ( 2017, 2018 ), Basketligaen MVP ( 2017 ), Basketligaen Finals MVP ( 2017 ), Basketligaen scoring champion ( 2017 )

strengths: High basketball IQ • Excellent court vision • Composed ballhandler
weaknesses: Below-average athleticism • Limited scoring upside • Defensive liabilities
awards: NCAA champion ( 2016 ), NCAA Tournament Most Outstanding Player ( 2016 ), Big East co-Player of the Year (2015), First-team All-Big East (2015), 2× Second-team All-Big East (2014, 2016), Big East All-Rookie Team (2013), No. 15 jersey retired by Villanova Wildcats

strengths: Great feel for the game • Solid shooter with range • Improved offensive creator
weaknesses: Lacks standout NBA skill • Undersized and lacks speed • Injury concerns and inconsistency
awards: 3× First-team All- MVC (2014–2016), AP honorable mention All-American ( 2015 )

strengths: Lightning-quick guard • Prolific scorer • Creative playmaker
weaknesses: Questionable defensive effort • Small frame • Inconsistent shooting
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2016 ), First-team All-ACC (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2013 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2022 ), CEBL champion ( 2023 ), 2× All-CEBL First Team (2023, 2024 ), 2× All-CEBL Second Team ( 2021, 2022 ), Portuguese Cup winner (2024), Portuguese Cup MVP (2024)

strengths: High basketball IQ • Strong defensive instincts • Versatile playmaker
weaknesses: Below-average athleticism • Limited scoring upside • Low three-point volume
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2016), SEC All-Defensive Team (2015)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2020 ), NBA All-Defensive First Team ( 2023 ), NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2024 ), Second-team All-NBA G League (2018)

strengths: Versatile playmaker • High basketball IQ • Strong rebounder for size
weaknesses: Below-average shooter • Limited athletic burst • Defensive limitations
awards: WCC Player of the Year (2016), 3× First-team All- WCC (2014–2016), 2× AP honorable mention All-American ( 2015, 2016 ), Utah Mr. Basketball (2010)

strengths: Solid post scoring • High motor rebounder • Reliable free throw shooter
weaknesses: Below-average athleticism • Limited defensive versatility • Lacks face-up game
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten – Media (2016), Third-team All-Big Ten – Coaches (2016), First-team Parade All-American (2012), Michigan Mr. Basketball (2012)
post draft awards: NBA G League champion (2018)

strengths: Experienced and quick-scoring point guard • Excellent leader and floor general • Great shooter, especially off-the-dribble
weaknesses: Very small with a thin frame • Lacks length for effective NBA defense • Limited potential for improvement at 23
awards: Second-team All-American – SN ( 2016 ), Third-team All-American – AP, NABC (2016), 2× First-team All- Big Ten (2015, 2016), Second-team All-Big Ten ( 2014 ), Big Ten All-Defensive team (2016), Big Ten All-Freshman Team ( 2013 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2012 )
post draft awards: Montenegrin Cup winner (2025), 2× Slovenian League champion ( 2022, 2023 ), 2× Slovenian Cup winner (2022, 2023), EuroCup Top Scorer ( 2023 ), NBA D-League All-Star ( 2017 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2017 )

strengths: High effort, defensive-minded forward • Solid shooter with good decision-making • Strong rebounder and finishes well
weaknesses: Limited offensive skills • Older with less developmental upside • Problematic shooting mechanics
awards: 2× Second-team All- SEC (2015, 2016), SEC Sixth Man of the Year (2014), ACC All-Freshman Team (2012)

strengths: Dead-eye three-point shooter • High basketball IQ • Reliable free throw shooter
weaknesses: Limited athleticism • Below-average defender • Struggles finishing inside
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten (2016), Second-team All- Horizon League (2014), Horizon League Newcomer of the Year (2013), Horizon League All-Newcomer Team (2013)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2021 )

analysis: Fultz is the perfect fit for the Sixers. They needed a big guard who can play both on and off the ball, stretch the floor and guard both backcourt positions. He's the perfect complement to Ben Simmons and Joel Embiid. The Sixers now have their big three. If they can stay healthy, they'll terrorize the league in a few years. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite transition play and vision • Exceptional passing accuracy • Efficient in transition play
weaknesses: Struggles with physical guards • Limited mid-range and pull-up game • Needs quicker shooting mechanics
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2017 ), NBA Summer League MVP (2017), Wayman Tisdale Award (2017), NABC Freshman of the Year (2017), NCAA assists leader (2017), First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2017 ), Pac-12 Freshman of the Year (2017), National high school player of the year (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), California Mr. Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2018 )
analysis: Lonzo Ball has as much talent as anyone in the draft. Forget about the hype and his father. He's the most talented passer to come into the draft since Jason Kidd. He makes everyone on the court better. He should help facilitate the development of their young players dramatically next year. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excels in mid-range scoring • Strong finisher at the rim • Advanced offensive skillset
weaknesses: Inconsistent defensive intensity • Struggles against physicality • Streaky three-point shooter
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2017), ACC All-Freshman team (2017), Gatorade National Player of the Year (2016), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), Mr. Show-Me Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2024 ), 6× NBA All-Star ( 2020 – 2025 ), NBA All-Star Game MVP ( 2023 ), 3× All-NBA First Team ( 2022 – 2024 ), All-NBA Third Team ( 2020 ), NBA Eastern Conference Finals MVP ( 2022 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2018 )
analysis: The Celtics went with a guy they felt could really improve their offense. Tatum is the best scorer in the draft and perhaps the most NBA-ready prospect. With so many defensively minded players on the perimeter, Tatum should be able to help open up the floor offensively. -- Chad Ford

strengths: High basketball IQ and court awareness • Elite offensive rebounder and assertive • Disruptive and explosive defender
weaknesses: Poor three-point and free throw shooting • Prone to foul trouble and frustration • Needs to refine shooting mechanics
awards: Second-team All-American – SN ( 2017 ), Third-team All-American – AP, NABC (2017), First-team All- Big 12 (2017), Big 12 Freshman of the Year (2017), McDonald's All-American Co-MVP ( 2016 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2018 )
analysis: Jackson gives the Suns the aggressive defender they've lacked the past few years. His ballhandling also allows him to play some point. He should be lethal paired on the wing next to Devin Booker. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite speed and athleticism • Strong ball handling and finishing ability • Promising defensive potential
weaknesses: Inconsistent jump shot • Prone to turnovers • Needs to add strength
awards: First-team All- SEC (2017), SEC All-Freshman Team (2017), SEC tournament MVP ( 2017 ), McDonald's All-American (2016), Jordan Brand Classic MVP (2016)
post draft awards: NBA All-Star ( 2023 ), All-NBA Third Team ( 2023 ), NBA steals leader ( 2024 ), NBA Clutch Player of the Year ( 2023 )
analysis: Fox is the perfect player to take over this young Kings team. He's tough, aggressive, hardworking on the defensive end and a leader on and off the court. The Kings are looking for a culture-changer and I think Fox can deliver. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Exceptional size and fluidity for a wing • Promising shooter with high potential • Strong rebounding and defensive capabilities
weaknesses: Lacks physical strength and toughness • Inconsistent shooter and ball handler • Struggles with interior physicality and positioning
awards: ACC All-Freshman team (2017)
analysis: Isaac fits the mold of players whom new front office executives Jeff Weltman and John Hammond have loved in the past. He's a long, athletic, multi-positional forward who can score in a lot of different ways and defend multiple positions. I think he has as much upside as Fultz and Ball. He's a project, but he's worth it. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite shooter with size and mobility • High basketball IQ and efficient play • Strong off-ball movement and mechanics
weaknesses: Defensive skills significantly lacking • Struggles with physicality and rebounding • Limited offensive game beyond shooting
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, NABC, SN ( 2017 ), First-team All-Pac-12 (2017), Pac-12 All-Freshman team (2017)
post draft awards: NBA All-Star ( 2023 ), NBA Most Improved Player ( 2023 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2018 ), Finnish Athlete of the Year (2023), 7× Finnish Player of the Year (2017–2023)
analysis: Markkanen may be the best shooter in the draft. With Nikola Mirotic hitting restricted free agency, Markkanen could be a bigger, better-shooting replacement at the 4. I like the Kris Dunn, Zach LaVine and Markkanen rebuild. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite size and athleticism for a point guard • Excellent passer with great court vision • Versatile and potential lockdown defender
weaknesses: Needs to add muscle and strength • Inconsistent long-range shooter • Struggles with physical play and contact
awards: 2× Pro A Best Young Player ( 2016, 2017 ), FIBA Europe Under-18 Championship MVP ( 2016 )
analysis: I think Ntilikina has major upside. He has a huge wingspan and great court vision, and has already been a starting PG in the French league finals. He needs to continue to improve his jump shot, but he could be really good down the road. The Knicks needed a point guard, hopefully one who can grow alongside Kristaps Porzingis if he remains in New York. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Explosive first step and elite athleticism • Exceptional ball-handling and finishing ability at the rim • Quick playmaker with vision in transition
weaknesses: Inconsistent jump shooting from midrange and beyond • Turnover-prone decision-making under pressure • Durability concerns due to playing style
awards: ACC Rookie of the Year (2017), Second-team All-ACC (2017), ACC All-Freshman team (2017)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2018 )
analysis: He's not a perfect fit for the Mavs, but they were blown away by his workout. He's quite possibly the best athlete in the draft. He has the potential to be an explosive scorer. His lack of size and length are issues, but the Mavs decided to gamble on his upside. If Smith pans out, he could form a formidable young big three with Harrison Barnes and Nerlens Noel. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent size and mobility • Versatile offensive skills • Strong defender and shot blocker
weaknesses: Limited playing time in college • Needs to improve free throw accuracy • Struggles against double teams
awards: Second-team All- WCC (2017), WCC All-Freshman Team (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 )
analysis: Collins is a great fit with the Blazers. They've been looking for an upgrade at the 4 who can both stretch the floor and protect the rim. They've tried several players, but none of them has the upside of Collins. He needs to get stronger, but he was worth No. 15 and No. 20. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Explosive scorer with great shooting touch • Strong in transition and open floor • Solid lateral quickness and defensive potential
weaknesses: Struggles defending bigger guards • Not comfortable as primary ball handler • Low free throw rate and inside scoring
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2017 ), Jerry West Award (2017), SEC Player of the Year – AP (2017), First-team All- SEC (2017), SEC Freshman of The Year (2017), SEC All-Freshman Team (2017), McDonald's All-American (2016), Mr. Basketball of Arkansas (2016)
analysis: Monk is the most explosive scorer in the draft. He's going to be instant offense off the bench behind Kemba Walker and Nicolas Batum. I think he's been a bit undervalued in this class. This is a very good fit for him. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Crafty scorer with high basketball IQ • Excellent shooter, effective off screens • Strong development and leadership at Duke
weaknesses: Lacks explosive athleticism • Short wingspan for his position • Struggled defensively against quicker players
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2017 ), First-team All-ACC (2017), ACC tournament MVP ( 2017 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2015 ), First-team Parade All-American (2015), 2× Ohio Mr. Basketball (2014, 2015)
analysis: Kennard is one of the two or three best shooters in the draft and the Pistons really wanted more perimeter touch. He's also tough, can play some point and has great leadership qualities. He's a good fit for the Pistons at No. 12. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Explosive athleticism and speed • Versatile scorer and defender • Improved perimeter shooting
weaknesses: Struggles finishing with left hand • Inconsistent playmaking and vision • Streaky shooter with poor shot selection
awards: First-team All-ACC (2017)
post draft awards: 6× NBA All-Star ( 2020 – 2025 ), All-NBA Second Team ( 2023 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2018 ), NBA Slam Dunk Contest champion ( 2018 )
analysis: Mitchell gives the Jazz more toughness and versatility in their backcourt. Most importantly, they were looking for an athlete who can defend both backcourt positions. He's got major upside and the Jazz had really cooled on Trey Lyles after a disappointing sophomore season. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite athlete with great size • Versatile and effective defender • Strong finisher at the rim
weaknesses: Struggles with free throw shooting • Lacks advanced basketball IQ • Limited offensive skill set
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2017), SEC All-Freshman team (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), North Carolina Mr. Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: 3× NBA All-Star ( 2020, 2023, 2024 ), NBA All-Defensive First Team ( 2024 ), 4× NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2020 – 2023 )
analysis: Adebayo is a super-athletic big man with great feet. His ability to guard three spots on the floor at his size is his biggest strength and was part of the appeal to the Heat, who had a hole to fill at the 4. His offensive game looked raw at Kentucky, but he has enough upside to justify this pick. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Big game experience and clutch performer • Versatile and efficient scorer • Strong defensive communicator
weaknesses: Lacks elite athleticism and explosiveness • Struggles with physicality and strength • Inconsistent shooter and ball handler
awards: NCAA champion ( 2017 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2017 ), ACC Player of the Year (2017), First-team All-ACC (2017), ACC All-Freshman team (2015), No. 44 honored by North Carolina Tar Heels, McDonald's All-American Game co-MVP ( 2014 ), First-team Parade All-American (2014)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2021 ), All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2022 )
analysis: The Kings got their point guard of the future with their first pick, now they get a Rudy Gay replacement at the 3 with Jackson. Teams are drafting him for his shooting, but I think he's streakier than his reputation. This is the first pick that I don't really like in the draft. I would've grabbed OG Anunoby here. He would've added a lot more toughness and defense. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Explosive leaper with quick second jump • Effective finisher, great in transition • Can defend guards, versatile defensively
weaknesses: Needs to develop physical strength • Prone to turnovers, especially under pressure • Free throw shooting needs improvement
awards: Big East Rookie of the Year (2017), Second-team All-Big East (2017)
analysis: Patton is raw, but there is a lot of upside there. The Wolves obviously already have an incredible big man in Karl-Anthony Towns, but down the road, Patton could probably play on the floor with him. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Explosive scorer in big moments • Fluid movement and transition play • Effective perimeter and post skills
weaknesses: Settles for contested jumpers • Lacks physicality and toughness • Needs improved defensive awareness
post draft awards: CBA Club Cup champion (2025)
analysis: Wilson is a bit of a surprise here. He stretches the floor and he's a great athlete, but he's got a reputation for being soft in the paint. His ability to guard on the perimeter was the big appeal for the Bucks. I think they reached, but the upside is clear. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Versatile offensive skillset • High basketball IQ and motor • Effective rebounder
weaknesses: Lacks physical strength • Struggles to finish through contact • Limited defensive presence in post
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2017 ), Pac-12 All-Freshman team (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 )
analysis: The Pacers wanted a skilled scorer to put on the floor with Myles Turner at the 4. Leaf is one of the best scorers in the draft. He's a defensive liability, but the Pacers hope that they can use Turner to hide him some. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Highly effective interior scorer • Excellent rebounder and leaper • Strong defensive presence
weaknesses: Limited offensive range • Prone to fouling • Needs defensive fundamentals
awards: First-team All-ACC (2017), ACC Most Improved Player (2017)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2018 )
analysis: With Dwight Howard gone and Paul Millsap likely to follow as a free agent this summer, the Hawks needed size. Collins can play both the 4 and the 5. He's a good rebounder, a solid shot blocker and has an emerging perimeter game. He's also the youngest sophomore in the draft. There's good value here at No. 19. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Exceptional athleticism and leaping ability • Versatile defender with good lateral quickness • Strong physical presence in the post
weaknesses: Significant injury history with multiple surgeries • Limited offensive skill set and poor shooting • Struggles with decision-making and consistency
analysis: Giles is headed to the Kings via a trade with the Blazers. I love this pick for the Kings. I thought Giles was worth a pick from No. 10 on. He has as much upside as anyone in the draft. With De'Aaron Fox, Giles, Skal Labissiere and Buddy Hield in Sacramento, I love the Kings' young core. Not as sold on Jackson, but if he hits shots, they'll be a very good team down the road. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Electrifying athleticism and leaping ability • Strong spot-up shooter with quick release • Good lateral quickness and defensive potential
weaknesses: Struggles with physical strength and bulk • Limited ball handling and creation skills • Inconsistent shooter, poor free throw percentage
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2016 )
post draft awards: NBA G League champion ( 2022 )
analysis: Ferguson was considered a top-10 prospect before he skipped Arizona to play pro ball in Australia. He's a very good (but streaky) shooter and athlete. The Thunder are always looking for wings who can stretch floor. He's not ready yet, but he's a good upside prospect. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Elite size and wingspan • Strong rebounding ability • Potential in pick and pop game
weaknesses: Struggles with lateral quickness • Post play slow and robotic • Vulnerable to being stripped in lane
awards: Third-team All- Big 12 (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Star ( 2022 )
analysis: Allen is an upside guy who runs the floor, blocks shots and rebounds, but he needs to add strength and offensive polish. With Brook Lopez off to the Lakers, the Nets needed to start grooming a young big. His mobility is really appealing. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent defensive potential with versatility • Strong rebounder and finisher at the rim • Good lateral speed and wingspan
weaknesses: Undefined offensive role • Inconsistent intensity and effort • Needs improvement in shot creation and mechanics
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2019 ), NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2023 ), NBA steals leader ( 2023 )
analysis: I love this pick for Toronto. The Raptors love tough, defensively-minded players who can guard multiple positions and stretch the floor. Anunoby might be better at that than anyone in the draft. He slid because of concerns about his ACL injury, but when he's healthy, this will be a steal for the Raptors. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent shooter with range • Good athleticism and leaping ability • Effective in post and midrange
weaknesses: Limited conventional defensive skills • Needs to add strength and weight • Questionable desire and toughness
analysis: Lydon is an interesting prospect and fits the Nuggets' need for a player who can defend and shoot from both forward positions. He needs to get stronger and at times he can be passive, but there's a lot of upside here. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Exceptional 7’2” frame with expanding muscle mass • Fluid mobility and coordination for his size • Offensive versatility as a face-up screener with shooting touch
weaknesses: Needs significant strength to handle NBA physicality • Limited defensive footwork and awareness • Slow shot release as a stretch big
awards: 3× LBL champion (2012, 2013, 2015), Spanish Supercup champion (2016), Spanish League All-Young Players Team ( 2017 )
analysis: Pasečņiks is a very skilled big man who thrives more as a face-the-basket big. He's had a great season in Europe. I suspect the Sixers will stash him, but he's great value here. -- Chad Ford

strengths: High basketball IQ and versatile skills • Excellent rebounder and passer • Strong outside shooter and free throw accuracy
weaknesses: Lacks explosiveness and speed • Struggles with perimeter defense • Limited by physical fitness and athleticism
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2017 ), Pete Newell Big Man Award (2017), Lute Olson Award (2017), Big Ten Player of the Year (2017), First-team All- Big Ten (2017), Big Ten All-Freshman team (2016), McDonald's All American ( 2015 ), First-team Parade All-American (2015), Indiana Mr. Basketball (2015)
analysis: Swanigan is one of the most skilled big men in the draft. If he stays in great shape, he can stretch the floor and bang in the paint. The Blazers are clearly shoring up their frontcourt with him and Zach Collins. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent agility and footwork at 6'9" • Strong rebounder and transition player • Effective scorer on the move
weaknesses: Inconsistent intensity and focus • Needs to improve ball handling • Struggles with shot selection and efficiency
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 (2017)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2020 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2018 )
analysis: Kuzma feels a bit like a stretch. A very good performance at the draft combine really helped his stock. He can defend and during the combine he shot the ball well. The Lakers can use both of those things, but I saw higher upside picks still on the board. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Impressive 7'4" wingspan and solid fundamentals • Good composure and high basketball IQ • Versatile scorer with either hand
weaknesses: Lacks great explosiveness and athleticism • Struggles against like-sized players • Needs to develop more offensive variety
awards: NCAA champion ( 2017 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), Florida Mr. Basketball (2016)
analysis: Bradley was one of the more underrated prospects in the draft. He's a great rebounder, and when he gets in better shape, I think he'll show more athleticism. The Jazz need a long-term answer as a backup to Rudy Gobert. Bradley is a good get here. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Versatile scorer from all three levels • Excellent size and passing vision • Strong defensive instincts and versatility
weaknesses: Lacks burst and shiftiness • Struggles against higher competition • Inconsistent defensive effort and focus
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 (2017), 2× NCAA Division II All-American (2014, 2015), 2× First-team All- RMAC (2014, 2015), RMAC tournament MVP (2015), RMAC Freshman of the Year (2013)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2024 ), 2× NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2023, 2024 ), NBA G League champion (2018)
analysis: White was another darling at the draft combine. He's an athletic guard who can play and defend both positions in the backcourt. With Tony Parker aging and Manu Ginobili likely to retire, they really needed depth in their backcourt. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Improved scoring and efficiency • High basketball IQ and passing ability • Strong rebounding for a guard
weaknesses: Lacks explosive athleticism • Limited ball handling skills • Perceived limited upside
awards: NCAA champion ( 2016 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2017 ), Third-team All-American – NABC ( 2016 ), Senior CLASS Award (2017), Julius Erving Award (2017), Big East Player of the Year (2017), Big East Co-Defensive Player of the Year (2017), 2× First-team All-Big East (2016, 2017), Big East Sixth Man of the Year (2015), Big East All-Freshman Team (2014), 2× Big East tournament MOP ( 2015, 2017 ), Robert V. Geasey Trophy (2017), No. 3 retired by Villanova Wildcats
analysis: Hart is the only senior to be selected in the first round. He's not a sexy pick, but he does just about everything well. He has a great feel and plays hard. He also shoots and passes well. He just lacks great athleticism or size for his position. With D'Angelo Russell and Nick Young gone, the Lakers needed some help here. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent scoring ability and athleticism • Strong physical build for guard positions • High energy and good motor
weaknesses: Undefined position and role • Low assist numbers for a PG • Limited defensive capabilities
awards: McDonald's All-American Co-MVP ( 2016 ), Utah Mr. Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2023 )
analysis: Jackson's recent foot surgery slowed his movement up draft boards, but there's a lot to like. He is super athletic, plays both backcourt positions and shoots it well. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Versatile with good size and length • Consistent outside shooter • Strong defensive player
weaknesses: Struggles to create own offense • Not an elite-level athlete • Limited offensive skill set beyond shooting
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2017)
analysis: Reed was the No. 57 ranked prospect coming into the draft as well as the No. 53 prospect by Kevin Pelton's statistical projections. He was a reliable 3-point shooter during his four years at Miami. -- Kevin Pelton

weaknesses: Limited jump shooting ability • Struggles with NBA three-point range • Not exceptional in any one skill
awards: 2× Third-team All- Big 12 (2016, 2017)
analysis: Iwundu is a versatile forward who can defend multiple positions, see the floor and stretch the court. He needs to add strength and improve his consistency. -- Chad Ford

strengths: High basketball IQ with elite decision-making • Competitive scoring guard with solid midrange game • Tenacious defender with quick hands
weaknesses: Undersized and limited NBA physical profile • Questionable shooting consistency from three • May struggle creating offense against length
awards: National college player of the year ( 2017 ), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2017 ), Bob Cousy Award (2017), Big 12 Player of the Year (2017), First-team All- Big 12 (2017), 2× Second-team All-Big 12 (2015, 2016), Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2016)

analysis: If Mason were three to four inches taller, he might be a lottery pick. Super tough, fast and devastating both at the rim and shooting from 3-point territory, he was a legit NCAA player-of-the-year candidate all season. Most NBA scouts don't really love little guards, but Mason's game fits the profile of the smaller guards who do succeed in the NBA. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Excellent rebounder with great instincts • Agile and mobile for his size • Effective post game and mid-range shooting

post draft awards: NBA G League Sportsmanship Award (2020)
analysis: Rabb looked like a potential lottery pick after a solid freshman season at Cal. He decided he wasn't ready for the NBA and surprised scouts with his decision to play another year of college. The thinking was that he'd get physically stronger and his offensive game would blossom. Unfortunately, neither really happened in a significant way. Still, he had a good season and showed improvement as a shooter. While scouts don't see a future superstar with Rabb, they do project him as a potential starter or solid rotation player who should be in the league a long time. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Versatile with high basketball IQ • Excellent in transition and shooting • Strong defender and rebounder
weaknesses: Needs to add upper body strength • Inconsistent free throw shooting • Struggles against physical defenders
awards: Israeli League Cup winner ( 2017 ), ABA League Top Prospect ( 2017 )
post draft awards: Israeli League champion ( 2018 )
analysis: Bolden is a versatile forward who can play multiple positions. He's a solid shooter and passer who can put the ball on the floor and makes good decisions on the court, though he needs to continue to add strength. -- Chad Ford

weaknesses: Undersized for traditional power forward • Needs improvement on defensive instincts • Limited experience against high-level competition

He's the type of player who looks as though he could make an impact right away. But his age (22), tweener status and poor defensive metrics make scouts pause. -- Chad Ford

strengths: Clutch performer in big games • Excellent three-point and free-throw shooter • Effective off screens and in transition

That's appealing to scouts. On the downside, his 2-point percentage plummeted, and his below-the-rim post game has scouts worried that Bryant's game might not fully translate to the NBA. -- Chad Ford

analysis: Sumner came into the season ranked by many scouts as a potential late-lottery to mid-first-round pick, but an ACL tear on Jan. 29 derailed things, and most scouts assumed — given the recovery time — that he'd return to Xavier for his junior season. With Sumner unlikely to play in the NBA next season, his chances of landing in the first round are pretty slim. However, the first-round talent is there, thanks to elite size, length and excellent athleticism for his position. His jump shot is still a major work in progress, and he can be turnover-prone. -- Chad Ford

analysis: The Suns have secured their center of the future with the No. 1 pick. Ayton is physically ready to step in right away and be a significant contributor for a team that has lacked an inside presence. His ability to improve his instincts defensively will play a large role in how quickly Phoenix is able to make another playoff push. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Terrific athlete with wing-like mobility • Elite offensive rebounder • Versatile inside-out scorer
weaknesses: Lacks wingspan compared to peers • Needs strength to handle contact • Inconsistent free-throw shooting

post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2019 )
analysis: From the moment they landed the No. 2 pick in the lottery, it was clear the Kings were locked in on Bagley as their big man of the future. He fills a massive hole at power forward, and he's going to be an instant contributor on offense. His scoring ability, athleticism and rebounding prowess should look great alongside De'Aaron Fox. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Versatile guard/forward with high basketball IQ • Natural leader, excels under pressure • Elite passer with great court vision
weaknesses: Struggles with athletic explosiveness • Inconsistent three-point shooter • Defensive limitations against quicker opponents

analysis: The Mavs traded a future first-round pick to the Hawks to move up and take Doncic here. The Mavs needed another ball handler alongside Dennis Smith Jr., and they got one. Doncic's basketball IQ, ballhandling and creativity will be great fits under head coach Rick Carlisle. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Exceptional physical and athletic profile • Versatile offensive skills • Strong defensive potential
weaknesses: Needs increased strength and muscle • Prone to foul trouble • Offensive game lacks polish

analysis: The Grizzlies viewed this as a four-player draft and will be happy to end up with Jackson. His perimeter shooting prowess and mobility should allow him to play right away alongside Marc Gasol while also logging time as a backup center. He's a great, young building block regardless of the direction the organization goes with Gasol and Mike Conley. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Averages nearly 30 points and nine assists • Threat to score from anywhere on court • Advanced pick and roll operation
weaknesses: Lacks ideal size and length • Prone to risky turnovers • Defensive liability on the court
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2018 ), Wayman Tisdale Award (2018), NCAA scoring champion (2018), NCAA assists leader (2018), First-team All- Big 12 (2018), Big 12 Freshman of the Year (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
post draft awards: 4× NBA All-Star ( 2020, 2022, 2024, 2025 ), All-NBA Third Team ( 2022 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2019 ), NBA assists leader ( 2025 )
analysis: Atlanta ownership was able to compromise with its front office and land a future first-round pick in exchange for moving back two spots to land Trae Young. Young brings shotmaking, pick-and-roll prowess, passing and — most importantly — star quality. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Elite rim protector with impressive wingspan • Good lateral quickness and rebounding ability • Developing offensive skills and free throw shooting
weaknesses: Needs to add strength for NBA play • Offensive awareness and aggression lacking • Relies more on length than explosiveness
place of birth: New York City , New York, U.S.
awards: Second-team All- Big 12 (2018), Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2018), Big 12 All-Newcomer Team (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
analysis: The Magic wanted Trae Young to fall here, but the Mavericks-Hawks trade forced Orlando to alter its plans. The Magic will still be very happy to have ended up with Mohamed Bamba, whom many feel has the potential to be the best player in this draft. He's going to fit in nicely with the length and athleticism of Aaron Gordon and Jonathan Isaac. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Powerful and efficient finisher in traffic • High-level rebounder on both ends • Face-up four with shooting range
weaknesses: Average lateral quickness • Needs to improve shot creation • Defensive timing not yet refined
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2018), ACC All-Freshman Team (2018), Morgan Wootten National Player of the Year (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
analysis: Chicago picks up a big center who can slide in right next to Lauri Markkanen's finesse game up front. He has excellent hands and touch around the basket, and his shot-blocking prowess will fit in nicely with the Bulls. They explored some trade scenarios to move up, but the Atlanta-Dallas trade prevented that from happening. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Dynamic guard with versatile scoring ability • Excels in high-pressure situations • Strong, athletic, and plays through contact
weaknesses: Needs to improve off-ball movement • Inconsistent shooting balance • Prone to forcing plays and poor shot selection
awards: SEC Freshman of the Year (2018), Second-team All- SEC (2018), SEC All-Freshman Team (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 ), FIBA Under-17 World Cup MVP ( 2016 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2019 )
analysis: The Cavs opted for Sexton after Michael Porter Jr.’s medical report tempered their interest. Sexton brings the type of athleticism, aggressiveness and toughness the Cavs have sorely lacked in a secondary ball handler. Even if LeBron stays, Sexton will help with scoring instincts, competitiveness and defense. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Versatile scoring wing with stretch ability • Explosive first step to rim • Strong three-point shooter
weaknesses: Inconsistent shot selection • Raw playmaking instincts • Defensive fundamentals need polish
awards: First-team All- SEC (2018), SEC Freshman of the Year (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 ), Florida Mr. Basketball (2017)
analysis: The Knicks zeroed in on Kevin Knox a few weeks back and never looked back. His physical gifts, shooting touch and defensive potential make him an intriguing fit alongside Kristaps Porzingis in a modern frontcourt. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Elite length and athleticism • High-efficiency 3-point shooter • Strong defensive capabilities
weaknesses: Lacks physical strength • Limited isolation skills • Needs to improve playmaking
awards: 2× NCAA champion ( 2016, 2018 ), Third-team All-American – AP, SN, NABC ( 2018 ), Julius Erving Award (2018), First-team All-Big East (2018), Second-team All-Big East (2017), Big East Co-Defensive Player of the Year (2017), Big East tournament MVP ( 2018 )

analysis: After being selected at No. 10 by Philadelphia, Bridges was traded to Phoenix for the draft rights to Zhaire Smith and a 2021 first-round pick. In Phoenix, Bridges will bring reliable catch-and-shoot 3-point shooting to the Devin Booker–Deandre Ayton pick-and-roll. Plus, he and Josh Jackson can combine for a scary defensive wing tandem in time. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent height and length for guard • Strong defensive skills and effort • High shooting percentages at Kentucky
weaknesses: Needs to add strength • Can stagnate offense holding ball too long • Prone to forcing plays and turnovers
awards: Second-team All- SEC ( 2018 ), SEC All-Freshman Team (2018), SEC tournament MVP ( 2018 )
post draft awards: 3× NBA All-Star ( 2023 – 2025 ), 2× All-NBA First Team ( 2023, 2024 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2019 ), NBA scoring champion ( 2025 ), Lionel Conacher Award (2023)
analysis: The Hornets traded this pick to the Clippers in exchange for the 12th pick (Miles Bridges) and two second-round picks. The Clippers have long coveted the size, length and multi-positional versatility offered by Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, and they were able to secure a trade with Charlotte on draft night to get him to LA. He's an interesting fit with a smaller combo guard like Lou Williams who usually struggles to find a defensive matchup on most nights. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Versatile two-way wing player • NBA-ready frame and explosiveness • High-level rebounder and clutch performer
weaknesses: Limited ball handling skills • Undersized for forward positions • Lacks a mid-range game
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2018 ), First-team All- Big Ten (2018), Second-team All-Big Ten (2017), Big Ten Freshman of the Year (2017), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2017), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2016)
analysis: Originally selected by the Clippers at No. 12, Bridges was sent to Charlotte in the Shai Gilgeous-Alexander swap. The Hornets passed up the opportunity to pair Shai with Malik Monk, instead preferring to add the powerful athleticism of Miles Bridges. His length, shooting potential and defensive pedigree fit the mold the Hornets covet. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent shooter with clean release • Strong off-ball player and ball handler • Good at creating shots off the dribble
weaknesses: Older than typical first-round prospects • Lacks elite first step and explosiveness • Needs to improve isolation skills
awards: First-team All-ACC (2018)
analysis: The Clippers fell in love with Jerome Robinson early in the process and will pair him with Shai Gilgeous-Alexander in an intriguing modern backcourt. The two complement each other's strengths and weaknesses fairly well. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Smooth shooting stroke from deep • Advanced scoring instincts • High basketball IQ and vision
weaknesses: Injury history raises durability concerns • Lacks defensive consistency • Not a strong isolation defender
awards: National high school player of the year (2017), McDonald's All-American MVP ( 2017 ), Washington Mr. Basketball (2017)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Michael Porter's long night ended mercifully with the Nuggets selecting him at the tail end of the lottery. Denver was happy to absorb any risk associated with his health status in exchange for the sheer talent and long-term upside offered by the former projected No. 1 pick. The Nuggets have the luxury of bringing Porter along slowly and potentially even “redshirting” him his rookie year. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Versatile 3-and-D wing • Excellent decision-maker and passer • High-level on-ball defender
weaknesses: Below-average explosiveness • Inconsistent catch-and-shoot rhythm • Needs greater strength on drives
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
analysis: The Wizards searched for depth in the backcourt all season, as their bench units were highly inconsistent. Troy Brown's ability to play anywhere from 1 to 4, along with his unselfishness, basketball IQ and defensive versatility, are attractive. He's one of the youngest players in the draft, and thus has potential to grow if he can find a way to become a more consistent shooter. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: High basketball IQ and court awareness • Versatile and athletic wing player • Strong defensive instincts and effort
weaknesses: Offensive skills still developing • Inconsistent three-point shooter • Needs better ball-handling skills
awards: Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2018), Big 12 All-Newcomer Team (2018)
analysis: Zhaire Smith had two excellent workouts in Philadelphia, piquing the 76ers' interest with his combination of length, athleticism, toughness and defensive versatility. It's an interesting move to trade local Villanova product Miles Bridges for a fairly unknown prospect in Zhaire Smith. It's a bold move for a front office without a GM. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent scorer and versatile defender • High basketball IQ and clutch performer • Strong athleticism and team player
weaknesses: Inconsistent shooting at times • Struggles defensively against bigger players • Unclear leadership and primary role

post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2021 )
analysis: The Bucks have been looking for a two-way combo guard who can make shots and bring toughness. Donte DiVincenzo looks like one of the more ready players to come in and play a role immediately alongside Giannis Antetokounmpo. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Good length with 6’9” wingspan • Explosive scoring with pull-up jumper • Smooth off-ball movement and spacing

analysis: The Spurs potentially get one of the biggest steals in the draft in Lonnie Walker, an athletic freak with terrific shot-making ability both with his feet set and off the dribble. Concerns about his health were overblown, according to NBA teams with which ESPN spoke. There might not be a better player for Walker to prove teams wrong, as he will be surrounded by an elite culture, coaching staff and player-development structure. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent perimeter shooter • Good size and athleticism • Effective facilitator and rebounder
weaknesses: Needs to add strength • Limited by wingspan defensively • Struggles with ball-handling and driving
awards: Mr. New York Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2019 )
analysis: After picking Trae Young as their point guard of the future, it makes sense for Atlanta to bring in a sharpshooting wing like Kevin Huerter. His addition will give the Hawks perhaps the most lethal shooting combination in the draft. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Explosive athlete with 7-foot wingspan • Solid scorer and free throw shooter • Strong rebounder and defender
weaknesses: Questionable feel for the game • Tendency to play out of control • Not a natural facilitator
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2018), ACC All-Freshman Team (2017)
analysis: The Wolves have been coveting wing depth all season, and they made a logical selection with Josh Okogie, who brings length, defensive versatility and budding shooting prowess. Younger than some freshmen who were selected, Okogie has significant potential to grow into a full-time role. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Pure shooter with solid rim attacks • Clutch performer with leadership qualities • High vertical and athletic ability
weaknesses: Older prospect with size concerns • Erratic behavior and discipline issues • Struggles against athletic defenders
awards: NCAA champion ( 2015 ), Second-team All-American – SN ( 2016 ), Third-team All-American – AP, NABC (2016), First-team All-ACC (2016), Third-team All-ACC (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2014 )
analysis: The Jazz desired a perimeter shooting combo guard to pair with the likes of Donovan Mitchell, Dante Exum and Ricky Rubio. They get one of the better marksmen in the draft in Grayson Allen. -- Jonathan Givony
