weaknesses: Needs to gain strength • Inconsistent scoring and ball handling • Lacks a mid-range game
awards: MW Player of the Year – Media (2018), 2× First-team All- MW (2017, 2018), MW All-Defensive Team (2018)
analysis: The Bulls promised Chandler Hutchison they would select him at No. 22 more than a month ago despite not being under much pressure of him possibly being picked higher. Encumbering their pick during the entire pre-draft process might have hurt their chances of moving up from the No. 7 pick, as they attempted to do repeatedly with Atlanta and Memphis. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Quick, penetrative guard with good finishing ability • Excellent in transition and decision-making • Strong three-level scoring capability
weaknesses: Small stature for NBA point guard • Needs to improve defensive screen navigation • High turnover rate needs addressing
awards: Third-team All-American – SN ( 2018 ), First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2018 ), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2018)
analysis: The Pacers were looking for a versatile guard who can play on and off the ball and a player they can groom long-term, as both Cory Joseph and Darren Collison enter the final years of their contracts. Holiday offers size, shooting and floor general instincts for Indiana’s backcourt. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent perimeter scorer • Strong free throw shooter • Good rebounder for position
weaknesses: Needs to improve playmaking skills • Lacks physical strength • Low assist-to-turnover ratio
post draft awards: NBA Slam Dunk Contest champion ( 2021 )
analysis: Anfernee Simons was the lone player the Trail Blazers brought in twice for a workout, and they obviously liked what they saw both times. He's an intriguing long-term prospect to groom between scoring guards Damian Lillard and C.J. McCollum, though he will likely require time in the G League to make up for not having played college basketball. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Great size and shooting ability • Effective in transition • Strong pick-and-pop skills
weaknesses: Struggles defensively against quicker players • Below average rebounder • Limited versatility and poor free throw shooting
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten ( 2018 ), Big Ten tournament MOP ( 2018 )
analysis: The Lakers found success in last year's draft by picking older and established college players with high skill levels and character. They continued along that same path this year by picking NCAA tournament darling Mo Wagner. With Brook Lopez’s contract expiring, there is certainly room on the roster for a shooting big man in his mold. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent decision-making and high basketball IQ • Versatile offensive player, effective on and off ball • Strong shooter, excels in pick-and-roll situations
weaknesses: Lacks explosive athleticism • Needs to develop physically for NBA • Defensive challenges against quicker players
awards: First-team All- AAC (2018), First-team All- MVC (2017), MVC Freshman of the Year (2017)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2019 ), NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 )
analysis: The Sixers went with the guard who complements Ben Simmons, as Landry Shamet is one of the better shooters in the draft and has the size to play either the 1 or 2. His feel for the game and ability to operate in a half-court setting will fit in nicely in Brett Brown’s system, giving him some added versatility to work with in the backcourt. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Athletic rim protector and shot-blocker • Excellent lob threat and finish • High-energy rebounder
weaknesses: Raw offensive polish • Poor free-throw shooting • Prone to foul trouble
awards: 2× SEC Defensive Player of the Year (2017, 2018), Second-team All-SEC (2017), SEC All-Freshman Team (2017), 2× SEC All-Defensive Team (2017, 2018)
post draft awards: NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2022 )
analysis: Danny Ainge does it again. The rich get richer, as the Celtics add the No. 12 player in the ESPN 100 all the way down at the 27th pick. Concerns about Williams' off-court habits and some question marks about his knee sank his stock, but this might end up being the steal of the draft. Williams' ability to protect the rim is something the Celtics covet, and he's now in a perfect situation to continue to develop his basketball IQ in one of the NBA's best cultures and player-development systems. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Elite defensive skills • Impressive size and wingspan • High basketball IQ
weaknesses: Inconsistent performance • Underwhelming rebounding • Needs to improve physical play
awards: First-team All- AAC (2018)
analysis: The Warriors fell in love with Jacob Evans' shooting, basketball IQ and defensive versatility through the season and pre-draft process. Evans' ability to play multiple positions is coveted in their positionless basketball structure, and the fact that he has three years of college under his belt might help him see minutes already next season for a team that lacked depth at times this past season. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Versatile multi-position player • High basketball IQ and scoring ability • Strong leadership and passion
weaknesses: Needs to improve physical strength • Inconsistent shooting and motor • Defensive focus and effectiveness lacking
awards: EuroCup Rising Star ( 2018 ), 3× Croatian League champion ( 2016 – 2018 ), 3× Croatian Cup winner (2016–2018), All-ABA League Team ( 2018 ), ABA League Top Prospect ( 2018 ), FIBA U16 EuroBasket MVP ( 2015 )

analysis: The Nets add one of the better scorers in the draft in Dzanan Musa, a player who was projected significantly higher for much of the season but ended up slipping due to his insistence on coming to the NBA right away as opposed to being stashed. Musa's scoring instincts, youth and competitiveness make him a prospect worth investing in. He has put up points in bunches in every setting he's played at every level. -- Jonathan Givony

strengths: Excellent three-point shooter • Strong rebounder and rim protector • Fits well in team concepts
weaknesses: Struggles with post footwork • Limited free throw efficiency • Can be predictable in half court
awards: NCAA champion ( 2018 ), Big East Rookie of the Year (2018)
post draft awards: EASL Champions Week champion (2023), EASL Champions Week MVP (2023), KBL champion (2023)
analysis: The Hawks complete the first round with Omari Spellman, a stretch big man who played a huge role in Villanova's national championship run. His shooting touch and ability to face the basket fill a need for Atlanta as they rebuild around Trae Young. -- Jonathan Givony

awards: LNB All-Star ( 2018 )
post draft awards: 3x LNB Pro A champion ( 2022 – 2024 ), French Cup winner (2023), LNB Pro A Finals MVP (2022), French Cup Final MVP (2023)
analysis: Okobo’s combination of deep shooting range, pick-and-roll savviness and improving playmaking provides valuable bench scoring and floor stability. -- Mike Schmitz

strengths: Two-time Big 12 Defensive Player • High level outside shooter • Strong primary ball handler
weaknesses: Struggles with length defensively • Limited upside due to age • Difficulty finishing at the rim

analysis: Graham’s clutch shooting, elite shot-creation off the bounce and system-driven passing numbers should translate into a reliable reserve point guard role. -- Mike Schmitz

weaknesses: Inconsistent perimeter shot • Raw playmaking instincts • Needs defensive fundamentals
awards: Second-team All- AAC (2018), AAC Most Improved Player (2018)
analysis: Frazier’s emergence as one of college basketball’s top perimeter defenders, combined with his growing offensive skill set, gives him high upside as a two-way wing. -- Mike Schmitz

weaknesses: Limited offensive skillset • Poor free throw shooting • Needs to improve basketball IQ
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2019 )
analysis: Robinson’s freakish length, rim-running ability and shot-blocking upside make him one of the biggest boom-or-bust prospects of the draft. -- Jonathan Givony

weaknesses: Lacks explosiveness and quickness • Inconsistent defender and effort • Limited playmaking and creativity
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2017 ), FIBA Americas Under-16 Championship MVP ( 2015 )
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2024 )

analysis: New Orleans has undergone one of the biggest reversals in fortune in league history over the past month, with the most important one being adding Zion Williamson to its incredible stable of assets at No. 1. The Pelicans will want to surround Williamson with shooting in a similar way to what the Bucks have done with Giannis Antetokounmpo, and that begins with their other top-10 pick coming up later tonight.

analysis: Memphis ushers in a new era by handing the keys of the franchise to Ja Morant, who will have every opportunity to learn the ropes on the job alongside one of the top rookies in the NBA last year in Jaren Jackson Jr. Morant's speed, playmaking ability and flair for the spectacular will help transform the Grizzlies overnight into one of the most entertaining teams to watch in the NBA on a nightly basis, even if it will likely take time for that to translate to the win column.

strengths: Strong finisher with crafty footwork • High basketball IQ and good court movement • Excellent in transition and open court speed
weaknesses: Inconsistent and slow outside shooting • Needs improvement in right-hand skills • Defensive effort off the ball is lacking
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2019 ), Jerry West Award (2019), First-team All-ACC (2019), ACC All-Freshman team (2019), National high school player of the year (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2018 ), FIBA U19 World Cup MVP ( 2017 )
analysis: The Knicks didn't seem completely sold on this pick from day one — like New Orleans and Memphis were at 1–2 — but they eventually settled in on the idea of drafting RJ Barrett, which seems like a match made in heaven. Barrett's shot-creation prowess, scoring instincts, killer mentality and willingness to embrace the spotlight should allow him to emerge as a Rookie of the Year candidate and eventual franchise player for the Knicks, who still have quite a bit of work left to do in their rebuilding process.

strengths: Versatile skill set and position flexibility • Strong body with a 7'2" wingspan • Excellent mid-range and 3pt shooter
weaknesses: Unclear elite skill for NBA level • Low steal and block rates • Rebounding numbers are low for his size
awards: NCAA champion ( 2019 ), Second-team All-American – NABC ( 2019 ), Third-team All-American – AP, USBWA, SN (2019), NABC Defensive Player of the Year (2019), First-team All-ACC (2019), ACC Defensive Player of the Year (2019), ACC Sixth Man of the Year (2018), ACC All-Freshman Team (2018)
analysis: The Hawks traded up to No. 4 to select De'Andre Hunter here. Atlanta was aggressively trying to trade up to ensure it got him, eventually using its huge stable of picks to get a deal done with New Orleans. Hunter's maturity, defensive versatility, 3-point shooting, national championship experience and strong frame should make him ready to step in from day one alongside Trae Young, John Collins and Kevin Huerter.

strengths: Great speed and court vision • Effective scorer and playmaker • Strong free throw shooter
weaknesses: Lacks physical strength • Prone to turnovers • Streaky outside shooter
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2018 ), 3× Tennessee Mr. Basketball (2016–2018)
post draft awards: 2× NBA All-Star ( 2022, 2025 )
analysis: On paper, the fit between Darius Garland and last year's top-10 pick, Collin Sexton, doesn't look seamless. Both players stand 6-foot-3 or shorter with lean frames, and both need the ball in their hands to be successful. However, teams have made a mistake in the past by picking for need over talent, especially at this stage of the draft. Garland has a strong case to be considered the fourth-most talented player in this class. In the meantime, the Cavaliers will play a Trail Blazers-style backcourt with plenty of shooting and pick-and-roll prowess.

strengths: Versatile size and solid athleticism • High basketball IQ and playmaking ability • Strong defensive instincts and rebounding
weaknesses: Needs to improve three-point shooting • Must tighten ball-handling skills • Physical strength needs enhancement
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2019 ), Big 12 Player of the Year (2019), First-team All- Big 12 (2019)
analysis: The Timberwolves traded up to No. 6 to select Jarrett Culver here. Minnesota didn't have to give up too much to move from 11 to 6, and the Timberwolves should like the fit of Culver with their existing backcourt of Jeff Teague and Tyus Jones — which should allow them to ease the Texas Tech product into playing both guard spots. Setting a culture is often the first thing a new NBA executive tries to do, and recently hired Timberwolves general manager Gersson Rosas will like the toughness, versatility and basketball IQ that Culver brings to the table.

strengths: Versatile, high-scoring guard • Quick first step and release • Effective scorer from all levels
weaknesses: Needs to improve as playmaker • Prone to turnovers • Struggles against physical defenders
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2019), ACC All-Freshman team (2019), North Carolina Mr. Basketball (2018), McDonald's All-American ( 2018 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2020 )
analysis: Chicago has a glaring hole at point guard and will be happy to see the draft's fourth-best guard sitting here at 7. Despite the fit, it's possible this could be viewed as somewhat of a reach down the road. No prospect in this draft was better positioned to succeed than Coby White at North Carolina, considering the situation he was in, but things might be a little different in the NBA. Nevertheless, the Bulls likely will put the ball in White's hands early and often, which should help his transition to the NBA, although efficiency might be an issue in the short term.

strengths: Elite rim protector with great size • High efficiency at finishing around the rim • Good free throw shooter for a big man
weaknesses: Needs to add muscle and toughness • Prone to committing fouls • Limited passing ability
awards: NIT champion ( 2019 ), Second-team All- Big 12 (2019), Big 12 Freshman of the Year (2019), Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2019)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2023 )
analysis: The Pelicans traded down to No. 8 to select Jaxson Hayes here. New Orleans was set to go into the season with only Jahlil Okafor under contract at center, which certainly would not have been ideal. That prompted the Pelicans to select the player most people viewed as the top center prospect in the draft, Jaxson Hayes, who will immediately make the New Orleans frontcourt one of the most athletic in the NBA.

strengths: Versatile skill set with strong mid-range shooting • Excellent length and athleticism • Strong work ethic and leadership qualities
weaknesses: Needs improvement in 1-on-1 skills • Undersized for power forward position • Inconsistent in high-pressure situations
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2019 ), Julius Erving Award (2019), WCC Player of the Year (2019), 2× First-team All- WCC (2018, 2019)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2023 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2020 )
analysis: The Wizards don't have much depth at the power forward position, with much of their frontcourt depth being diminished a year from now. This made drafting one of the safer prospects in the draft, Rui Hachimura, attractive here. His addition will give Washington another dimension, as his physical tools, scoring instincts and aggressiveness will fit in nicely with the roster.

strengths: Smooth shooting stroke with NBA range • Long, versatile wing defender • Strong off-ball movement and cutting
weaknesses: Inconsistent aggression and playmaking • Needs to add strength to finish through contact • Questionable defensive consistency
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2018 ), Mr. Pennsylvania Basketball (2018)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2023 )
analysis: The Hawks continue to add multi-positional forwards to the roster after drafting De'Andre Hunter with the fourth pick. Cam Reddish's talent is undeniable, and at this stage in the draft, that makes him worth taking a flier on, especially since he won't be called upon to do too much in terms of shot creation, which should accentuate his strengths. Reddish and Hunter form an intriguing forward combination, and they are excellent fits alongside the pick-and-roll passing prowess of Trae Young — all of which should generate quite a few open looks.

strengths: High basketball IQ and hustle • Versatile defender across multiple positions • Effective open-court runner
weaknesses: Limited scoring upside • Below-average outside shooting • Needs to add strength
awards: First-team All-ACC (2019)
analysis: The Suns traded down to No. 11 to select Cameron Johnson here. The Suns made the first truly shocking move of the night by reaching significantly for the oldest player in the draft in UNC's 23-year-old Cameron Johnson. History will judge whether the Suns got enough value here or whether they could have dropped down 10 spots or so and picked up other assets.

strengths: Versatile and skilled offensive player • Strong body suited for NBA physicality • High basketball IQ and leadership qualities
weaknesses: Lacks ideal size for NBA power forward • Needs to improve perimeter skills • Limited defensive impact potential
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, NABC, USBWA, SN ( 2019 ), First-team All- SEC ( 2019 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2020 )
analysis: Charlotte has a need at the power forward position, with much of its frontcourt depth being diminished a year from now. That made drafting one of the safer prospects in the draft, PJ Washington, attractive here. Washington can play either the power forward or center positions with his strong frame, long arms and ability to step outside and make 3-pointers. He looks like a solid building block for the Hornets to add to their roster at this stage of the draft.

strengths: Excels at creating own shot • High free throw accuracy • Effective in transition play
weaknesses: Struggles with footwork off screens • Limited ball handling skills • Lacks ideal NBA body size
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2019), SEC Newcomer of the Year (2019), SEC All-Freshman Team (2019)
post draft awards: NBA All-Star ( 2025 ), NBA Sixth Man of the Year ( 2022 ), NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2020 ), NBA Three-Point Contest champion ( 2025 )
analysis: Miami's backcourt is highly unsettled from a long-term perspective, which makes drafting a combo guard such as Tyler Herro an attractive proposition. His ability to play off the likes of Josh Richardson and Justise Winslow with his deadly jump shot should allow Herro to get on the court early in his career. As he continues to mature, Herro should be able to develop into more of a ball handler and playmaker, as he has significant potential operating in the pick-and-roll, shooting off the dribble and creating for others.

strengths: Aggressive rim attacker with size and quickness • Excellent in transition and rebounding • Good facilitator with high court awareness
weaknesses: Inconsistent intensity and engagement • Poor three-point and free throw shooter • Prone to questionable decision-making and turnovers
awards: Second-team All- Big Ten ( 2019 ), Big Ten All-Freshman team  (2019), McDonald's All-American ( 2018 ), Indiana Mr. Basketball (2018), Indiana Gatorade Player of the Year (2018)
analysis: Celtics coach Brad Stevens had told colleagues in the lead-up to the draft that he was enamored with Romeo Langford, as he was very familiar with the Indiana product since both grew up in the Hoosier State. Langford was one of the most hyped players in Indiana high school basketball history, which likely helped quite a bit in masking his somewhat disappointing freshman season, which was hampered by a wrist injury. Langford falls into an ideal situation, in which he will be asked to utilize his intriguing ballhandling and playmaking ability in a variety of different roles and positions on a Boston roster that is in quite a bit of flux at the moment.

strengths: Great defensive potential and versatility • Excellent athleticism and size • Effective in transition and as a slasher
weaknesses: Lacks basketball fundamentals and IQ • Struggles with decision making and turnovers • Limited offensive skills in half-court
awards: Pro B Best Young Player ( 2018 )
post draft awards: NBA G League champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Detroit stopped the minor fall of Sekou Doumbouya, making him the first non-collegiate international player drafted. It will be intriguing to see how Doumbouya is utilized in Detroit with Blake Griffin under contract, as there might not be too many minutes available for Doumbouya early on at his natural position of power forward. As the youngest player in this draft class — Doumbouya won't turn 19 until late December — the Pistons can afford to be patient with his development.

strengths: High basketball IQ and versatile forward skillset • Excellent midrange and three-point shooting • Strong rebounding for size
weaknesses: Injury concerns (ACL) • Limited athletic explosiveness • Needs to improve defensive lateral quickness
awards: Mr. Georgia Basketball (2017)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2025 ), NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Orlando wasn't daunted by Chuma Okeke likely missing most or all of the 2019–20 campaign after tearing his ACL in March, adding him to its stable of forwards that includes Jonathan Isaac and Aaron Gordon with an eye on the long term. Okeke going 16th with a torn ACL makes you wonder how high he might have gone had he not injured himself in the NCAA tournament. He is a prototype for the modern NBA with his chiseled frame and long arms combined with an ability to play pick-and-pop, make 3-pointers, switch onto big men and even provide some ballhandling at times.

strengths: Excellent shooter with quick release • High basketball IQ and decision-making • Versatile guard, comfortable in both positions
weaknesses: Lacks physical strength and explosiveness • Struggles to score in traffic • High turnover rate (2.9 per game)
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2019)
analysis: The Pelicans traded down to No. 18 to select Nickeil Alexander-Walker here. Alexander-Walker is at his best playing off another creator who can allow him to be a secondary ball handler and use his superior feel for the game, and he'll be able to do that playing alongside Lonzo Ball and Zion Williamson. In a draft devoid of shooting, Alexander-Walker certainly stands out with that part of his game, something the Pelicans went into this draft knowing they will need to add more of.

strengths: Good size and wingspan • Effective in post and pick n' roll • Strong rebounder and shot blocker
weaknesses: Lacks explosiveness and leaping ability • Inconsistent shooter, needs better finishing • Prone to emotional play and turnovers
awards: EuroLeague Rising Star ( 2019 ), Montenegrin Cup winner (2019), BLS Most Valuable Player ( 2019 ), ABA League MVP ( 2019 ), All-ABA League Team (2019), ABA League Top Prospect (2019), ABA League blocks leader (2019), Junior ABA League champion ( 2018 ), Junior ABA League MVP (2018), All-Junior ABA League Team (2018)
analysis: On paper, the fit here doesn't make a ton of sense, with Myles Turner and Domantas Sabonis already in the fold. But there's an argument to be made that Goga Bitadze is one of the better prospects on the board from a talent standpoint, something that has to be considered at this point in the draft. His size, skill, shot-blocking and ability to score from inside and out made him the likely second-best center in the draft.

strengths: Versatile offensive skillset • Good basketball IQ and mobility • Effective in open floor situations
weaknesses: Inconsistent motor and focus • Struggles against physical defense • Defensive positioning needs improvement
awards: FIBA Europe Under-18 Championship B MVP ( 2017 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2023 )
analysis: The Spurs have a long track record of drafting international players, and they decided to do it once again in picking Luka Samanic, one of the biggest standouts at this year's NBA combine. The Spurs have very little depth at the forward spots and might be able to spoon-feed minutes fairly early on to the Croatian player who is at an early stage of development physically and needs to continue to improve his skill level and basketball IQ.

strengths: Lock down defender with NBA potential • Good size and wingspan for a wing • Effective in disrupting passing lanes
weaknesses: Inconsistent offensive skills • Needs improvement in ball handling • Shooting accuracy regressed over time
awards: Naismith Defensive Player of the Year ( 2019 ), Lefty Driesell Award (2019), NCAA steals leader (2019), First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2019 ), 2× Pac-12 Defensive Player of the Year ( 2018, 2019), 2× Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2018, 2019)
post draft awards: 2× NBA All-Defensive Second Team ( 2021, 2022 )
analysis: The 76ers traded up to No. 20 to select Matisse Thybulle here. Matisse Thybulle was rumored to have a promise from the 76ers at No. 24, and it appears the Celtics snuffed that out and forced their hand in making a trade. The Sixers get arguably the best defender in this class in Thybulle, who broke every record in college basketball with his combination of blocks and steals.

strengths: Explosive scorer and rebounder • Elite shot-blocking ability • Strong defensive versatility
weaknesses: Lacks ideal size and strength • Inconsistent perimeter shooting • Needs to improve ball handling skills
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, SN ( 2019 ), First-team All- WCC (2019), WCC Defensive Player of the Year (2019), WCC Newcomer of the Year (2019), Mountain West Sixth Man of the Year (2016), First-team All-Mountain West (2017), Mountain West All-Defensive Team (2017)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2020 )
analysis: The Grizzlies traded up to No. 21 to select Brandon Clarke here. Memphis continues with its impressive moves after getting strong value for Mike Conley, then using one of those picks to acquire Brandon Clarke — an analytics favorite who will make for a fascinating pairing with Jaren Jackson Jr. and Ja Morant. The Grizzlies are building what appears to be one of the most athletic teams in the NBA.

strengths: Solid finisher, versatile scorer • Strong rebounder with 6'11" wingspan • High basketball IQ, good playmaker
weaknesses: Undersized for post play at 6'7" • Not an explosive athlete • Struggles with perimeter defense
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2019 ), 2× SEC Player of the Year – Coaches (2018, 2019), SEC Player of the Year – AP (2019), 2× First-team All- SEC (2018, 2019), SEC All-Freshman Team – Coaches (2017)
analysis: Boston has some major holes in the frontcourt to address with Al Horford likely departing, prompting the Celtics to select one of the most productive big men in college basketball in Tennessee's Grant Williams. Williams' toughness, basketball IQ and defensive versatility will fit right into what the Celtics wanted their culture to look like before things went off the rails for them, which might be one of the reasons they elected to add him to the fold.

strengths: Versatile forward with good length • Strong rebounder and defender • Effective scorer inside and out
weaknesses: Needs to improve game understanding • Inconsistent in half-court offense • Struggles with ball handling and turnovers
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2018 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2024 ), NBA G League All-Defensive Team (2024), NBA G League Next Up Game (2024)
analysis: The Thunder traded down to No. 23 to select Darius Bazley here. Bazley was one of the biggest risers of the pre-draft process, showing impressive talent at the NBA combine and in workouts at 6-foot-9 with his ability to handle, pass and shoot.

strengths: Ideal size and defensive versatility • Efficient shooter and passer • High basketball IQ and awareness
weaknesses: Lacks speed and athleticism • Struggles to create offensive separation • Needs to improve off-the-dribble shooting
place of birth: New York City, New York , U.S.
awards: NCAA champion ( 2019 ), Second-team All-ACC (2019), Third-team All-ACC (2018)
analysis: The Suns traded into No. 24 to select Ty Jerome here. The Suns clearly went into this draft looking to add experience and perimeter shooting, picking Cam Johnson at No. 11, then adding another player in that mold in national champion combo guard Ty Jerome. He is an intriguing fit in the backcourt alongside Devin Booker, who has developed his ballhandling and playmaking ability significantly.

strengths: Explosive finisher with quick first step • Excellent size and wingspan • Dynamic slasher and rebounder
weaknesses: Inconsistent freshman performance • Limited offensive creation skills • Needs improvement in basketball IQ
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2018 ), McDonald's All-American Game MVP (2018)
analysis: Portland ended the surprising slide of Nassir Little, a player who started the year in the top five of most mock drafts but ended up sliding to No. 25 on draft night. The Trail Blazers have a significant need for a player in Little's mold; Al-Farouq Aminu is entering free agency, and Mo Harkless is approaching the final year of his contract. Little's shredded frame, impressive athleticism and budding 3-point shooting will fit right into their roster while playing off the likes of Damian Lillard and CJ McCollum. Little also has significant upside to grow into.

strengths: Excellent long-range shooter • Strong rebounder for position • Good at using screens effectively
weaknesses: Needs to improve strength • Limited defensive impact • Close to developmental ceiling
awards: 2× First-team All- OVC (2018, 2019)
analysis: After adding another ball handler in Darius Garland at No. 5, the Cavs drafted a player who doesn't need the ball to be successful in Dylan Windler — considered one of the best perimeter shooters in this draft. Windler is the second player drafted in the first round from the Ohio Valley Conference, after Ja Morant.

strengths: Dominant scorer and rebounder • Excellent shot-blocking ability • Strong three-point shooter for size
weaknesses: Struggles with decision making • Limited ball-handling skills • Very foul prone
awards: ACC Sixth Man of The Year (2019)
post draft awards: All-EuroCup First Team ( 2025 ), EuroCup rebounding leader ( 2025 ), Greek All-Star (2023), NBA G League champion ( 2022 ), All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2023 ), NBA G League All-Defensive Team (2023)
analysis: The Clippers traded up to No. 27 to select Mfiondu Kabengele here. Florida State's Mfiondu Kabengele is a versatile big man who can score inside and out. Kabengele's ability to make 3-pointers should allow him to operate as a center alongside a power forward such as Danilo Gallinari or in bigger lineups with Montrezl Harrell, giving Kabengele nice lineup versatility.

strengths: Excellent long-range shooter • Strong ball handler and passer • Solid perimeter defender
weaknesses: Needs to add core strength • Prone to turnovers • Can improve playmaking ability
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2022 ), All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2021 )
analysis: Jordan Poole is a player with intriguing shot creation and perimeter shooting ability, something the Warriors might need a lot more than previously thought, considering the injuries to Kevin Durant and Klay Thompson. Poole will have to show better decision-making and defensive potential than he did at Michigan to earn minutes for the NBA finalists. But he does have some upside to grow into, thanks to his natural scoring instincts and all-around talent.

strengths: High basketball IQ and hustle • Versatile defender across multiple positions • Effective open-court runner
weaknesses: Limited scoring upside • Below-average outside shooting • Needs to add strength
awards: SEC Freshman of the Year – Coaches (2019), McDonald's All-American ( 2018 )
analysis: Keldon Johnson's surprising slide was halted by the Spurs, who always are on the lookout for toughness, perimeter shooting and defensive versatility. With very little depth at the small forward position, Johnson could push for minutes immediately, depending on which direction they head in free agency.

awards: Washington Mr. Basketball (2018)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League First Team ( 2021 ), NBA G League scoring leader ( 2021 ), NBA G League assists leader ( 2021 )
analysis: The Cavaliers traded up to No. 30 to select Kevin Porter Jr. here. With the last pick of the first round, the Cavs decided to roll the dice on the upside of Kevin Porter Jr., who was ranked as high as the top 10 during portions of the season but ended up tumbling significantly due to question marks about his intangibles and off-court approach. It will be interesting to see how Porter is utilized alongside two ball-dominant point guards in Darius Garland and Collin Sexton, as Porter struggled to make an impact at USC when he wasn't the focal point of the offense himself.

strengths: Elite shot-blocking and rim protection • Long frame and mobility for defensive versatility • Improved free-throw shooting for a big man
weaknesses: Needs to add strength and muscle • Below-average three-point shooting • Developing post moves
awards: Second-team All- SEC – Coaches (2019)
analysis: The Nets took a flier on the upside of big man Nic Claxton — who offers intriguing mobility, ballhandling and defensive versatility — with the No. 31 pick. Claxton was a late invite to the NBA draft green room but ended up sliding to the second round, likely due to his thin frame and average feel for the game. The Nets likely will give him plenty of minutes in the G League to try to shore up his perimeter shooting and decision-making skills, as he does have some potential to grow into as his frame matures.

strengths: Excellent size and athleticism for a wing • Improved 3-point shooter in sophomore year • Versatile defender across multiple positions
weaknesses: Struggles against quicker, aggressive players • Needs to improve defensive effort and physicality • Below average in blocking shots and steals
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2019 )
analysis: The Heat traded into No. 32 to select KZ Okpala here. KZ Okpala's somewhat surprising slide to the second round ended here with Miami, which will try to mold his intriguing size, length and ballhandling ability into a functional rotation player by developing his perimeter shooting, frame and basketball IQ. Okpala is a late bloomer who is on a different trajectory than most prospects in this draft and could benefit from added seasoning in the G League.

strengths: Elite scorer with deep range and clutch ability • High basketball IQ and pick-and-roll creator • Strong free-throw shooting
weaknesses: Limited size at 5'11" for NBA guard • Below-average defensive versatility • Needs to improve finishing through contact
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2019 ), NCAA Tournament South Region Most Outstanding Player ( 2019 ), Second-team All-American – NABC ( 2018 ), Third-team All-American – AP, SN (2018), Jerry West Award (2018), 2× First-team All- Big Ten ( 2018 , 2019 )
post draft awards: All-EuroLeague First Team ( 2025 ), Bundesliga champion ( 2024 ), German Cup winner ( 2024 ), Bundesliga Finals MVP (2024), NBA G League scoring champion ( 2022 )
analysis: The Celtics traded down to No. 33 to select Carsen Edwards here. The Celtics picked Carsen Edwards, one of the best shooters in this draft, with this pick that they extracted from the 76ers. Edwards put on one of the most impressive performances in NCAA tournament history against Virginia in the Elite Eight, and while not possessing prototypical size or court vision for a point guard, he has the type of athleticism, scoring instincts, range and confidence you look for at this stage of the draft.

strengths: Explosive finisher with great bounce • Excellent touch and shooting ability • Strong post moves and footwork
weaknesses: Offensive game still developing • Struggles against double teams • Limited shooting range beyond 12-15 feet
awards: First-team All- Big Ten ( 2019 ), Big Ten All-Defensive team ( 2019 ), Big Ten All-Freshman team ( 2018 )
analysis: The Hawks traded into No. 35 to select Bruno Fernando here. Fernando was considered one of the best big men prospects in this draft, thanks to his chiseled physique and improved skill level, but he ended up falling to the second round due to the diminishing value teams seem to be placing on traditional centers in his mold. The Hawks could develop him into a functional backup, as there are some things to like with his size, athleticism and motor.

The Pelicans traded into No. 35 to select Marcos Louzada Silva (better known as Didi) here. Brazilian wing Didi found a spot fairly high in the second round, after helping his draft stock significantly at the Nike Hoop Summit this spring. Didi's intensity level, solid perimeter-shooting stroke and defensive versatility give him a chance to develop into a potential 3-and-D rotation player for New Orleans.

strengths: Excellent defensive versatility with high basketball IQ • Reliable 3-point shooting for a forward • Strong playmaking and rebounding
weaknesses: Below-average athletic explosiveness for wing • Needs improved finishing consistency inside the paint • Inconsistent free-throw shooting
awards: Second-team All- Mountain West (2018), Third-team All-Mountain West (2019), Mountain West Defensive Player of the Year (2018)
analysis: Charlotte took a flier on long-armed, 6-foot-6 wing Cody Martin, a versatile player who saw quite a few minutes at point guard for Nevada and impressed with his defense and toughness.

strengths: Versatile with ideal size for a wing • High basketball IQ and excellent shooter • Can play multiple positions effectively
weaknesses: Below average athleticism for NBA • Limited defensive capabilities • Struggles to create separation
awards: King Mindaugas Cup winner (2019), Next Generation Tournament MVP (2018)
post draft awards: EuroCup Top Scorer ( 2024 ), All-EuroCup Second Team ( 2024 ), All-LKL Team ( 2024 )
analysis: Detroit traded into the No. 37 pick to select Lithuanian player Deividas Sirvydis, who they reportedly had promised with the No. 45 pick but decided not to take a risk on waiting for. Sirvydis has terrific size at 6-foot-9 and is one of the better perimeter shooters in this class, having just turned 19 years old recently.

strengths: Long, fluid, and agile bigman • Strong rebounder and rim protector • Consistent improvement in post scoring
weaknesses: Below average shooter • Struggles against quick perimeter guards • Needs to develop offensive skills
awards: First-team All- SEC ( 2019 ), SEC All-Defensive team ( 2019 ), SEC All-Freshman team ( 2018 ), Mr. Basketball of Arkansas (2017)
analysis: Chicago added some frontcourt depth with explosive Arkansas sophomore Daniel Gafford, another center who saw his stock fall during the pre-draft process due to the diminishing interest around the NBA in big men in this mold. Gafford is a bouncy athlete who could carve out a niche as a rim-running vertical spacer if his motor improves.

strengths: Versatile with high basketball IQ • Strong finisher with good footwork • Potential as a shooter and passer
weaknesses: Struggles with high-level competition • Inconsistent perimeter shooting • Below average lateral quickness
post draft awards: ABA League champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Golden State got the player it has been pursuing for the better part of three years in Serbian teenager Alen Smailagic, making two different trades in the second round to ensure it could select him. Many scouts questioned whether Smailagic's upside warranted the amount of attention that he received from the NBA finalists, who went to great lengths to secure his rights, and it will be interesting to see how his career turns out.

strengths: Elite deep shooter with quick release • Excellent fundamentals and court vision • Strong on-ball pressure defense
weaknesses: Height disadvantage limits finishing • Limited strength to absorb contact • Needs to improve playmaking
awards: CBI champion ( 2017 ), First-team All- Mountain West (2018), Second-team All-Mountain West (2019), Third-team All-Mountain West (2017)
analysis: Wyoming's Justin James, a versatile ball handler who was somewhat of an afterthought in the pre-draft process, was picked at No. 40.

strengths: Impressive motor and effort • Efficient shooter from mid-range and 3-point • Strong finisher at the rim
weaknesses: Struggles against taller players • Limited offensive fluidity and athleticism • Lacks explosive first step
awards: NCAA champion ( 2018 ), First-team All-Big East (2019), Atlantic Ten Rookie of the Year (2015)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2020 )
analysis: Villanova big man Eric Paschall took a bit of a slide but ended up at No. 41. His toughness, defensive versatility and budding 3-point shooting give him a chance to carve out a long NBA career.

strengths: Good shooter with solid range • Strong rebounder for his position • Versatile scorer off the dribble
weaknesses: Struggles to draw fouls • Defensive lapses against quick players • Limited passing ability
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2019 ), First-team All- SEC (2019), Second-team All-SEC (2018)
analysis: Tennessee's Admiral Schofield had an excellent senior season, and he has some things to build on with his shredded frame and spot-up 3-point shooting ability. His ballhandling and feel for the game will need to develop in order to carve out a niche in the NBA, but he has made significant strides with his game every year in college.

strengths: Versatile scorer and athletic • Effective in creating turnovers • Strong three-point shooter
weaknesses: Prone to forced shot selection • Struggles with ball security • Limited facilitation skills
awards: Pac-12 Player of the Year ( 2019 ), First-team All-Pac-12 (2019)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League First Team ( 2025 )
analysis: Washington's Jaylen Nowell landed a spot at No. 43 by winning Pac-12 player of the year honors. His ballhandling and scoring instincts will serve him well in the G League as he attempts to develop his 3-point shooting and defense enough to earn NBA minutes.

strengths: Elite size with mobility and skill • High potential as a rim protector • Effective scorer inside and out
weaknesses: Durability and health concerns • Needs to improve physical strength • Inconsistent effort and intensity
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2018 )
analysis: The Denver Nuggets were the team that eventually decided to trade in order to draft Bol Bol, who apparently had such extraordinary red flags with his injury history and off-court approach as to make him fall all the way to the No. 44 pick. It will be fascinating to see how his career unfolds, as he has a lot of work to do on his frame, his ability to step outside the paint defensively and his approach to reach the lofty potential many saw him in.

strengths: High level multi-position defender • Athletic with good end-to-end speed • Effective passer and improving shooter
weaknesses: Limited offensive scoring ability • Struggles against top competition • Needs right team fit to excel
post draft awards: NBA G League Showcase Cup champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Isaiah Roby finally found a home halfway through the second round at No. 45. He offers intriguing athleticism, defensive versatility and ballhandling, as well as budding 3-point shooting ability. But he has significant work to do on his frame, toughness and consistency before carving out a niche for himself at the NBA level. Roby has upside and is a project worth investing in.

strengths: Strong defensive production and versatility • Excellent rebounder for his size • Explosive leaper with above rim ability
weaknesses: Poor shooting and shot selection • Slow release, struggles with iso • Needs significant development time
awards: Big 12 All-Freshman Team ( 2019 )
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2020 )
analysis: The Lakers traded into No. 46 to select Talen Horton-Tucker here. Horton-Tucker took a tumble deep into the second round, as question marks about his conditioning and approach took a toll on his stock, despite his intriguing upside. Horton-Tucker is the youngest college player to be drafted, has a wingspan that is nearly a foot larger than his height, and has intriguing ability to handle the ball and make perimeter jumpers, making him a player who is worth rolling the dice on to see how he develops in the G League.

strengths: Natural scorer with elite touch • Good 3-point shooter at 39.2% • Strong physical frame, competitive nature
weaknesses: Lacks defensive length and foot speed • Limited playmaking and vision offensively • Free throw shooting needs improvement
awards: AP Honorable mention All-American ( 2019 ), Big Ten Freshman of the Year (2019), Second-team All- Big Ten ( 2019 ), Big Ten All-Freshman team (2019)
post draft awards: King Mindaugas Cup MVP ( 2025 ), LΚL champion ( 2023 ), King Mindaugas Cup winner ( 2023, 2025), Greek Cup winner ( 2024 ), Greek Super Cup winner ( 2023 )
analysis: The Knicks traded into No. 47 to select Ignas Brazdeikis here. Brazdeikis earned a spot in the late second round thanks to his aggressive scoring instincts and toughness, which helped him earn Big Ten freshman of the year honors. The Lithuanian-Canadian will need to improve his defense and perimeter shooting consistency to stick in the NBA.

strengths: Gifted scorer at the rim • Good size and rebounding ability • Improved significantly in three-point shooting
weaknesses: Needs better ball handling skills • Lacks confidence in shot • Disappears in crucial games
analysis: Florida State's Terance Mann had a strong pre-draft process by showcasing his impressive defensive versatility and high basketball IQ. The Clippers will attempt to hone his scoring ability in the G League with the Agua Caliente Clippers of Ontario to the point that he will need to be guarded, but there are some things to like about his physical tools and versatility.

strengths: High-scoring guard with deep shooting range • Strong ball-handling and playmaking ability • Competitive and fearless defender
weaknesses: Below-average size for shooting guard at 6'3" • Inconsistent shot selection and efficiency • Limited athleticism finishing through contact
awards: First-team All- SEC (2019), 2× Second-team All-SEC (2017, 2018), SEC All-Freshman Team (2016), 2x Howell Trophy (2018, 2019)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2022 ), NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2024 )
analysis: Mississippi State's Quinndary Weatherspoon had a strong pre-draft process starting at the Portsmouth Invitational Tournament and continuing at the NBA combine, earning himself a spot in the draft with his toughness, defensive versatility and budding 3-point shooting.

strengths: Versatile scorer with good rebounding • Strong perimeter and post defense • Solid athleticism and shooting touch
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA power forward • Streaky three-point shooter • Struggles with off-ball defense
awards: First-team All- CAA (2019), 2× Second-team All-CAA (2017, 2018), Third-team All-CAA (2016), CAA All-Defensive Team (2017), CAA Rookie of the Year (2016)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League First Team ( 2020 ), NBA G League All-Rookie Team (2020)
analysis: The Jazz traded into No. 50 to select Jarrell Brantley here. College of Charleston's Brantley has the honor of being the first player not in the ESPN 100 to be drafted. He had a strong showing at the Portsmouth Invitational Tournament, but didn't receive an invite to the G League or NBA Combines. Brantley's shredded frame and impressive shot-creation ability are unique for a big man, and will make him a load for opposing big men to contain in the NBA G League next year.

strengths: Excels on both ends of the court • High basketball IQ and floor general • SEC Defensive Player of the Year
weaknesses: Undersized at 5'9.5" barefoot • Struggles defensively against taller players • Questionable decisions in clutch moments
awards: First-team All- SEC (2019), SEC Co-Defensive Player of the Year (2019), SEC All-Freshman Team (2018), Jordan Brand Classic (2017)
post draft awards: FIBA World Cup steals leader ( 2023 ), NBA G League Rookie of the Year (2020), NBA G League All-Rookie Team (2020), All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2020 ), BSN champion (2023), BSN Rookie of the Year (2022)
analysis: LSU's Tremont Waters fell deep in the second round due to concerns around his lack of size and slender frame, but he may be able to earn a roster spot in the NBA down the road thanks to his excellent ballhandling skills, shiftiness, pull-up jumper and court vision.

strengths: Lengthy with great ball handling • Strong finisher, high free throw percentage • Good rebounder and energetic offensively
weaknesses: Needs to improve defensive discipline • Must develop physical strength • Inconsistent outside shooting
awards: Second-team All- Mountain West (2019)
analysis: Jalen McDaniels' size, ballhandling and defensive versatility are interesting enough to warrant a pick at this stage of the draft, even if his slender frame will have to improve to earn a roster spot eventually.

strengths: Elite deep shooter with quick release • Excellent fundamentals and court vision • Strong on-ball pressure defense
weaknesses: Height disadvantage limits finishing • Limited strength to absorb contact • Needs to improve playmaking
awards: 2× Honorable mention All-American – AP ( 2018, 2019 ), 2× CAA Player of the Year (2018, 2019), 2× First-team All- CAA (2018, 2019), Second-team All-CAA (2017)
post draft awards: 2x CEBL scoring champion ( 2023, 2024 ), 2x All-CEBL First Team (2023, 2024), 2x CEBL scoring champion (2023, 2024)
analysis: Hofstra's Justin Wright-Foreman was one of the best scorers in college basketball and should continue to do the same at the G League level with his deep range, ability to make jumpers off the bounce, and explosive athleticism. Wright-Foreman will need to improve his court vision and defensive intensity. But he has some intriguing ingredients to work with as one of the younger seniors to hear his name called.

strengths: Excellent 3-point and free throw shooter • Good size and wingspan for NBA • Efficient scorer with smart shot selection
weaknesses: Limited athletic fluidity and explosiveness • Older with less developmental upside • Struggles with quickness and defense
awards: AP Honorable Mention All-American ( 2019 ), First-team All- Big 12 (2019), Big 12 tournament MVP ( 2019 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2020 ), NBA G League All-Rookie Team (2020)
analysis: Iowa State's Marial Shayok earned a spot in the late second round by exploding in his fifth year of college basketball and developing into one of the best players in the Big 12. While slender at under 200 pounds, the wing of South Sudanese heritage has a 7-foot wingspan that allows him to play bigger than his size.

strengths: Elite long-range shooter • Effective finisher at the rim • Low turnover rate
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA guard • Needs to improve ball handling • Lacks muscle and strength
awards: NCAA champion ( 2019 ), NCAA Final Four Most Outstanding Player (2019), 2× Third-team All-American – AP, NABC ( 2018, 2019 ), Third-team All-American – SN (2019), 2× First-team All-ACC (2018, 2019), ACC tournament MVP ( 2018 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2016 ), Indiana Mr. Basketball (2016)
post draft awards: FIBA Champions League Top Scorer ( 2024 )
analysis: Kyle Guy was the third player to be drafted off of Virginia's national championship squad. Guy is one of the best shooters in the draft, capable of coming off screens, but also able to attack closeouts, boasting a little more versatility than your typical spot-up shooter. His lack of size, length and poor frame may hinder him defensively at the NBA level, but he does have one skill he can hang his hat on with his ability to stretch defenses from beyond the 3-point line.

strengths: Explosive and confident playmaker • Strong defender with quickness • Effective shooter with NBA range
weaknesses: Needs improved defensive alertness • Ball handling and decision-making require tightening • Must get stronger to finish drives effectively
awards: Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2019 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2017 )
analysis: The Nets traded down to No. 56 to select Jaylen Hands here. UCLA's Hands is one of the better athletes selected in the second round, and also has some interesting perimeter shooting ability, giving him two skills that can possibly be developed at just 20 years old. Hands' slender frame, average decision making and defensive intensity will need work to earn a roster spot at the NBA level eventually.

strengths: Elite athleticism and speed • Strong passing and free throw shooting • Good scoring improvement
weaknesses: Needs to build strength • Inconsistent shooting from range • Struggles against bigger players
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2019)
analysis: The Pistons traded into No. 57 to select Jordan Bone here. Bone ranked among the best athletes tested in nearly every category at the NBA combine, and also had a winning pedigree as the point guard of a Tennessee team that significantly exceeded expectations the past two seasons. Bone's basketball IQ and scoring consistency will have to improve to carve out a roster spot in the NBA, but his quickness, ability to change speeds and explosiveness playing above the rim are hard to find.

strengths: Good size and quickness for NBA wing • Versatile defender, can guard multiple positions • Strong finisher and solid shooter
weaknesses: High turnover rate needs improvement • Struggles to perform in big games • Limited upside due to age
awards: Ivy League Player of the Year (2019), 2× First-team All- Ivy League (2018, 2019), Second-team All-Ivy League (2017)
analysis: The Jazz traded into No. 58 to select Miye Oni here. Yale's Oni is the first player drafted from the Ivy League since 1995, and he does have some things he can hang his hat on with his size, length, perimeter shooting and passing ability. Oni is raw in a few different areas, namely his ballhandling and decision-making, but he does have the outlines of a 3-and-D player if his body improves.

strengths: Versatile big man with stretch shooting ability • Solid defender with shot-blocking instincts • Good mobility for positionless play
weaknesses: Inconsistent scoring aggression • Lacks strength to battle inside against physical centers • Limited offensive repertoire beyond jump shot
awards: McDonald's All American ( 2016 )
analysis: Dewan Hernandez lost his entire junior season by a surprisingly harsh ruling made by the NCAA. But he was able to get his draft stock back on track at the G League combine, and then the NBA combine, by virtue of his terrific motor. Hernandez's energy will help the Raptors 905 initially, and he may be able to push for a roster spot eventually if his perimeter skill set and defensive consistency improves.

strengths: Versatile size and position flexibility • Excellent shooter with unlimited range • Above average rebounder for his position
weaknesses: Struggles creating his own shot • Limited by average athleticism • Inconsistent and lacks playmaking skills
awards: Serbian League champion ( 2014 ), 2× Serbian Cup winner ( 2018 , 2019 )
analysis: Vlade Divac drafted fellow Serbian Vanja Marinkovic with the final pick of the NBA draft. Marinkovic had a strong season in Partizan as a volume scorer from the perimeter. He'll likely be stashed for a few years and will have an opportunity to earn a roster spot if his athleticism, defense, ballhandling and shooting consistency improve.

strengths: Elite perimeter defender and lock-down on-ball defender • Strong athleticism and transition finishing ability • High motor and competitiveness
weaknesses: Limited offensive creation and inconsistent shooting stroke • Struggles with playmaking under pressure • Below-average 3-point shooting consistency
awards: Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2019 ), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2019), Pac-12 Freshman of the Year (2019), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2019), 2× BioSteel All-Canadian Game MVP (2017, 2018)

strengths: Quick first step and scoring ability • Excellent midrange and three-point shooting • High basketball IQ and craft
weaknesses: Undersized defender • Inconsistent defensive effort • Limited playmaking vision
awards: Horizon League Player of the Year (2018), First-team All- Horizon League (2018), Big Ten All-Freshman team ( 2014 )
post draft awards: EuroLeague champion ( 2024 ), EuroLeague MVP ( 2025 ), 2× All-EuroLeague First Team ( 2024, 2025 ), Alphonso Ford EuroLeague Top Scorer Trophy ( 2025 ), NBA All-Rookie First Team ( 2020 ), Greek League champion ( 2024 ), Greek Cup winner ( 2025 ), All-Greek League First Team (2024), Greek League Most Popular Player (2024)

strengths: Strong physical defender with good length • Solid playmaking and shooting abilities • High effort level and rebounding for a guard
weaknesses: Lacks ideal height for shooting guard • Ball dominant and turnover prone • Struggles with off-ball play and isolation scoring
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2019)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2020 )

strengths: Elite rim protector with immense height • Strong finisher and solid rebounder • Good mobility for his size
weaknesses: Struggles defending on the perimeter • Poor free throw shooter • Limited offensive range
awards: Third-team All- AAC ( 2019 ), AAC Defensive Player of the Year ( 2017 )
post draft awards: CBA blocks leader ( 2023 ), 2× NBA G League All-Defensive Team ( 2020, 2022 ), NBA G League blocks leader ( 2022 )

strengths: NBA size with solid freshman stats • Effective rim protector and rebounder • High field goal percentage, smart shot selection
weaknesses: Needs to improve shooting form • Limited offensive moves • Struggles with perimeter defense

awards: Pac-12 All-Freshman Team ( 2019 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2018 )
post draft awards: NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 ), All-NBA G League First Team ( 2021 ), All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2025 ), 2x NBA G League All-Defensive Team ( 2021, 2025 )

weaknesses: Limited perimeter shooting • Undersized compared to NBA 4s • Inconsistent pick-and-pop shooting

post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2020 ), Italian Supercup winner ( 2023 ), All-NBA G League First Team ( 2020 ), NBA G League All-Rookie Team (2020)

strengths: Reliable three-point shooter with NBA range • High basketball IQ off the ball • Solid athleticism for wing play
weaknesses: Limited defensive versatility • Inconsistent playmaking • Below-average ball-handling
awards: Atlantic Sun Player of the Year (2019), 3× First-team All- Atlantic Sun (2017–2019)

strengths: High-energy athletic forward • Strong rebounder and shot-blocker • Effective lob threat in transition
weaknesses: Raw offensive skillset • Free-throw inconsistency • Needs better perimeter defense
awards: First-team All- SEC (2018), First-team All-SEC – Coaches (2019), SEC Co-Defensive Player of the Year (2018), SEC All-Defensive team (2018)

strengths: Elite shot-blocker with long wingspan • Excellent athleticism and rim-finishing • High upside as a defender
weaknesses: Raw offensive polish • Inconsistent foot speed in pick-and-roll defense • Poor free-throw shooting
