analysis: Indiana took Mathurin at No. 6, enamored by his Canadian pedigree, shooting touch and high-motor two-way play. He projects as a ready-made 3-and-D wing with secondary playmaking chops. His athleticism and competitive spirit bode well for an immediate role; sharpening shot creation inside the arc will boost his scoring impact.

strengths: Elite athleticism and NBA-ready body • Three-level scoring ability • Excellent ball control and defensive potential
weaknesses: Unproven against higher competition • Questionable intensity and focus • Potential long learning curve
analysis: Portland grabbed Sharpe at No. 7 despite just six college games, banking on his high-end scoring talent and physical upside. His deep shooting and explosive first step offer clear NBA traits. Limited competitive experience and playmaking polish leave some questions, but his raw tools make him a high-ceiling prospect.

analysis: New Orleans chose Daniels at No. 8 for his rare blend of size, defensive instincts and playmaking calm. He’s a multi-positional stopper who can initiate offense, handle the pick-and-roll and spot up. Continued growth as a shooter and finishing in traffic will determine how quickly he carves out a rotation spot.

analysis: San Antonio selected Sochan at No. 9 for his two-way verve, length and playmaking from the frontcourt. He brings immediate energy as a shot-blocker, rebounder and weak-side help defender. His ability to handle the ball and pass out of short rolls adds a modern dimension; steady shooting development will unlock his ceiling.

strengths: Athletic with strong frame • Effective transition player • Promising defensive skills

Expanding his perimeter shot-making and playmaking will be crucial for him to emerge as a primary option in time.

awards: ABA League Top Prospect (2022), 2× Junior ABA League champion ( 2021, 2022 ), Junior ABA League MVP (2021), 2× Junior ABA League Ideal Starting 5 (2021, 2022)
analysis: Miami took Jović at No. 27, lured by his 6-10 playmaking, shooting feel and fluid athleticism. Though inexperienced, he shows Gallinari-like upside as a floor-spacing forward with secondary creation chops. Gaining strength and defensive discipline will be key to unlocking his two-way potential.

strengths: Pure jump shooter with quick release • Strong catch-and-shoot threat • Good mobility at 6’9 frame
weaknesses: Needs strength for physical matchups • Defensive consistency concerns • Inconsistent finishing at rim
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021)
analysis: LA Lakers used No. 28 pick on Baldwin, wagering on his pedigree, shooting mechanics and size despite an uneven college season. He offers lottery-caliber talent if he regains health and confidence. Proving durability, consistency and effort will determine whether he becomes a high-floor role-player or bust.

strengths: Efficient playmaker with low turnover rate • Deadly pull-up jumper in pick-and-roll • High competitiveness on defense
weaknesses: Lacks ideal size for point guard • Below average athletic explosiveness • Inconsistent defensive focus
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2022), SEC All-Freshman team (2022), Jordan Brand Classic (2021)
analysis: Houston grabbed Washington at No. 29, betting on his pick-and-roll IQ, pace-setting and midrange scoring. He fits as a second-unit engine with positional size and vision. Staying healthy, locking into defensive assignments and knocking down open 3s will be vital for his early-career trajectory.

strengths: High level athlete with NBA size • Potential as a two-way player • Excellent rebounder and shot blocker
weaknesses: Needs significant strength development • Poor offensive efficiency • Lacks experience and rhythm
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2021 )
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Phoenix took Watson at No. 30, intrigued by his length, defensive promise and off-ball instincts. Although raw offensively, he brings switchability and transition instincts at 6-8. Building strength, assertiveness and a consistent shooting stroke will help him carve out a role in a veteran Suns rotation.

strengths: Expert at running efficient offense • Disruptive defender with good size • Improved perimeter scorer
weaknesses: Lacks elite level speed and athleticism • Jump shot development recent and limited • Struggled against high-end competition
awards: First-team All- WCC (2022), Second-team All-WCC (2021), WCC Sixth Man of the Year (2021), WCC tournament MOP ( 2022 ), SEC All-Freshman Team (2019), Jordan Brand Classic (2018), Nike Hoop Summit (2018)
analysis: Nembhard had an outstanding four-year college career and brings significant experience at the FIBA level, as well as with the Canadian national team. He has good size for a point guard at 6-4½ in shoes and steadily improved as a perimeter shooter. He was the steady engine behind one of college basketball’s most efficient offenses, playing virtually every minute down the stretch. What he lacks in explosiveness and upside, he makes up for with experience, poise and willingness to run a team—making him an easy backup and multi-guard lineup fit in the NBA.

strengths: High-level shooter with good mechanics • Impressive basketball IQ and feel for the game • Great size and wingspan for defensive play
weaknesses: Lacks fluidity and explosiveness • Not a strong shot-creator • Inconsistent and underwhelming production
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021)
analysis: Coming off an outstanding showing at last summer’s FIBA U19 World Cup leading Canada to a bronze medal, Houstan entered the draft as a top-10 recruit but struggled terribly with consistency and efficiency at Michigan, often looking physically overwhelmed. Despite flashes of versatility as a ball handler, passer, defender and shooter in high school and international play, he failed to translate that confidence to the college game and declined combine workouts—signaling that the promise many teams once saw in him didn’t materialize.

strengths: Excellent rim protector and finisher • Strong rebounder with active motor • Developing mid-range shooting ability
weaknesses: Struggles with physicality and muscle • Limited offensive game beyond dunks • Defensive fundamentals need improvement
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 (2022), Pac-12 Defensive Player of the Year (2022), Pac-12 Most Improved Player (2022), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2022)
analysis: The Raptors went on a late-season run to claim the fifth seed in the Eastern Conference, showing promise with one of the NBA’s youngest rosters. Toronto traded into No. 33 to find a starting-caliber center, landing Koloko—Pac-12 Defensive Player of the Year and Most Improved Player. His 102-block junior season and 7’5” wingspan showcased his rim protection and mobility, while his lob finishing flashed upside. He must add strength, improve physicality and refine his feel to handle contact and sustain consistency in the NBA.

strengths: Versatile defender with high basketball IQ • Strong rebounder and passer • Potential to expand shooting range
weaknesses: Limited outside shooting ability • Prone to turnovers • Underwhelming shot blocking stats
awards: First-team All- SEC – Coaches (2022), Second-team All-SEC – AP (2022), SEC All-Defensive Team (2022), Mr. Basketball of Arkansas (2020)
analysis: Williams checks many boxes at 6-10, 237 lb with a 7-1 wingspan—high IQ, toughness, rebounding and passing instincts. He’s a Vladimir guard in the Kevon Looney mold, projecting as a high-motor backup who excels on charges, screens, and defensive rotations. Lacking shooting range and rim-protection upside, he’ll need to continue expanding his perimeter game and switching agility to carve out a long-term NBA role.

strengths: Sweet shooting with high release • Utilizes screens effectively • Coachable and high basketball IQ
weaknesses: Needs to increase strength • Inefficient and contested shooter • Limited natural playmaking ability
awards: Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2023 )
analysis: Christie is a sweet-shooting guard with picture-perfect mechanics, fluid pull-ups and on-the-move catch-and-shoot ability. At 6-6 with a 6-9 wingspan, he offers defensive versatility and team floor spacing. He struggled with consistency and shot volume at MSU but has the foundation to develop into a reliable 3-and-D role player if he refines his confidence and decision-making.

strengths: Athletic wing with good size and IQ • Effective finisher, versatile defender • Strong in transition and off-ball movement
weaknesses: Struggles with shot creation • Needs to improve strength and handling • Defensive gambles leave team exposed
post draft awards: EuroLeague Rising Star ( 2024 )
analysis: Procida is an almost 6-8 Italian wing with NBA-level shooting touch, bump-and-run finishing and surprising fluidity. He’s one of Europe’s deadliest catch-and-shoot creators but remains raw as a ball handler and perimeter defender. His slender frame and inexperience against elite talent temper expectations, but his shooting and work ethic give him sleeper appeal as a floor-spacing bench scorer.

strengths: Elite finisher and space creator • Strong defensive instincts and recovery • Improving shooting percentages
weaknesses: Predictable offensive moves • Prone to turnovers and overconfidence • Needs better decision making skills
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021)
analysis: Hardy started the season projected as a top-5 pick but saw his stock tumble after an inefficient G League campaign marked by poor shot selection and defensive lapses. He possesses one of the best pull-up strokes at any age and elite off-dribble creativity, yet his lack of discipline and inconsistent effort relegated him toward the back of the second round. On the right team, he could thrive as a high-variance bench scorer.

strengths: Lightning quick with improved 3-point shooting • Excellent mid-range shooter and passer • Disruptive defender with good anticipation
weaknesses: Small and slight frame for NBA • Poor free throw shooter • Slow shooting motion and adjustment time
awards: Second-team All- SEC (2022), SEC All-Freshman Team (2022), SEC tournament MVP ( 2022 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021), 2× Tennessee Mr. Basketball (2019, 2020)
analysis: Chandler finished as one of college basketball’s best two-way freshmen with lockdown perimeter defense, 47 % 3-point shooting down the stretch and dynamic burst. At 5-11 barefoot with a 6-5 wingspan, he overcame size concerns to become a quick-trigger pick-and-roll creator. His draft slide into the late second round reflects teams’ lingering worries about shooting consistency and leadership, but his skill set projects well as a backup point guard.

strengths: Prototypical size and athleticism • Strong finisher, good in transition • Effective Pick and Roll player
weaknesses: Inexperienced, needs game polishing • Predictable post moves, right-hand dominant • Inconsistent mid-range shooter and free thrower
awards: EuroCup Rising Star ( 2022 )
post draft awards: EuroCup champion ( 2023 ), 2× ACB All-Young Players Team ( 2022 , 2023 )
analysis: Diop is one of Europe’s most versatile defensive bigs at 7-0 with a 7-4 wingspan—able to hedge screens, switch onto guards and protect the rim. He paired that with steady offensive rebounding and short-roll passing to earn a late second-round selection. His lack of polish as a pick-and-pop shooter (57 % FT) and a need to add strength will likely relegate him to a long-term stash or G League role before an NBA call-up.

strengths: Athletic with potential for explosiveness • Effective three-level scorer • Good rebounder due to length
weaknesses: Inconsistent defensive engagement • Needs to improve shot selection • Struggles against physical defenders
awards: Third-team All- Big Ten (2022), Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2022), South Carolina Mr. Basketball (2021), Jordan Brand Classic (2021)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Second Team ( 2025 )
analysis: McGowens is a naturally gifted scorer with smooth pull-up range and creative finishing at 6-6 with a 6-9 wingspan. He led Nebraska in scoring as a freshman but struggled against top-tier competition, displaying uneven defensive effort and decision-making. His ability to stretch the floor and run in transition gives him winning “garbage-time” appeal, but he’ll need seasoning before reliable rotation minutes.

strengths: High basketball IQ and anticipation • Effective post passer and rebounder • Improved perimeter shooting
weaknesses: Lacks explosiveness and quickness • Struggles with shot elevation • Right-hand dominant, struggles with off hand
awards: Third-team All-American – AP, USBWA, NABC, SN ( 2022 ), First-team All- Big Ten – Media (2022), 2× First-team All- Big Ten – Coaches ( 2021, 2022), Big Ten All-Defensive Team (2022), Second-team All-Big Ten – Media (2021), 2× Illinois Mr. Basketball (2018, 2019)
analysis: Liddell opened eyes with an All-American junior season—averaging 20 ppg, 7 rpg, 38 % 3-point shooting and anchoring Ohio State defensively. At 6-7 with near-7-foot length, he moves like a guard, blocks shots, and steps out to hit open jumpers. Undersized as a traditional big and reliant on strength over explosion, he fell to the late second round but should carve out a 3-and-D power-forward role.

strengths: Excels at driving and finishing • Versatile and effective defender • Strong rebounding abilities
weaknesses: Inconsistent outside shooting • Limited playmaking vision • Inefficient free-throw shooter
awards: ACC All-Rookie Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021)
analysis: Keels is a stocky 6-5 combo guard with perimeter toughness, solid two-way instincts and secondary playmaking. He showed why he was a lottery contender in spurts at Duke but was inconsistent as a shot creator and on-ball defender. His blend of size and feel earned a late second-round nod; sustained aggression and shooting growth will dictate his path to regular minutes.

strengths: Agile with potential to add mass • Good finisher around the rim • Unselfish with developing passing skills
weaknesses: Needs to improve shooting touch • Lacks offensive skill variety • Can be physically overpowered
awards: Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021)
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2023 ), NBA G League All-Rookie Team (2023)
analysis: Diabate is an ultra-athletic 6-10 freshman who posted highlight-reel rim runs, chase-down blocks and lobs for Michigan. His wiry 210 lb frame and lack of polish made him a raw draw, falling to the second round. With elite mobility and defensive upside, he profiles as a modern rim-runner if he can fill out, add touch and develop consistent effort on both ends.

strengths: Elite court vision and size • Strong slasher and finisher • Effective in transition and rebounding
weaknesses: Questionable competition level • Inconsistent defensive effort • Needs shooting improvement
awards: First-team All- MAC (2022), MAC Freshman of the Year (2021), MAC All-Freshman Team (2021)
post draft awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Rollins broke out as Toledo’s leading scorer, showcasing a 6-9 wingspan, shiftiness and off-dribble pull-up that reminded scouts of mid-first-round talent. His defensive motor wavered at times, and his 33 % 3-point mark needs improvement. Drafted late in Round 2, he’ll need to lock in defensively and refine his decision-making to earn two-way minutes.

strengths: Excellent size and wingspan for a wing • Can score from anywhere, versatile shooter • High motor and consistently runs the floor
weaknesses: Shooting form needs improvement • Struggles with lateral movement on defense • Can be out of control on layups
awards: AAC All-Freshman Team (2022)
analysis: Minott offers explosive athleticism, vertical spacing and versatile defense. When given minutes at Memphis, he flashed highlight-reel finishes, offensive rebounding and shot-blocking. His inconsistent role behind veterans and lack of perimeter game left him raw, but his physical upside earned a second-round pick and makes him a candidate for a two-way contract.

strengths: Athletic with good size and leaping ability • Effective in pick and roll situations • Strong rim protector and shot blocker
weaknesses: Needs to add muscle and strength • Limited offensive skills and basic post moves • Inconsistent in setting effective screens
awards: LNB Pro A Best Defender (2022), LNB Pro A Domestic Player of the Year (2022), LNB All-Star (2021)
post draft awards: EuroCup blocks leader ( 2023 )
analysis: Kamagate is a 6-11 French big with a 7-3 wingspan who developed into a lob-catching, defensive playmaker in Spain’s top league. His shot-blocking, quickness and occasional short-roll passing give him modern center appeal. He needs added strength, improved screening and finishing consistency, but his late-blooming trajectory makes him an intriguing second-round stash.

strengths: Solid three-point shooter with quick release • Strong defensive instincts and lateral quickness • Above-average athleticism and motor
weaknesses: Limited playmaking vision • Needs to improve isolation scoring • Struggles finishing through contact
awards: First-team All- Atlantic 10 (2022), Third-team All-Atlantic 10 (2021)
analysis: Williams is a 6-6 wing with a 7-1 wingspan who shot 40 % from three over two seasons at VCU and showed solid all-around feel. He plays with high energy, basketball IQ and versatility, but he lacks explosion and off-dribble creation. His floor-spacing and defensive instincts earned him a late second-round selection as a potential 3-and-D role player.

strengths: Explosive athlete with excellent size • Strong finisher around the rim • Potential as a versatile defender
weaknesses: Needs to refine overall skill set • Inconsistent shooter from all ranges • Limited offensive playmaking ability
awards: Big 12 All-Freshman Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), Nike Hoop Summit (2021)
analysis: Brown is one of college’s most explosive leapers, showcasing rim-runs, rim protection and off-ball cutting at Baylor. His 6-8 frame and 6-11 wingspan belie his shot-creation upside, but he struggled with shooting consistency, defensive focus and feel as a freshman. Drafted late in Round 2, Brown projects as a high-upside bench athlete if he hones his jumper and reads.

strengths: Extremely mobile and athletic stretch-big • Solid rebounder with strong frame • Talented passer with good court vision
weaknesses: Poor rim protection and shot blocking • Inefficient two-point scorer • Average free-throw shooter at 68%
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2022 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2019 )
post draft awards: All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2023 ), NBA G League Next Up Game (2023)
analysis: Mobley, the older brother of Evan, averaged double-digit scoring and 36 % 3-point shooting at USC while defending both forward spots with his 7-3 wingspan. His instincts and IQ stood out, though limited burst and a narrow frame capped his upside. He fell to the second round but figures to earn early minutes as a glue-guy big who can knock down open shots.

strengths: High basketball IQ and court vision • Effective shooter with good mechanics • Versatile scorer and solid defender
weaknesses: Inconsistent performance and decision-making • Struggles with physicality and athleticism • Needs improvement in Pick and Roll defense
analysis: Spagnolo is a polished 6-5 point guard who averaged 12 ppg and 49 % 3-point shooting in Italy’s top league at 19. His pick-and-roll creativity, off-dribble shot and floor vision are advanced, but his average athleticism and inconsistent defense raise questions. Drafted late on a draft-and-stash deal, he’ll likely develop overseas before an NBA look.

strengths: Athletic wing with improved shooting • Excellent rebounder and transition finisher • Versatile defender and solid passer
weaknesses: Limited shot creation ability • Older prospect with limited upside • Below average free-throw shooter
analysis: Martin is a hard-nosed wing who shot 43 % from three and served as UConn’s defensive stopper on their title run. At 6-6 with a 6-8 wingspan, he projects as a Swiss-army knife off the bench. He lacks explosive tools and must round out his offensive game, but his motor, feel and two-way track record earned him a second-round nod.

strengths: Athletic with good size and mobility • High basketball IQ and court awareness • Effective in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Needs to add strength and weight • Limited offensive creation skills • Inconsistent perimeter shooting
awards: Croatian Cup winner (2019), Jordan Brand Classic (2017)
post draft awards: EuroCup blocks leader ( 2024 ), Slovenian League champion ( 2023 ), Slovenian Cup winner (2023)
analysis: Matkovévić exploded at the pre-draft pro day showing high-voltage dunking, touch shooting and contagious energy. A 6-11 Serbian big with a 7-1 wingspan, he showed early flashes as a rim-running shot-blocker. Raw as a screener and shooter (6 career threes), he slipped into Round 2 but has high upside if he refines his skill set.

strengths: Explosive athleticism and vertical leap • Excellent in transition and ball handling • Strong passer with quick three-point release
weaknesses: Inconsistent outside shooting • High turnover rate • Struggles with off-ball defense and versatility
awards: SEC All-Freshman Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2021), 2× Alabama Mr. Basketball (2020, 2021)
post draft awards: NBA champion ( 2024 ), NBA G League Most Valuable Player ( 2025 ), All-NBA G League First Team (2025), All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2024 ), NBA G League Next Up Game (2024)
analysis: Davison entered as a YouTube dunk sensation and turned heads at Alabama with elite rebounding, defensive tenacity and playmaking flashes. His scoring polished to 12 ppg in limited minutes, but his shooting off the dribble was inconsistent and his turnover rate high. Drafted late, he projects as a high-energy backup who can develop into a pass-first guard.

strengths: Great size and wingspan • Strong finisher, good in P&R • Athletic with high potential
weaknesses: Needs to add weight • Limited offensive skills • Struggles with physical play
awards: ACB All-Young Players Team ( 2021 )
analysis: Nzosa missed much of the season with injury but reminded evaluators why he was a rising lottery pick as a 17-year-old in Spain: an ultra-athletic 6-11 defender with switchability, chase-down blocks and rim-runs. His second-year struggles and thin 215 lb frame dropped him to the late second round, but his defensive upside makes him a worthwhile stash.

strengths: Excellent ball handler with good game sense • Strong in transition and offensive rebounds • Effective in creating offensive plays
weaknesses: Struggles against faster, more athletic opponents • Inconsistent shooting from distance • Needs to improve physical strength and decision-making
awards: NBB Sixth Man of the Year (2022)
post draft awards: NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2023 )
analysis: Santos is a strong, versatile Brazilian wing with dependable finishing around the basket, rebounding instincts and 37 % 3-point shooting in the Brazilian league. At 6-8, he defended multiple positions but must develop his handle and playmaking. Drafted in Round 2, he has sleeper appeal as a two-way role player if he refines his skill set overseas.

strengths: Great size and quick release • Confident playmaker and passer • Effective in transition and finishing
weaknesses: Inefficient perimeter shooting • Limited against high-level competition • Struggles with defensive impact
awards: NBL champion ( 2020 ), NBL Cup winner ( 2021 ), SBL Most Improved Player ( 2019 )
analysis: Travers is a 6-8 Australian wing who logged minutes from the point guard to small forward spots, showcasing slashing, on-ball defense and playmaking. His slender 199 lb frame and inconsistent shooting kept him raw, but his size, IQ and versatility earned a second-round pick as a long-term project with Boomers upside.

strengths: Versatile position-less forward • High-level rebounder • Solid free throw shooter
weaknesses: Struggles with consistency • Lacks great physical strength • Turnover prone
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2022 ), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2021)
analysis: Walker, son of former NBA big Samaki, is a 6-8 forward with a 6-10 wingspan who shot 35 % from three and blocked shots at Colorado. His athleticism and shot-blocking instincts stood out, but he needs to add strength and consistency. Drafted late in Round 2, he profiles as a developmental stretch-four with defensive upside.

strengths: Score-first combo guard with good size • Creative offensive player, good at drawing fouls • Effective in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Streaky, inefficient shooter • Prone to turnovers and poor shot choices • Defensive skills need significant improvement
awards: LNB Pro B All-Star Five (2021), LNB Pro B Best Youngster (2021), LNB Pro B Best Scorer (2021), No. 25 retired by Saint-Quentin BB
analysis: Besson is a third-generation pro scorer who flourished in the French second division and Australian NBL with deep shooting (38 % 3-point) and off-dribble creativity. At 6-5, he lacks elite athleticism and must improve defensively, but his ability to score in bunches and make plays earned him a late second-round selection as a potential microwave scoring spark.

strengths: Gritty playmaker with scoring versatility • Reliable spot-up shooter with quick release • Instinctual, disciplined on-ball defender
weaknesses: Struggles shooting off the dribble consistently • Occasional defensive lapses in focus • Average athleticism limits upside

analysis: A generational two-way talent- Wembanyama instantly transforms the Spurs on both ends: a 7'5" shot-creator and elite rim-protector with elite playmaking for his size. He’ll be the focal point of San Antonio’s offense and defense- tasked with lifting a young core toward contention in the coming years.

strengths: Extremely talented 6'9 versatile forward • Excellent shooter with deep range • Good rebounder and defender
weaknesses: Lacks great burst and explosiveness • Struggles with finishing through contact • Not a strong playmaker for others
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2023 ), Wayman Tisdale Award (2023), NABC Freshman of the Year (2023), SEC Player of the Year (2023), SEC Rookie of the Year (2023), First-team All- SEC (2023), SEC tournament MVP ( 2023 ), McDonald's All-American ( 2022 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2022), Tennessee Mr. Basketball (2022)

analysis: A 6'8" playmaking wing with strong shot-making and passing instincts- Miller offers secondary creation- 3-level scoring and defensive versatility. His explosiveness and skill set pair well with young stars like LaMelo Ball- though his stamina and shot efficiency versus top defenses will be closely watched.

strengths: Outstanding length and athleticism • Excellent at creating offense • Strong finisher at the rim
weaknesses: Inconsistent three-point shooter • Defensive fundamentals lacking • Can stagnate offensive flow
awards: NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2023 )
analysis: An electrifying playmaker at 6'2" with All-Star upside- Henderson changes gears off the dribble- finishes creatively and flashes advanced passing. He’ll bring dynamic scoring and playmaking to Portland’s backcourt- provided he refines his decision-making- jumper and consistency on defense.

strengths: Physically gifted, versatile defender • Excellent in transition and passing • Explosive athleticism and speed
weaknesses: Poor jump shot mechanics • Struggles in half-court offense • Defensive fundamentals need improvement
awards: OTE champion (2023), All-OTE First Team (2023)
post draft awards: NBA All-Rookie Second Team ( 2024 )
analysis: A 6'7" ultra-athletic guard with elite open-court scoring- live-ball passing and switch-anywhere defense. Thompson fits well as a high-upside project for the Rockets- though he must add an off-ball game and perimeter consistency to reach his ceiling.

strengths: Explosive athleticism and speed • High defensive potential and motor • Effective transition player and passer
weaknesses: Relies too much on athleticism • Underdeveloped jump shot • High turnover rate and poor shot selection

Risacher provides roster flexibility for an active offseason around their young core.

college: Independence CC (2020–2021) Northeastern Oklahoma A&M (2021–2022) Missouri State (2022–2023) San Francisco (2023–2024)

analysis: Toronto selected sleeper Mogbo, a versatile, defensive-minded forward with strong passing and transition skill. He fits the Raptors’ development model and could become a useful role player if he adds perimeter shooting. Long-term flier with intriguing playmaking upside.

strengths: Good coordination and productivity • Strong post skills and rebounding • Improved outside shooting threat
weaknesses: Limited athletic explosiveness • Struggles against athletic bigs • Defensive limitations, not a rim protector
awards: Consensus second-team All-American ( 2024 ), First-team All-ACC (2024), Second-team All-ACC (2023), ACC All-Freshman team (2023), ACC Rookie of the Year (2023), ACC tournament MVP ( 2023 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2022), Nike Hoop Summit (2022)
analysis: Utah landed Filipowski at No. 32, adding a skilled 7-footer with perimeter touch and offensive versatility. He fell into the second round but gives the Jazz a chance to develop his shooting and consistency. A likely rotational big with upside as he matures.

strengths: Versatile forward with strong dunking ability • High potential as a three-point shooter • Excellent mobility and coordination for size
weaknesses: Limited ISO and post game • Average efficiency and scoring output • Needs improvement in rebounding and speed
awards: NBA Cup champion ( 2024 ), NBA G League Next Up Game ( 2024 ), All- OTE Second Team (2023)
analysis: Milwaukee added Smith after projecting as a late first-rounder, valuing his size, outside shooting and scoring per minute. He offers floor-spacing upside and took positive steps with G League Ignite. A developmental pick to bolster the Bucks’ long-term plans.

strengths: Makes game look incredibly easy • Top facilitator with high basketball IQ • Excellent shooter, 88% free throws, 40% threes
weaknesses: Lacks speed, size, and athleticism • Defensive struggles against NBA caliber • Older prospect, turning 23
awards: NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 ), NBA G League Winter Showcase MVP (2024), Consensus second-team All-American ( 2024 ), Second-team All-American – USBWA, SN ( 2023 ), Third-team All-American – AP, NABC (2023), NCAA assists leader (2024), Big East Player of the Year (2023), 2× First-team All-Big East (2023, 2024), Atlantic 10 Rookie of the Year ( 2021 ), Big East tournament MOP ( 2023 )
analysis: New York traded back into Round 2 for seasoned point guard Kolek, who brings pick-and-roll savvy and efficient shooting. He’ll compete for backup minutes behind Jalen Brunson and fits coach Thibodeau’s emphasis on toughness. Proven college playmaker in a low-risk move.

strengths: Versatile scorer with strong three-point shooting • Effective without needing offensive focus • Good size and potential for NBA wing
weaknesses: Needs significant development time • Limited creator off the dribble • Defensive mechanics and focus lacking
awards: Big 12 All-Freshman team (2024)
analysis: Indiana swung on Furphy, the late-blooming wing with offensive upside despite his youth and defensive inexperience. The Pacers traded up to select him as a developmental perimeter piece. His size, shooting flashes and potential earned him a roster spot.

strengths: High basketball IQ and court vision • Excellent in transition and Pick and Roll • Creative ball handler and passer
weaknesses: Struggles with shooting consistency • Below average athleticism and explosiveness • Defensive weaknesses due to physical limitations
awards: German BBL champion (2023), Spanish League champion ( 2022 ), Spanish Supercup winner ( 2021 ), EuroLeague NGT champion ( 2021 )
analysis: San Antonio took Núñez as a non-roster stash, betting on his elite creativity, court vision and evolving shooting. The Spurs’ international development track record makes them ideal for his growth. Could be a future backup point guard option.

strengths: Good shooter with solid offensive potential • Effective in creating steals and fast breaks • High energy and unselfish team player
weaknesses: Limited athleticism for NBA standards • Struggles with ball handling and creation • Prone to turnovers and lacks strength
analysis: Detroit drafted Klintman as a developmental project with size, shooting and defensive versatility. He joins Trajan Langdon’s rebuild alongside Ron Holland. Upside pick with room to grow on both ends.

strengths: Plays with flair and control • Strong free throw shooter • Good passer with low turnovers
weaknesses: Inconsistent three-point shooter • Limited experience against top competition • Questions about defensive intensity
awards: Big West Player of the Year (2023), 2× First-team All- Big West (2023, 2024), Second-team All-Big West (2022), Big West Freshman of the Year (2022)
analysis: Oklahoma City maneuvered into No. 38 to select playmaking guard Mitchell, bolstering backcourt depth with his pick-and-roll creativity and improving shooting. He joins Topic and Jones in the Thunder’s youth movement. A developmental guard with upside.

strengths: Excellent shooter with deep range • Good height and frame for wing positions • High basketball IQ and decision-making
weaknesses: Needs to improve first step and explosiveness • Limited offensive moves and creativity • Defensive positioning and impact lacking
awards: CCAA Player of the Year (2023), First-team All-CCAA (2023)
analysis: Memphis added Wells, a breakout shooter from Washington State, as a second-round flier. His spot-up shooting and age make him an intriguing project for the Grizzlies. Potential bench floor-spacer if he can expand his overall game.

strengths: Experienced, athletic bigman with solid rebounding • Effective rim protector and passer • Strong leaper and lob target
weaknesses: Undersized for NBA center position • Limited shooting range and poor free throw shooter • Needs to add strength and improve post game
awards: 2× Second-team All-Big East (2023, 2024), Second-team Academic All-American ( 2024 )
analysis: Phoenix traded up for Ighodaro, an interior passer and defender from Marquette with local roots. He offers unorthodox skill around the basket and could carve out rotation minutes. A low-risk bench addition to complement the Suns’ stars.

strengths: Elite shot-blocking with 7-3 wingspan • Fast in open court, strong dunker • Improved free throw shooting at UCLA
weaknesses: Fouls too frequently, lacks discipline • Underwhelming rebounder for his size • No demonstrated passing or shooting ability
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2024 ), Pac-12 Defensive Player of the Year (2024), 2× Pac-12 All-Defensive Team ( 2023, 2024), Pac-12 Freshman of the Year (2023), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2023), McDonald's All-American ( 2022 )
analysis: Philadelphia selected Bona for his relentless motor, defensive versatility and rim-running ability behind Joel Embiid. He competes for bench minutes, providing toughness and rebounding. Value pick with upside in a winning culture.

strengths: Explosive leaper with high efficiency • Excellent shooter, quick in transition • Strong pick and roll decision-maker
weaknesses: Struggles with size defensively • Limited rebounding and defensive impact • Physical attributes nearly maxed out
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2024 ), Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2023 ), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2022)
analysis: Charlotte added Simpson, a creative undersized scorer whose jump in efficiency at Colorado earned him attention. His playmaking and defensive grit give him a chance at bench minutes. A high-effort guard with upside.

strengths: versatile playmaking wing with size (6'8") and NBA-caliber athleticism • high basketball IQ enabling elite pick-and-roll creation and court vision • improved three-point shooting (33%) with ability as secondary creator
weaknesses: shooting consistency remains a question mark, especially in catch-and-shoot situations • lateral quickness and on-ball defense can lag against quicker guards • needs to add strength to finish through contact consistently
awards: ABA League Top Prospect (2023), Euroleague NGT champion (2022), 2× Junior ABA League champion ( 2021, 2022 ), Euroleague NGT MVP (2022), Junior ABA League Ideal Starting Five (2021)
analysis: Atlanta traded up for Djurisić, a young European wing with scoring bursts and potential as an international stash. He brings size and athleticism for future lineup versatility. Low-leverage overseas swing after a payroll move.

strengths: Excellent shooter with quick release • Strong pick and roll facilitator • High basketball IQ and court awareness
weaknesses: Struggles with on-ball defense • Limited physical attributes for position • Scoring dipped against tougher competition
awards: Second-team All-Pac-12 (2024), Pac-12 Sixth Man of the Year (2022), Second-team Academic All-American ( 2024 )
analysis: Miami moved back and drafted Larsson, a versatile guard with efficient catch-and-shoot prowess and defensive instincts. He fits the Heat’s culture as a high-IQ role player and could earn bench minutes. Value pick targeting long-term reliability.

strengths: Excellent defensive skills and toughness • Strong passer with low turnovers • Effective in pick-and-roll situations
weaknesses: Limited offensive scoring ability • Struggles with shooting range • Can be overly aggressive on defense
awards: Consensus first-team All-American ( 2024 ), Naismith Defensive Player of the Year (2024), NABC Defensive Player of the Year (2024), Big 12 Player of the Year (2024), First-team All- Big 12 (2024), Big 12 Defensive Player of the Year (2024), Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2024), Second-team All- AAC (2023), Third-team All-AAC (2022), AAC Defensive Player of the Year (2023)
analysis: Toronto selected Shead for his defensive intensity, playmaking and winning pedigree. He profiles as a spark-plug backup guard, close to NBA-ready among second-rounders. Veteran toughness and court vision give him a shot at early minutes.

strengths: Excellent jump shooter with high release • Good passer with strong basketball IQ • Uses length well defensively
weaknesses: Needs to add strength and muscle • Lacks quickness and explosiveness • Struggles with physical play
awards: Big Ten All-Freshman Team (2024)
analysis: Los Angeles took Christie, a sharpshooter from Minnesota, as a floor-spacing project off the bench. His shooting touch and frame offer upside, though he needs to grow into his role. Developmental pick with long-term shooting potential.

strengths: Highly efficient three-level scorer • Excellent shooter with strong percentages • Improved defensively, takes responsibility
weaknesses: Older rookie with limited upside • Inconsistent in high-pressure games • Lacks elite athleticism and versatility
awards: Third-team All-American – USBWA, SN ( 2024 ), First-team All- SEC (2024), SEC co-Sixth Man of the Year (2023), Second-team All- MVC (2022)
analysis: New Orleans acquired Reeves, a 45% three-point shooter at Kentucky, as bench depth. He offers instant shooting off the catch and could develop defensively. Value pick to bolster perimeter shooting.

strengths: Versatile defender across positions • Strong rebounder and physical presence • Improved three-point shooter
weaknesses: Limited offensive creation ability • Below average speed and athleticism • Needs to reduce turnovers
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2024), Pac-12 Freshman of the Year (2022), Pac-12 All-Freshman Team (2022), McDonald's All-American ( 2021 )
analysis: San Antonio added Ingram, a versatile wing with high basketball IQ and 3-point range, to their rebuild. He brings experience and smarts and can defend multiple positions. Floor spacing and playmaking give him rotational appeal.

strengths: Excellent size and playmaking ability • Strong rebounder and defender • High basketball IQ and clutch performer
weaknesses: Lacks a standout skill • Inefficient scoring percentages • Limited upside due to age
awards: 2× NCAA champion ( 2023, 2024 ), NCAA Final Four Most Outstanding Player (2024), Consensus first-team All-American ( 2024 ), Bob Cousy Award (2024), First-team All-Big East (2024), Second-team All- AAC (2022)
analysis: Indiana drafted Newton, a two-time champion point guard from UConn, for depth and size behind Tyrese Haliburton. His improved playmaking and interior finishing translate to a backup role. A seasoned guard with winning experience.

strengths: Excellent rebounder with high determination • Effective post scorer with good mobility • Uses 7'2 wingspan effectively defensively
weaknesses: Older than typical draft prospects • Short for an NBA center • Struggles with pick and roll defense
awards: NCAA rebounding leader (2024), AP honorable mention All-American ( 2024 ), MAC Player of the Year (2024), 2× First-team All- MAC (2023, 2024), Second-team All-MAC (2022), MAC Defensive Player of the Year (2022), 4× MAC All-Defensive team (2021–2024), 2× MAC tournament MVP ( 2022 , 2024 )
analysis: Indiana also took Freeman, a athletic mid-major big who competes and stretches the floor after a standout combine. His late rise and energy impressed scouts. Developmental rebounder and shot-maker with high motor.

strengths: Hard-nosed defender with versatility, off-ball awareness, and glass-crashing motor • impressive shotmaking and defensive athletic traits for a forward • dependable free-throw shooter (86.7% FT) showcasing shooting touch
weaknesses: Not a dynamic off-ball shooter, struggles to drain 3s off screens • lacks high-level pick-and-roll playmaking experience • raw ball-handling and playmaking need refinement
analysis: Dallas used its pick on Ajinça, a young French wing with shooting upside and defensive flashes. Could be stashed in Europe, he adds to the Mavericks’ long-term prospect pool. Low-risk international playmaker with size.

strengths: High shooting proficiency and touch • Effective passer with good vision • Improved rim protection and defense
weaknesses: Limited athletic explosiveness • Struggles to defend in space • Older age reduces potential growth
awards: Second-team All-ACC (2024), ACC All-Defensive team (2024), ACC Most Improved Player (2023)
analysis: Golden State re-acquired Post after a multi-trade shuffle, landing the skilled big with a smooth shooting stroke from Boston College. He offers floor spacing and interior passing as a low-leverage pick. Potential rotational center in a deep roster.

strengths: Excellent 3-point shooter • High basketball IQ • Versatile offensive fit
weaknesses: Limited athleticism • Defensive liabilities • Injury history concerns
awards: NCAA champion ( 2024 ), First-team All-Big East (2024), First-team All- Patriot League (2022), First-team Academic All-American ( 2024 )
analysis: Memphis traded up for Spencer, a UConn sharpshooter and key title team contributor. His off-screen shooting and toughness fit Memphis’s bench scoring needs. Veteran poise gives him a chance at early minutes.

strengths: High field goal percentage • Smart offensive and defensive player • Versatile in forward positions
weaknesses: Poor free throw shooter • Lacks explosive athleticism • Older prospect at age 24
awards: First-team All- WCC (2024), Washington Mr. Basketball (2019)
analysis: Boston took Watson, a versatile Gonzaga forward, on a two-way deal for interior defense and passing. He adds size and experience to the Celtics’ bench. Floor spacing and IQ make him a value depth option.

strengths: Explosive and athletic combo guard • Excellent finisher through contact • Rapidly improving outside shooter
weaknesses: Lacks experience at guard positions • Inconsistent defensive intensity • Not a high-volume scorer
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2023 )
analysis: Los Angeles selected Bronny, who’ll join his father’s Lakers despite limited college output, focusing on development and medical clearance maturity. Low-risk project on a rookie contract in a supportive environment. Narrative pick with long-term upside.

strengths: Versatile wing with strong defensive prowess and lateral mobility • two-way production (18.3 ppg, 6.0 rpg, 4.1 apg) showcasing scoring and playmaking • high basketball IQ and weak-side shot-blocking instincts
weaknesses: Knee injury concerns could limit availability and athleticism • below-average three-point consistency (33.3% 3PT) • lacks elite playmaking creation in half-court sets
awards: Third-team All-American – NABC ( 2024 ), First-team All- Big 12 (2024), Third-team All-Big 12 (2023), Big 12 All-Defensive Team (2023)
analysis: New York drafted McCullar, a Kansas veteran with two-way production derailed by injury, as a potential quick contributor. If healthy, he provides perimeter defense and secondary playmaking. Value pick to deepen the rotation.

strengths: Great length and athleticism • Intriguing shooting form • Strong hands and good passer
weaknesses: Extremely raw prospect • Slow outside shot release • Struggles with lateral movement
awards: Nike Hoop Summit (2024)
analysis: Toronto grabbed Chomche, a long-armed Cameroonian big, as a G League project for his length and defensive upside. He’s years from contributing but fits the Raptors’ player-development model. High-upside sleeper pick.

strengths: Athletic with great size and mobility • Effective rim protector and rebounder • Strong in pick and roll actions
weaknesses: Limited offensive skill set • Poor game awareness and decision-making • Prone to fouls and lacks shooting range
awards: NBA G League Winter Showcase champion ( 2024 )
analysis: Dallas closed the draft with Hukporti, a rebounding machine from Germany with flier upside despite injury concerns. The Mavs bet on his athleticism and motor as a late-round gamble. Low-risk pick to bolster future frontcourt depth.

strengths: Excellent playmaker and decision maker • Strong mid-range and three-point shooter • Effective in pick and roll situations
weaknesses: Below average defensively • Lacks physicality and strength • Struggles with explosiveness at the rim
awards: Second-team All-Big East (2024), Big East All-Freshman team (2022)
post draft awards: NBA G League Rookie Of The Year (2025), All-NBA G League Third Team ( 2025 ), NBA G League All-Rookie Team ( 2025 )

strengths: Skilled swingman with 6′7″ size and scoring versatility • reliable jump shooter with three-level scoring ability • solid showing at 2024 Portsmouth Invitational with 27.5″ vertical
weaknesses: Needs to improve defensive consistency against top-level wings • limited playmaking and ball-handling for creation • may struggle finishing through contact at 218 lbs
awards: Third-team Academic All-American ( 2024 ), Third-team All- Atlantic 10 (2021), Atlantic 10 All-Rookie Team (2020)

strengths: Tall, athletic with good defensive skills • Efficient playmaker with high A/TO ratio • Utilizes length and quickness defensively
weaknesses: Shooting mechanics and efficiency need work • Limited upside due to age • Struggles with off-ball efficiency
awards: 2× ACC Defensive Player of the Year (2023, 2024), Second-team All-ACC (2024), Third-team All-ACC (2023), 3× ACC All-Defensive Team (2022–2024), Louisiana Mr. Basketball (2020)

strengths: Excellent shooter with quick release • Good defensive skills with great length • Effective in transition and cutting
weaknesses: Older than most draft prospects • Lacks physical strength and muscle • Inconsistent scorer and limited facilitator
awards: Third-team All- Big 12 (2024), Big 12 All-Freshman Team (2021)

strengths: Chiseled forward with good athleticism and burst • comfortable mid-range scorer with developing perimeter shot • versatile defender able to guard multiple positions with length
weaknesses: Perimeter shooting remains inconsistent, 3PT still a work in progress • lacks explosive first step to consistently beat defenders • turnover-prone under pressure, needs improved vision
awards: First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2024 ), Second-team All-Pac-12 (2023), Jordan Brand Classic (2019)

strengths: High-IQ pick-and-pop threat knocking down 37.9% from long range • efficient inside scorer and reliable free-throw shooter (71.4% FT) • floor-spacing big with strong shooting mechanics
weaknesses: Lacks athleticism for defending in space and perimeter switches • more role player than shot creator with limited isolation skills • average lateral quickness may struggle in PnR defense
awards: 2x First-team All-Pac-12 ( 2023, 2024 ), Second-team All-Pac-12 ( 2022 )

strengths: Mid-major monster does it all with elite size and athleticism • Solid off-ball and on-ball defender with 7′1″ wingspan and versatility to guard 1–4 • Efficient shooter (41.1% 3PT, 72.5% FT) with smooth mechanics
weaknesses: Lacks primary playmaking and ball-handling creativity, not a shot creator • Older mid-major prospect with two ACL tears raising durability and upside questions • Not a high-volume scorer, may struggle to carry offensive load
awards: Conference USA Player of the Year (2024), First-team All- Conference USA (2024), 2× Third-team All-Conference USA (2021, 2023), Conference USA Defensive Player of the Year (2024), Conference USA All-Defensive team (2024)
post draft awards: NBA G League champion ( 2025 )

strengths: 6′6.5″ frame with 6′9.5″ wingspan and NBA-level athleticism • Skilled swingman with smooth shooting mechanics, catch-and-shoot threat (40% SL) • Active defender with lateral quickness and ability to guard multiple positions
weaknesses: Raw playmaking and ball-handling limit isolation creation • Inconsistent shot selection and streaky outside shooting under pressure • Needs to add strength to finish through contact and defend stronger wings
awards: 2× All- CBA Domestic Second-Team (2023, 2024), CBA Rookie of the Year (2023), CBA All-Star Rookie Challenge MVP (2023) [ 1 ]

strengths: Great size and athleticism • Effective scorer and rebounder • Strong defensive presence
weaknesses: Limited offensive range • Inconsistent post moves • Needs better ball handling skills
awards: 2× First-team All-Pac-12 (2023, 2024), Pac-12 All-Defensive Team (2024), Pac-12 tournament MOP ( 2024 ), 2× Nike Hoop Summit (2018, 2019)

strengths: Agile, skilled point guard who excels at attacking the hoop and playmaking • Averaged 19.6 PPG, 7.8 APG, 1.8 SPG in G League, showcasing scoring and defensive instincts • Prototypical combo guard size (6′2.75″, 6′8.5″ wingspan) for passing vision
weaknesses: Inconsistent outside shooting (career 32.8% 3PT) needs more reliable jumper • Turnover-prone under high usage with limited ball-handling creativity • Lacks elite athletic explosiveness, can struggle finishing through contact
awards: MAC Player of the Year (2023), First-team All- MAC (2023), Second-team All- Big 12 (2024), Big 12 All-Newcomer team (2024)

strengths: Reliable floor-spacer knocking down 43.8% of 3s at Saint Mary’s with advanced shooting mechanics • High basketball IQ enabling effective drive-and-kick actions and strong passing in PnR • Durable veteran with program-record 150 college games, exhibiting leadership
weaknesses: Average physical tools and athleticism limit finish at the rim • Limited defensive versatility, struggles to guard quicker wings due to lateral mobility • Secondary playmaker, not a primary shot creator and can overthink in reads
awards: SBL champion ( 2019 ), Second-team All- WCC (2022, 2024)

strengths: Prototype 6′11″ center with 7′5″ wingspan and plus athleticism for rim protection and PnR impact • Efficient interior scorer (60.3% FG) with strong putback and lob finishing • High motor rebounder and shot-blocker (8.2 RPG, 1.2 BPG) with defensive discipline
weaknesses: No perimeter game (0 3PT attempts) and 52.7% FT signals shooting touch concerns • Overcommits on defense leading to mistakes when switching • Older prospect (24) with slim development upside and raw offensive mechanics
awards: Third-team All-ACC (2023), ACC All-Defensive team (2023)

strengths: Excellent height and length for NBA wing • Strong catch and shoot ability • Effective in transition and as a cutter
weaknesses: Inconsistent NCAA production • Struggles with ball handling and creation • Poor rebounder and defender
awards: McDonald's All-American ( 2023 ), Jordan Brand Classic (2023), Nike Hoop Summit (2023), Mr. Pennsylvania Basketball (2023)

strengths: High shooting potential with NBA range • Strong physical build and core strength • Explosive vertical and highlight-reel dunks
weaknesses: Inconsistent focus and productivity • Below average defensive intensity • Limited size and flexibility for a forward

strengths: Versatile scorer with three-point range • Strong leadership and character • Impressive wingspan and free throw shooting
weaknesses: Below average size for NBA center • Struggles with speed and lateral movement • Inconsistent three-point shooting and rebounding
awards: First-team All-ACC (2024), Third-team All-ACC (2023)

strengths: Talented pull-up scorer with 35.4% on pick-and-roll threes and 49.4% on pull-up twos • Reliable playmaker averaging 5.4 APG to 2.4 TOV • Disruptive defender with 2.9% steal and 1.9% block rates
weaknesses: Struggles finishing through contact and limited finishing athleticism • Inconsistent outside shooting under pressure • Lack of elite burst off the first step

weaknesses: Lacks elite athleticism and burst off the dribble • Struggles guarding quicker players due to average lateral quickness • Inconsistent free-throw shooting and rebounding effort

weaknesses: Questions about shot consistency and ability to create off the dribble • Average lateral quickness limiting pick-and-roll defense • Needs to expand playmaking repertoire beyond catch-and-shoot role

weaknesses: Limited perimeter shooting range and mid-range jumper inconsistency • Average foot speed impacting defensive rotations on the perimeter • Lacks elite athletic burst for finishing through contact consistently

strengths: Prolific scorer with 19.1 PPG on 42.5% FG, 40.9% 3PT, and 81.4% FT • Well-built 198-lb frame enabling sturdy defense and off-ball roles • High-volume deep shooter (13.2 3PA/100 possessions) showcasing reliable catch-and-shoot ability

strengths: Classic back-to-the-basket center with polished post moves and strong touch around the rim • Excellent passer out of the post with above-average court vision • Athletic 6'10.75", 254-lb frame with 7'0" wingspan and 30" vertical for rim protection and rebounding
weaknesses: Raw perimeter shooting, jump shot needs significant work • Lacks lateral quickness to guard perimeter players effectively • Needs defensive improvement to adapt to modern pace-and-space schemes

weaknesses: Struggles with lateral quickness post-injury • Poor shooter from free-throw and three-point line • Limited dribbling ability in half-court sets
